z5shi0Tkke3obThzikokcg.review_text: Dosa has created a luxurious experience out of South Indian cuisine and style. Creative dishes, posh environment and the most exotic delicious cocktails I've ever tried.

Hq2TWfWXX18JODZj3P1JzQ.review_text: The good:  - Nice decor, and great for groups because of the space and the seating arrangements they have available. - The Vada Pav (vegetarian sliders) were super tasty.  - the white truffle dosa was yummy too - but I was suprised to find that it just had mashed potatoes in it. I was hoping for more!  The bad: - our server had a weird personality and attitude; because we were a party of 6, gratuity was automatically included, so maybe that is why... - I didn't think the Crispy Fish Pakora was anything special. -the Lamb Pepper Fry was not very appetizing. I didn't like the seasoning on the rice either.  - Surprised to hear that the Peony was SF's drink of the year at one point... but I may be biased because I just don't like spices/chili in my drinks.

1Af7_c8ZvOhPGJc5niRWGw.review_text: Really nice and professional service.  Otherwise, pretty overpriced and nothing out of the ordinary. I had shrimp curry, which was delicious, but not mind-blowing. It cost $30 (with a mandatory side). I can find equally delicious shrimp curry elsewhere in SF for half the price.  I guess the main draw of this restaurant is that it's convenient (it's right next to Kabuki).

wq5IO5dp0l9Z1wiTiSZmtQ.review_text: Dosa knows how to run a restaurant. Spectacular service and delicious food.   My boyfriend and I had a reservation (recommended, it was pretty busy for a Tuesday night) and we were seated immediately. The host gave us a run through of how their menu works and gave us his own recommendations, which was really helpful. Then our server, Megan H, came by and also helped us out with our selections. I was REALLY impressed by how knowledgable she was about the foods. She recommended drinks and answered all of our questions about portion size, flavor, etc. They also give you these chips to start off with, which are SO ADDICTING, and Megan was able to tell me what they were made of. Already obsessed.   The food was delicious. We got the scallops and samosa appetizers, which were definitely appetizer-sized portions. Just enough to split between the two of us. We also shared a dosa, which was very good when paired with the chutneys and the tomato-lentil soup that it came with. We also got two of their specialty cocktails, the Ante and the Peony, which were both quite good. Megan recommended their chai-white chocolate gelato (their dessert special that night), which we got, and it was amazing. Hints of chai in a creamy gelato... My boyfriend got their chai tea, which we were not really impressed with. We prefer spicier chais, and their's is quite mild. But all in all, it was a delicious meal.  The appetizers came out pretty quickly, but our dosa took awhile, which we were more than okay with. They kept us occupied with more of those chips. Then suddenly, we were told that since our dosa was taking awhile, it'd be on the house?! I have never had a restaurant take responsibility like that, and was most pleasantly surprised. Especially because I've waited longer for food from other restaurants. Dosa cares about the entire experience, not just the food, which was very refreshing. 5 stars, would recommend to a friend, and will definitely be back.

vJxM4GyUIu6xZ0zk9qpfTg.review_text: I decided to take my family here for dinner as it had so many great reviews.   Pros: -beautiful decor which gives the restaurant a very elegant feel -good service  Cons: -Dosa's were really bland and we were really disappointed as this was one of the worst dosa's we've ever had. The chutney was so-so and sambar was the best part of the meal.  -$13/dosa. seriously?  Here's the bottom line- If you're Indian or know what good, tasty Indian food tastes like, you're really going to be disappointed by this restaurant. We had the paneer & peas, white truffle masala, spicy basil and rava sada dosa's. The names sounded extravagant and tasty but definitely did not live up to it. Don't get me wrong, the restaurant is nice but if you're looking to eat delicious Indian food, hit up an actual Indian restaurant that serves authentic Indian food.

J5MPSiyECTVSjrq6_hVnCQ.review_text: Waitress was a little awkward, to say the least. I politely asked if I could sub a different booze in one of the house cocktails. Her answer "No!" in a very abrupt, loud voice. Now, having been a waitress, I totally understand that not all bartenders/chefs are okay with subbing, which is why I asked, but I would never have said it that way. It left a bad taste in my mouth, which was exacerbated by the fact that we weren't asked how our food was until after we were almost done, and the bus boy/food runners did most of the actual checking on us/filling our waters/clearing our plates (they were great by the way, so we slipped the most attentive one extra cash on our way out).   Service aside (which had been good the last time we were here), the food was awesome. We had a kale/carrot/cashew salad and lentil patties with an awesome yogurt sauce as appetizers. I had fish moilee, which was white fish (don't think the menu specified the type), with a really flavorful sauce over curry leaf rice. It was one of the best Indian food dishes I've had in a long time. Hubby had duck vindaloo, which was really spicy, but delicious, and the coconut rice was creamy and delicious.   Atmosphere is nice - pretty decor, comfortable chairs, etc.   The food was definitely 4.5 stars, but I've rounded down for service, which was more like a 2/3.

3cnIyELXdZa9C9nFH5NXtg.review_text: Looking to experience the finer side of Indian Dining, my friend and I decided to make a trip out to Dosa.  We didn't make reservations so we had to make 45 minutes (not really a problem since we were able to explore Japantown a bit).    Once seated we knew knew we were going straight for the Duck Vindaloo and Prawn Masala.  We need help with the Dosa selection though because wel, there are so many.  We ended up with the White Truffle Masala.  The Duck Vindaloo was quite good.  The Vindaloo sauce itself had the typical spicy/sour taste, but unlike the ones you get at "lesser" Indian places, the flavors truly danced on your taste buds.  I didn't get to taste the duck breast, but ended up with the leg instead.  Honestly, it was just okay, but I have always preferred breast of drumstick.  The Prawn Masala was also quite good.  Another dish that was enhanced with the use of higher standard ingredients.  The flavor was familiar, but more sophisticated.  The Dosa was delicious, and the white truffle oil really stood out.  Flaky, crispy, and chewy all at once  Best pairing is with the lentil soup, which I thought was amazing!  We also had a couple of drinks.  My friend got the Peony and she thought it was on the sweeter side.  I got the Winter Smash and thought it was quite delicious.  So delicious I got another.  Service was quick, friendly and helpful, and really compliments the more sophisticated Indian atmosphere.

cEhMBD1_FhyzmzL_AJPG5g.review_text: Had a great time with my girlfriends. We went in for dinner on a Thursday night and Mike was our server - such a delight. This was our first experience at an Indian restaurant and were not very familiar with the food. He answered all of our questions and gave us awesome recommendations. The food was delicious and the service was outstanding. We will definitely be coming back and requesting Mike as our server again!

-FhWNXl3Xecvdas9Fhkxwg.review_text: Dosa is OUT OF THIS WORLD GOOD.  In an area where there are a lot of great options to eat, DOSA is one of the best I  have dined at in a long while.  Yes, the food was very good, but so too was the service and they sure do have a great wine list.  Bravo for your wine selections.    Our server was able to explain every dish we asked about.  We ended up sharing some appetizers including a lentil dumpling...beware this is not what you think.  i liken it to an indian version of a mexican layered bean dip.  Same colors too...different flavors all together though.  We love the papadams.  We also loved the 'fries' that we dined on.  Each of us selected a different entree.  All of them came grandly wrapped in a thick or thin dosa which enticed us before it even was placed before our drooling mouths.  I had a masala dosa.  This is a basic spiced potato mixture served in a large wrapping...similar to a crepe or burrito.  It is accompanied by a sweet tomato sauce, tangy green sauce and delicious spicey soup.  Another of us chose the egg dosa...its ALL ABOUT THE EGG.  It too came beautifully presented only open face this time.  Beth had a paper Dosa.  It was thin and crispy rather than chewy crepy.  And so much more.  We all enjoyed the dinner so much.  We cannot wait to return.  I saw a puffed bread walking by that I will have to try next time....its a big balloon bread filled with steam.  They bring it to your table inflated and then you get to stab it and let the steam out.  Again...the wine was devine and well priced for the quality.  We had a CabFrancis of some sort...wish i could remember!  Beth took a picture of the label I will have to get the name.  Anyhow...we loved it so much we ordered another for $48.00.  In another restaurant I bet you would have paid much more than this.  A meal with appetizers and wine came out to 350 or so...two bottles and gratuity included.  I don't know why anyone gives Dosa 4 stars when they can give them 5. I almost forgot, they have a tasting menu with wine parings for something like 40.00 or so.  Out of this world.  :)

4Xgpz7LNlNJAETiYFCRVuw.review_text: Glad I finally got a chance to try Dosa out, after walking by regularly and hearing about it so much. It's very elegant and beautiful inside, with high ceilings and big wooden tables, but still maintains a comfortable and kwasi-casual atmosphere.   We had a drink at the bar while waiting for the rest of our party, which is very open and sleek. I had the Bengali Gimlet, with curried nectar and lime juice, which was exquisite. I love the use of curry- very inventive and flavorful. We had made a reservation for Sunday dinner for 4 only a few hours before but they seated us with no problem in the cozy upstairs dining room after the other two had arrived.  Food! I tried:  Prawn-Chili Fry - I thought this was just okay, but one really loved this.  Samosas - Very tasty, I do love me some ground, spiced veggies stuffed in fried  pastries and dipped into varying flavor-packed sauces. Nailed it! The other star here was actually a small side salad, dressed in what seemed to be some sort of lemon-cumin vinaigrette. I wish I could order more of this as an entire dish as well!  Chennai Chicken - Not too crazy about this dish, something was a bit lacking for me.  White Truffle Masala Dosa - I may be a sucker for anything with truffles, but this one knocked it out of the park. A giant, thin crepe that is simultaneously pillowy-soft, yet crispy, filled with creamy, spiced, mashed potatoes and white truffle oil, served alongside three unique (fantastic!) sauces for tearing and dipping. We inhaled it in less than two minutes and had to order another.  The staff was very friendly, prompt, and knowledgeable of the menu, and the food was overall delicious. Price for a nice dinner for 4 with drinks was pretty reasonable as well, definitely with the price. I will definitely be back!

mpm9olv35gqQePUdQvK62g.review_text: This place had some good things going for it, and then some neutral things.  Good: - Restaurant is very aesthetically appealing, in all ways - Great menu, everything looked really good and it was hard to narrow down - Papadum. yum.  Neutral: - Dining companion and I ordered different dosas. His marsala dosa came out big and overflowing the plate, and my paneer dosa came small and tightly wrapped. Wish we had known this difference up front. - Paneer dosa seemed slightly dry and lacking in texture. Even when dipped in the sauces, it still seemed to miss some kind of structure or relief from the soft texture. It was good and tasty, just wished for some structure or crunch. - Side order of poori was average, small portion for price  Meh: -We ordered, and our food was out in 10 minutes. We had timed it with a movie at kabuki but then we had, 45 minutes to kill. Our reservation was at restaurant's opening time but we felt rushed by it coming out so quickly (though I didn't feel though that was the intention, waiter acknowledged its speedy arrival).  Overall experience was good, mostly due to setting and ambiance.

N5C4MR_2mffwTnMqwjN9bw.review_text: Pros:  Kerala Moilee is awesome! so is the moong salad with paneer and watermelon pieces. Their vada paav is the bomb- literally.  Cons: expensive drinks are not that great. You just cannot add curry leaves and expect an alcoholic drink to taste good. NO.

7Ma166LlK2pwbtA2HSzbfg.review_text: I thought this was just OK. It was not bad, but basically to me you seem to be paying a bit more for food that you can get elsewhere for cheaper and perhaps even better tasting. The decor is very nice inside, but again I do not think its the best food available. Good just not great.

OF8eXI41LKKIFMZ30IidAg.review_text: I mostly love the food here. It is delish. So many spices, masterfully wielded.   I also love the fact that they have so many gluten-free options, and will provide a menu with all of the dietary restriction information spelled out.  I was disappointed today, though. I had the Chicken Xacuti for lunch with a friend there a few days ago and it was absolutely delicious. Hoping to share the deliciousness with my mother, I took her to Dosa this evening. Sadly, this Chicken Xacuti was made with so much hot pepper that it hid the delicious spice mixture of non-hot pepper spices like cardamon that made the Chicken Xacuti that I had for lunch there sing. It was very sad that they are inconsistent. When they aren't inconsistent, they are golden.  Both dosas that my lunch companions and I had, the spicy basil dosa and the spring vegetable dosa, were very good, and the sauces that they came with are marvelous.  The surroundings are beautiful, but the music is a little too loud.

yh8_9Ix1wp9dekvyOZbilQ.review_text: I love Indian food, but I guess I never knew that it could be taken to such an elegant place! First off, the space is gorgeous, with romantic lighting and soaring ceilings. They serve delicious wine at the bar or with your meal, and even offer a wine pairing menu if you so desire.   My friends and I came in unfamiliar with a lot of the menu but were told we absolutely had to try a dosa (duh). We went with the white truffle variety because, really, when something comes with white truffle, how do you say no? I liked it a lot - the texture was perfect, but I found it a tad salty.   The highlight of the meal was the lamb dish, recommended by our super informative and friendly server. It was cooked absolutely perfectly! We also had a vegetable side that I can't seem to find on the menu now - it may have been a seasonal item, which featured brussels sprouts and was kind of forgettable.  I was truly impressed by the lamb dish as well as the beautiful ambiance and attentive service. I will absolutely come back here again... I'm just waiting for the next opportunity!

jgi0iam1b2XEqYAQBP7NRQ.review_text: This is a great place for a large, family-style, group dinner. Came here with a work group, and they sat us in the loft area (which is semi-private). Dosa was able to put together a crowd-pleasing menu (for a mix of folks from those who love Indian food to those who'd never had it), provided excellent service, and were quick to refill wine.  Food was fresh and flavorful. Prices are reasonable, and staff is accommodating. Great selection of beer, wine, and liquor.

DcT_1cSf0q82gHs3LbeRSQ.review_text: Very very good place.  The best Dahi Vada and Vada Pav I have had in the US. The Dahi Vada is presented in a very beautiful way, just like the previous reviews have mentioned.  The mixed chili uthapam is really spicy. Not for the faint hearted!

DlYUfHUOWwlwG0m7QVyf1Q.review_text: Trust this review I'm Indian. This place is really good and you can tell because the place has mostly Indian people eating inside. You can always tell if a place is good if you see native people eating there. Best to go during lunch because they have thali which is amazing. Nice atmosphere.

eQp9pnMTLgrTkmKLv7Mkog.review_text: If you want dosa, this is the place to come. I have never been disappointed by their dosas or uttapams. Sometimes they have too many customers so when the dosa comes to you, seems like it had been sitting for a bit, so not too too crispy, but still delicious.  Key to have a good dining experience: - Must make a reservation: walk-ins are available but be prepared to wait for an hour at least (staff is super nice about it but still, waiting for an hour is sometimes too much) - Just get the dosas or uttapams. I find the other main dish just ok

A2mAJMZBc_r9sFNJgHDukQ.review_text: Great spot for folks looking to get away from Indian food that solely consists of "Chicken Tikka Masala".  Dosa's take on South Indian food is great - everything has so much flavor.  Our favorite was the Paper Masala Dosa and Duck Vindaloo (very spicy).  We always end up ordering way too much food.  Only negative is that the service can be a bit slow, but that's it.

BAXXJrlGW6o8zWfw47q1Tg.review_text: My favorite indian restaurant in the city. Conveniently located three blocks from my new pad in Pac Heights, I've become a regular. I came here for a dinner meeting and was able to kick it at the bar with a friend while we waited on our party.  The service was great, and the girl to guy ratio was unbelievable. There were literally 15 girls at the bar and then my friend and I. Ow Ow. They seamlessly transferred over our tab to the table which usually comes with an eye roll, however they were extremely polite.  We must have ordered seven appetizers to share and they were incredible. Forgive me for not remember the names of everything, but whatever item was bread filled with potatoes was insane. If someone could drop me a line if they remember what it was called I will update my review!

3oC57Z24H8GfR6jXiJJyUw.review_text: Dosa was a unique restaurant   When you walk in, you notice the beautiful high ceilings and long chandeliers, impressive art work. The piece behind the main bar is 12 feet with has writing in Arabic and other languages.   The food menu was reasonably priced and quite the variety of spices and flavors. I had the shrimp masaqa and it was delicious!   Wine menu was tasty as well..Service was excellent!   Will defiantly go back next time I am in SF!

t1t00_iGzFtQGAwlI00_tQ.review_text: An incredible culinary experience of authentic Southern Indian food at it's finest. There is something for everyone here, even if you don't like Indian food, you will LOVE this place. The chef has made these stunning concoctions that will blow your mind and palate, everything I tried was top notch, finished off by the best mango lassi I've ever had. Can't wait to go back to try more!

0BypTx7HWe0beJHHXMr9Bw.review_text: the dosas and uttapams are incredible here. so many choices, such great variety and consistently delicious.  the food here is very heavily spiced, probably not great for those with a sensitive stomach. highly recommended is the coconut seafood soup, lamb curry and kerala fish.  great service, excellent ginger beer, will definitely be back to try the huge variety of dosas and uttapams.

ixAzWY0pBHd-1P0gUPFcTw.review_text: When you first step into Dosa, it is a stunning restaurant, but you will be continuously impressed by the service, the food and the experience.  I love the lamb meatballs, fire broth, the calamari, the prawn masala with coconut rice, the dosas.   Truth be told, I have not ordered a bad dish here - everything smells and tastes wonderful with spice and flavor.    Side note: Dosa is ahead of their time with thier nut menu - which features every dish and outlines which nuts are in which dish - which is super helpful to those with nut allergies.  Rest asured.

AAAEAdjYTh09xguDlAYTJQ.review_text: Don't expect to walk in and be seated at this sophisticated Southern Indian restaurant!  The management knows their loyal customers well and they strive to seat everyone precisely, but not before, specified reservation time. In the meantime, enjoy the soft violet coloring of the space, take time to notice the beautiful details that went into the design of the airy main rooms.  Be transported to modern Chennai. Order one of their special mixed drinks.  I once had a violet liquer cocktail that was like nothing else I've ever tasted.  It's seasonal and not often offered, but if it's on the menu, I recommend it as an iced sip of heaven.  When you are seated, take time to peruse the extensive menu, especially the Dosa listings.  If you are like me and you've had your fill of Americanized Indian restaurants, seek out the unusual items on DOF's menu and feel confident in ordering absolutely anything.  If you like lamb as I do, order the Dosa with Lamb Keema.  Your mouth and your tummy will thank you.

dliupsToKzf6Jp2EPUWqOw.review_text: The dishes we had at Dosa were innovative and beautifully presented. The coconut corn soup had delicious, subtle flavors, and the sweet potato dosa was an awesome twist on a classic. The flavor and spicing of the sambar and coconut chutney were spot on.   The atmosphere and service were also great. We were seated immediately at the communal table at 6PM on a Saturday, although the restaurant quickly filled up by 6:30PM. The service was lightning quick.

fsJL8tj_VdJ-EFMILBNGjQ.review_text: Can I give it 6 stars!? I LOVE this place! The wonderful experience begins as you walk through the door. The place is gorgeous, the staff is really friendly and helpful. But I would come back if neither of those were true. The food! Oh, the food! I started with the kohlrabi and cauliflower soup and my wife had to restrain me from licking the bowl. The North and South samosas were also excellent (the South was my favorite... caramelized onion... yum!). Then I tried several different dosas and each gave me a different experience of flavors... subtle and dare I say, complex. Run, don't walk to Dosa on Fillmore. You will thank me.

VS1H_wjt4SC8VtUDyt6c3g.review_text: Great ambiance, high end establishment. I recommend trying the Sweet potato dosa, its unique, delicious and not too spicy. Monsoon madness beverage was refreshing but had more ice than I would have liked. Service was decent, however the waiters changed from the beginning to end of our meal.   Even though I was wearing tennis shoes the floor was slippery where we were seated. Due to cozy distance between other tables whenever waiters passed by they kept tucking in so we are closest to the table, like we are little kids;)

5BQy8hXX0nc9YXt60k_tDQ.review_text: I wanted to take my wife to dinner on her bday @ SFO where vegeterian is good.  The two restaurants i could think of were Amber India and Dosa. Amber, its a good one too but we have been there before. I have also been to Dosa on Valencia but not the one on Fillmore. I came to know that the Fillmore was a very good one. So we went to Dosa @ Fillmore. The moment we entered in, i could only say "wow". The ambience was perfect. We got a table on 2nd floor and it was perfect. Food was really tasty and service was simply superb. We could complete all the dishes we ordered leaving behind the empty containers. If you like indian Chai dont foeget to order the masala chai at the end. I felt very refreshing after having it. Perfect spot for a date. Ambience, Service and Food were fantastic, what can one expect more than this. I would recommend this place a must go.

iK5oMORPCmoWUmannptD-Q.review_text: Good food, great space.  Docked one star for price.  (Maybe I'm just cheap)

yY3Uj1cm3LVaMbtFvd8mfg.review_text: Great cocktails, tasty Indian food...and definitely worth a try but a little on the pricier side.  This fine city offers better options for the buck in my humble opinion.

sRcIxpu4RRkb0FMQSq1euw.review_text: Dosa has brought indian food to a whole new level for me. Although I heard great things about the restaurants from many of my friends (many of them that grew up with authentic Indian food), the elegance of the restaurant, the attentive servers, and quality and plating of the food far exceeded my expectations.  I had their summer seasonal tasting menu, which consisted of 3 courses from a pre-set menu for $39. Each course is a half-sized portion of the original, and thoroughly satisfying. With recommendations from the server (since I'm a wimp when it comes to spicy food), I had the watermelon salad (mild), the trumpet mushroom uttapam (mild), and the chicken eggplant (mild/medium).   Everything was delicious, the mushroom uttapam was definitely my favorite - my boyfriend also liked it even though he hates mushrooms (strangely); the chicken in the chicken eggplant curry was extremely tender.   My boyfriend ordered the tamil lamb, which was also extremely tender (medium spicy) and yummy. It was a bit too spicy for me though.   Some side notes: - They have preset levels of spiciness in their dishes - Make sure to call ahead and make a reservation, it was pretty busy the night I went - Their chai tea has free refills - There is ample street parking around the area

2rPT_0AAVfNlqfia_zcDgg.review_text: Very poorly coordinated. First, they told us the wait will be 30 minutes. We ended up waiting for 1.5 hours. Seemed like they didn't keep of track of wait list. Food was pricey and not that great.

LikzZL2O64FzmMniu34LMQ.review_text: Excellent cocktails and generous, shareable portions. Chicken biryani was delicious.   Atmosphere and decor are warm but impressive.

wUJEBK06EQtSNtzCVX29Fw.review_text: Very good place .Good ambiance and Food was awesome  :)

TGYT19BPhNCeTyL_aCsO7g.review_text: My most recent experience at Dosa on Fillmore was quite pleasant. I'd visited both Dosa locations in the past and had a preference for the Valencia location because it felt cosier and more inviting. I'd commented to several friends in the past that although the Fillmore location looks nice, the combination of the high ceiling and the size of the restaurant makes it feel less private and more exposed.  However, on my most recent visit I was seated in a little area on the second floor just next to/behind the bar. Sitting up in that area I felt far more cozy and far less exposed. (It would also be an ideal place to people watch.)  The food at both locations is good. As their name implies, they make many different kinds of dosas, but they also a few other dishes like curries. I sampled a soup, a duck curry, an uttapam, and a lamb dish on my most recent visit and was quite satisified.

x39_Y8G_TY7sncLJfsYEMQ.review_text: The only reason I would not give this a five star rating is that the food falls short. Just a little short. And by little I mean the length of a subatomic particle little.  It wasn't crowded, we went here on a Sunday at 1. The ambience is excellent and the waitress was very good.   I had the mint lemonade (on the assumption that it would help cure the thirty-six-wheel-truck that was roaming around in my head because of too much vodka the night before). There was nothing remarkable about the lemonade.   I ordered the White-Truffle-Masala-Dosa. Mostly because that just sounded interesting - usually in an Indian place that has dosas I will get the Rava dosa because I happen to be partial to those.   The dosa did not disappoint. It itself was well made. The Sambhar was rich and not watered down and could have been a touch spicier (that's just nitpicking). The coconut chutney was good too. I could taste the white-truffle-oil and it did really make the dosa delightful. PROTIP: White-Truffle-Oil does not do much for hangovers :-)  I also had the Rasmalai which was presented very nicely, I loved the bowl. It needed to be a touch sweeter though.  All in all - I will go here again. Without hesitation. And on my list of places for dosas this place is next after my friend Prashant T's house.

hXkCICsGQcjERtGC_zkYNg.review_text: Went here for 2013 Dine About Town.  It was okay.  Food:  The highlight was definitely the scallop appetizer.  The remainder of the meal was okay - nothing exceptional, but not horribly bad.  Ambience:  Pretty sweet. If I came here again, it'd be for the ambience and bar.  The chandeliers are beautiful with various conversation pieces throughout the restaurant.  Definitely a cool place to hang out.

OdIiVC_BOi38jrFRvdXd3g.review_text: As our home-base was Japantown in SF, my fiancee and I looked for something new for dinner on a Wednesday night. After some Yelp sleuthing, we came upon Dosa on Fillmore.   Something that we haven't tried before? Yep! Something that isn't Japanese food? Yep! We didn't require transit to get there? Yep! The meal wouldn't break the bank? Yep!  So with that information in tow, we walked 5 minutes from our hotel to Dosa on Fillmore. To our surprise, the restaurant was quite upscale, but still retained a casual feel. We were greeted by the friendly hostess, who quickly led us to our table (booked on OpenTable).   Of course, we couldn't go to an establishment named after a food and not try said food item. So along with a Masala Dosa, my fiancee ordered a Paneer & Cheese Uttapam and an order of the Chennai Chicken to start.   First came some homemade lentil chips. It was a bit oily, but burst with flavour (surprising, since the chip itself is very plain from what I assumed was ground lentils). I could only have a single chip, but oil aside the flavour was great.   Soon after, we received the Chenna Chicken, which was served in a bowl on top of a bed of red onions along with a savoury yogurt-based dipping sauce. This was my favorite part of the meal. The chicken pieces were breast meat, but still remained juicy. The seasoning had a substantial spicy kick to it, but when paired with the yogurt dip the flavours all came together and only really nice touch of heat remained at the end of the bite.   Next came the dosa, which comes with 3 dipping sauces: a spicy lentil soup, and a pair of tomato  and coconut chutneys. The lentil soup by itself explodes with flavour. The chutneys were both very delicious as well. As for the dosa itself- the dosa is basically a large, thin crepe folded in half with the filling inside. The crepe had a wonderful sweetness to it that mixed very well with the dipping sauce flavours. The filling (in this case potatoes, onions and cashews) was also very good, but was a touch heavy (since it's almost all starch). That said, all the flavours came together really well, and no one ingredient overpowered any of the others. The variety in dipping sauce flavours kept each bite different from the next, so overall it was a very engaging meal. I honestly thought we didn't order enough and insisted we order something else (the uttapam), but after the dosa and chicken starter my fiancee and I were stuffed. However, the uttapam came to the table so we couldn't ignore it.   The uttapam is basically a pancake with various ingredients embedded in it, and sliced like a pizza for your enjoyment. The same dipping sauces that accompany the dosa are present, providing the same flavour variety you get with the dosa. From what we could finish, the uttapam was delicious as well. The paneer (cheese) was mild, and added a nice creaminess to the dish which otherwise would've been a touch on the dry side.   I was really glad my fiancee decided to try this place. While she doesn't share the same enthusiasm as I do with the meal, it opened my eyes to another delicious aspect of Indian cuisine that I never knew existed. I just hope that the few dosa eateries in Vancouver are as good as this place was.

3S53VaMDPy8Lywk2TuPb4A.review_text: Curiosity killed the review.  Oh no, that was the cat.  Maybe it is expectations that killed the review.  The service: I only had one beer.  And my dinner companion only had one glass of wine.  Why?  Our server was basically absent.  After taking our order, he did not check back to see how our meal was proceeding.  And when the food was dropped by, it was quickly deposited on the table.  It seemed like a race.  Overall, for fine dining, it was some of the worst service I have witnessed in some time.  The ambiance: This was the strong point of the experience.  It is a very nice room.  I have to say the high ceilings, the decorative touches, and general overall styling of the room comes together to create an exotic and elegant space.  However, even here, the tables along the wall are placed too close together.  There is no sense of privacy.   I would not want to be sitting at one of these tables for a date.    The food: Overall, the food ranged from mediocre to slightly above average.  We selected the four course tasting menu.  I think this is where we may have lost our server.  After we told him we were each going to order the tasting menu, he became disinterested.   Even for a tasting menu, each of the portions were relatively small.  Starter: She selected - Grilled Calamari (the calamari was overcooked and tough) I selected - Chennai Chicken (this was actually pretty good.  the chicken was tender and the spices were nice) We shared.  Mini Dosa; She selected - Masala Chutney (This was good but not outstanding.) I selected - Spring (This was their take on a spring roll.  It was also good but not outstanding. We shared.  Each came with a trio of sauces -  Tomato - I liked it. Red Bean - She liked it. Coconut - neither of us are big fans of coconut.  South Indian Curry: She selected - South Indian Lamb Kofta (This was my favorite dish.  the lamb was tender.  The sauce was mild but had a very nice combination of spices.) I selected - Prawn Masala (The prawns were overcooked and rubbery.  The sauce was pretty amazing.  Another relatively mild sauce with an excellent blend of spices.) We shared.  Dessert: She selected - Gulab Jamoon (Neither of us liked this very much.  it was rather bland.) I selected - Banana Cream Pie (While it was a very small portion, it was actually very tasty.  It reminded my of my mom's banana pudding.) We shared.  Overall:  Based on feedback from multiple friends and  reviews, I had high expectations.  However, on this particular night, Dosa on Fillmore did not meet these expectations.  If I graded them as a run of the mill Indian restaurant, they would score 3 stars.  However, as a fine dining experience, they rate at 2.5 stars and, in this case, I am rounding down.  Service = 1 star (graded against fine dining expectations) Food = 3 stars Ambiance = 4 stars

rWcNIXUBOSQkq5WgzPFGCg.review_text: Food is always wonderful. The staff not so much.... I will still come in because I love the food. I will just try Dosa at their other location see how their staff is.

zElA4vbH2RzEdaQNhQHI6Q.review_text: Beautiful ambiance with good food. I think it would great place for happy hour with some friends.

zD9JC4DlFzCNwGCfYCvp9A.review_text: I really like this restaurant, and I feel as if in some ways, this location is more successful than the Mission location. First, the space is much larger. It's elegant without being overdone, and not fussy at all. Think high ceilings, large banquettes, and generous tables. The space is really quite beautiful.   Next, the food is just excellent. I like the Mission location's food too, but there are more offerings here--super appetizers (samosas = yummy), generous dosas with tasty fillings, delicious curries, and elegant entrees. Their salads are good, too. I've enjoyed several and have never been disappointed. I *love* the keema dosa, but the potato-based fillings are excellent, too. Even better, everything is so reasonably priced (between $12 and $15 per dosa or uttapam; it's between $20 and $32 for the entrees, which I've never felt the need to order because the dosas are so darn good!).   Each time I've been, my servers have been friendly and knowledgeable. I've also had some stellar drinks from the bar (an excellent sidecar and some very good wine). Add easy parking at the Kabuki to the mix (which is harder at their Valencia location despite that parking garage on 21st), and this is just a winning space. I will be back--many, many times.

G5LXEaxhQMF_BVjNHkVr7g.review_text: Dosa continues to spicily satisfy. As somewhat of a regular, I've gone through my share of dosas and uttapams, and if you're new to the restaurant, that's where you really have to start.   But otherwise... damn the namesake and try some of their other dishes, like the rather excellent peppercorn chicken I had at lunch the other day, or the coconut cilantro fish at dinner. Or go traditional on weekend brunch with their fine rendition of thali (really a great way to get sudden exposure to the varied flavors of South India).  Whether I've gone in the day or night, the place stays lively (almost bursting on Thur/Fri/Sat). It's super to see a now "older" restaurant keeping its charm and substance, but staying modern; a good sign that Dosa is going to be (if not already) a San Francisco institution.   Locals note: I now live a block from this location so I'm expecting to use the bar quite a bit, itself with its own sense of spice and flair!

D0F7xbsRRsdKA_omCoYR0g.review_text: Must visit @ SF! great food... Ambience... Service....Pricy but worth it! Sambar Idly - best in the bay area.

YdJhhIhOtgvOVLUW_5nRvw.review_text: Awesome food. Awesome ambience. Always crowded. Make sure to reserve well ahead of time. Loved the masala and rava dosa they have. They have some cool opentable integration options. You can pay within the app.

9i14yU2CqdoK2Pi8yAvT2g.review_text: The best dosa I ever had in US.  I had dosa in most of the restaurants in San Jose, Dallas and New Jersey locations. But this place beats all other restaurants in it's taste, ambience, authenticity.  The main food items to try here :  1) Dahi Vada: very delicious and beautifully presented  2) Lamb kheema dosa 3) Chilly garlic uttappam  4) Vada Pav 5) masala dosa

drI9J9xeWephVGlfMC487w.review_text: Everything was so delicious! I especially loved the White Truffle Masala Dosa. It was so lovely, chock full of spiced potato goodness with just enough truffle oil to give it a heavenly aroma and a rich, earthy taste. It was terrific on its own, and also nice with the cilantro-mint chutney. The Uttapam with Paneer and Peas was also really nice. It's almost like an adult version of grilled cheese I particularly liked it paired with the subtly spiced Channa Bhatura (a chickpea masala dish which is also terrific with its own soft, puffy wheat bread) and Dahl Rice (rice with yogurt and veggies). The rice is a terrific way to cut spice and bring out the flavors of a dish. The cocktails, even my virgin versions, are really nice. I recommend the Peony, it's a gin-based cocktail with has hibiscus masala nectar, coconut juice, lime and and a hint of chili. Even minus the gin, It''s delicate and quite refreshing. Dessert was a teensy bit disappointing, but I really appreciated that they had vegan offerings. The service at Dosa is really gracious and the atmosphere is romantic. Both make it great for a date, or in my case, a quite girls night out.

1UZTj9lu3TzMggKGA1wDiQ.review_text: Everything is wonderful at FOSA on Fillmore. The ambience, the wait staff, and of course, the food.  We have driven from San Jose on many special occasions for this lovely place, and will do it again!

b1ZmZoX5ALWkn_Nhu73QgQ.review_text: King of Indian cuisine. I had no idea what a dosa was before this, but my boyfriend took me here because of great reviews from his Indian friend and Yelp. Best things were the Dahi vada and white truffle masala dosa (yes the white truffle makes the difference). OMG honestly an Indian foodgasm in your mouth - as it completely changes your perception of what Indian food should be.

CAoVa48TkH-L_56tyaxpmA.review_text: Never have I been disappointed when dining here - food is great, service prompt and friendly, and the atmosphere hip and happening - will always return.

kpL9GJYRkE_DYV6dsM-Y_g.review_text: They were busy when I visited, despite being a Tuesday night. The ambiance and service were excellent. This is not a traditional Southern Indian Restaurant, the interior is modern and the menu inventive.   Ordered the following: Poori Bread - Excellent Chutney Sampler - Good but would prefer more interesting flavors - It paired very well with the Poori though Bhel Puri - Excellent Lamb Kofta (Meatballs) - Excellent Prawn Masala with a side of Coconut Rice - Excellent Truffle Oil Dosa - Unusual flavor for Southern Indian Food but Excellent Chicken Biryani - The only dish I did not like. Biryani should be in the comfort food category - for me the topping was too heavily spiced for this type of dish and I love spicy food. Pear Tart Thing - Excellent Chocolate Chilli Mouse - Was not quite what I expected - it is more cake-like with a small amount of mouse on top. It was Ok, but I preferred the Pear Tart.  Overall a very pleasant dinner. Could have been 5 stars if not for the over-spiced Biriyani.

nGqmdnQb_xUHNcPheQbwtg.review_text: This is not your typical Indian restaurant. The menu is very creative, so you have spinoffs on typical Indian dishes, often with non traditional ingredients. There are also some typical Indian menu items that frequent diners to Indian restaurants would know about. The portions are appropriate, so you could easily be full with one entree, but could stuff yourself with an entree, & splitting an appetizer & dessert. The menu's core is South Indian but some North Indian dishes are offered as well. They do not have traditionally associated with other regions of India such as Gujarat. Vegetarians & vegans will not have problems here as the menu has marked items & the staff are familiar with ingredients as well.  My wife & I have had: Great beet croquettes, rava dosa, the winter uttappam, masala dosa, kale fritters, the 5 mini uttappam combo & the desert rasa malai.  3 things I do not like are: * tables are very close to each other so it can be difficult to hear the person in front of or next to you that you actually want to hear * reservations are hard to get, though you can walk in &  possibly get seated * the salt lassi drink was extremely thick & salty.

M-ZvzpcvFBrS2A72MHf6Aw.review_text: Ambiance and decor was very nice, and the bar seemed to be very lively.  However, my family and I came here for dinner and were extremely disappointed with the food. Three out of the four family members got sick from the food.  We ordered the duck plate and all they have us was the dark, leg meat of the duck; very small and cheap pieces.  Would never come back to this restaurant for their food, maybe the bar.

x_bpi_SRk-UNQ6-gfNJqnA.review_text: There are hits and misses with this restaurant. I've been here a handful of times now with different groups to order different things.  Ambience: Beautiful two-story restaurant with nice light fixtures and classy atmosphere. Although, once we sat upstairs and I thought the images of skinny village children and old men were not comforting as we indulged in rich foods.  Service: Always promptly seated when you have reservations and the entire group shows up. Service is efficient and friendly. Minus a chutney episode we had the last time for Ayesha's birthday. Basically one of the managers flung a spoon of chutney on three girls while picking up the plates (one of them being the b'day girl!) It kinda put a damper on our evening because we were supposed to go out afterward to Harry's but instead they spent time in the bathroom; hand-drying their pants. The guy as nice enough to reimburse them for dry cleaning although it's still a pain to deal with.  Food: +Chennai Chicken- probably my favorite thing on the menu; spicy but tasty breaded chicken with yogurt dipping sauce +Samosas- regular North Indian samosa and South Indian samosa with masala filling +Vada Pai- OMG SO SPICY; i was drinking water for 10 minutes with shots of raw sugar and couldn't enjoy the rest of my meal; also ended up with a stomach ache because of this +Idli Fries- interesting concept; its basically a fried idli in the shape of a wedge fry +Collard Green Dosa- not my favorite; collard greens just don't mix with dosa +Paper Dosa- typical standard dosa with a side of sambar +Paneer & Peas Dosa- I thought I'd like this but the peas were throwing off the taste +Lamb Keema Dosa- the lamb comes on the side and its perfectly seasoned +Uttapam- this was a favorite at the table and the mushroom one looked great  +Bengali Gimlet- amazing gin-based drink and I'm Bengali so this was a must-have for me  I prefer Udupi Palace in the Mission to Dosa for food but Dosa has its ambiance I guess.  -Hungry Hungry Pongy

ve5OWa-qh2r8HkAWiQyPSg.review_text: Vegetarians go nuts at this place :) Vada pav and dahi vada, best ever.. Dosas are superb too :) Must visit if you are in San Francisco :)

4uscIP7YDERJG9oxEFed3w.review_text: I mentioned I went to Dosa to a friend, and he smiled. Good food but it's not authentic. I don't know if I really care that much. But yeah, the dosa with truffle oil is probably not an ancient recipe.  Our threesome ordered from the tasting menu, ordered different things and shared family-style. Everything was delicious, especially the aforementioned truffled dosa as well as the lamb curry. A couple of us ordered the wine pairing. Because the flavors in the food were so bold, the wines did not stand out or bring anything new in the pairing.  The decor of the room is gorgeous and our waitstaff was friendly and attentive.

clfjVE51HvlL99PLRrMolA.review_text: My family really wanted a good Indian meal, and were excited at the prospect of dosas. Upon arriving we realized it wasn't a traditional Indian restaurant but more of a cookie cutter establishment trying to be "fancy"...our waitress had never heard of chapati. The menu took inspiration from traditional meals and added some interesting flavors to the dosas such as truffle oil. The end result was bland, heavy, and overall disappointing.  If a traditional Indian restaurant is what you're looking for don't go here.

32H700jZvaW2P12__eAwMw.review_text: Pleasantly surprised to find this place last week. This was my first introduction to dosa, which is a type of savory Indian crepe. I ordered the spicy basil dosa, which was basically a gigantic, crispy triangle. It was pretty delicious on its own but the side sauces were key; they let you experiment throughout the meal and balance the spiciness to your liking. I also ordered the lamb meatballs, which were a bit expensive for what they were.   Luckily, we got there right before the main crowd and were able to secure half of the large communal table in the front after waiting at the bar, which was also a step up from most Indian restaurants. Another difference I noticed: very few if any Indian people actually work here. Make of that what you will, but this is definitely not your classic Indian curry joint, more like a modern interpretation of the usual cuisine.   Really cool decor and ambience. I'd go back for sure.

MJ1cw7dlcJ5Cx8bXU-C0ag.review_text: The most unique Indian food ever! Great to introduce to your friends who think Indian food is just curry and nan. Spicy Basil is my favorite and paper dosa is kind of fun too! Totally recommend to bring your significant others for anniversary and even parents for family dinner.

qJ2-3AEMEbQxpwg3wjY_Sg.review_text: Dosa has a great atmosphere and is conveniently right by Kabuki, but with the terribly long wait, it need not be your go to destination.  While the vegetable curry was good, everything else was mediocre.  I'd pass and go elsewhere.

fhOpYAOHgY-mH6E4vA654Q.review_text: Every time I m in SF I come to this place, recently I had dinner w my girls and the food was fantastic as always my favorite is the spicy basil dosa  and chiliy uttapam. I love the specialty drinks but beware they make it good! The only thing I don't like are the desserts, I think they need to do better.

jFy31THbIK45H8TN-HCL4A.review_text: Best Indian I've had.  Tried the Vada Pav (really awesome and interesting), duck vindaloo (delicious and super spicy), and the mixed chile uttapam (super spicy).  We also had a few cocktails a piece that were awesome (mango is the new black, ginger ante).  Can't wait to go back to try more of the menu.

5NKviPtd7SfXDy1Mdnr_FQ.review_text: Great southern indian food!  Lots of vegan/vegetarian options in the heart of the mission.

_E3yaczgef7enusOIf7Jug.review_text: Let me preface this by saying that I am not that well versed on Indian food.  All I know was that I had a tastebud overload of deliciousness.  I came here with a friend, and we ordered 3 dishes off the menu.  We way over-ordered, and I apologize for all of the food that had to be wasted.  :( [[ Mango Prawns ]] came with 6 giant prawns and 3 mango chunks.  Sweet and mildly tangy, it was perfect with a side of coconut rice which comes with shredded coconut - and wow, when I realized that, I hit a food high. [[ South Indian Moons ]] - a selection of five different uttapams.  One was more bland than the rest (it was mostly flavored with diced tomatoes).  One was a little more spicy with some peppers of the green variety.  Overall good, but I became so full that it was tiresome to eat this and appreciate the differences between them. picture of the first 2 dishes: sphotos-b.xx.fbcdn.net/h… [[ Dosa with Paper Masala ]] - soft/mashed potatoes, sambar, chutneys.  Delicious!  (On the 7x7 Big Eat list).  This is so huge!  Just look at it: sphotos-a.xx.fbcdn.net/h… The cocktails were delicious as well, and had a nice Indian flavor kick to them! [[ Peony ]] gin with hibiscus masal nectar and coconut milk [[ Bengali Gimlet ]] had curried nectar - and was mildly spicy Amongst the two of us, our total came to ~$70 before tip.  The restaurant also offers a Seasonal Tasting menu for $35 per person, which comes with 3 courses.  Maybe the courses are smaller than the regular courses, but I do not understand how anyone would normally eat that much food.  We really should have stuck with 2 dishes between the two of us. AMBIANCE:  Spacious and big.  (This used to be a Bank of America.)  Classy. Dimly-lit.  Romantic.

RXHuqqw59JFsk1MKqiwrWQ.review_text: Dosa on Valencia and Dosa on Fillmore are like the Hemsworth brothers. Both are great, yet there are people who strongly like one over the other. For me, it really depends (not talking about the Hemsworth brothers, talking about Dosa now ;). It depends on how I'm feeing and how much I'm willing to spend that night. I have reviewed Valencia separately but I thought it would be helpful  to do a quick comparison. I found Fillmore to be a little expensive than its counterpart, it is also upscale and bigger and has a more trendy vibe to it. Perfect for a group to hang out by the bar and enjoy some delicious cocktails before grabbing dinner. The drinks here are very good. I would go to Valencia on a night when I just truly want to hog, get in and get out quickly, probably also when I'm not dressed too well: p  I have had a few dishes at both the locations and honestly they were pretty consistent in taste and quality. Fillmore has things on the menu that Valencia does not and vice versa. Reservations are recommended at both since it can get very busy especially for dinner and over the weekends. Dosa on Fillmore - I made reservations for four for a weekend and when we went here, of course, it was packed! We arrived about half an hour earlier than our reservations and had to wait at the bar since they did not have anything available sooner, which we pretty much knew. We grabbed a few cocktails and were seated upstairs.  Our server was very nice and accommodating. Our order came at a lightning speed, I think they brought our appetizers almost immediately! We must have ordered about seven people's worth of food among the four of us and we managed to finish every morsel of it! I am very surprised at how great the food is here. There are very few places who nail both South and North Indian dishes and Dosa does a pretty good job at both types of cuisines. Masala/Plain dosa and vada paav are must try's!

zPvo9z9yDT1Ls9z31a6uzg.review_text: The food is consistently excellent. They change their menu seasonally and are very creative with their dishes. I recently discovered they're open for brunch on the weekend. The Fillmore location is so much larger and more comfortable than the Valencia Street location. I only wish they would open an East Bay restaurant.

C1OU2oUR-yCNsAhd3corlw.review_text: How can I have lived 3 blocks away from here AND NEVER KNEW ABOUT IT?  Went here for the first time just recently with the boy and his friends. Very classy interior, albiet a bit on the dark side.   We decided to share an order of Grilled Calamari (spicy!), regular Dosa, Paper Dosa, and I think it was the Masala Prawns-- they were all fabulous, but I really liked the Paper Dosa. The spiced potatoes that came with the dosas were AMAZING.   Waitstaff was really helpful and friendly.

ORjobLNM_vkRgL1dtbd8VA.review_text: One of the best South Indian meals I have had to date - and I am South Indian. The food is authentic but with a twist to make it interesting. The flavors are the right balance of heat, spice and sour. We ordered the kale pakoras, rasam, mung dal dosa, garlic and chili dosa and all were excellent. I had a cocktail (can't remember the name but it had tequila, cucumber and citrus) which was good too. We ordered the white chocolate turmeric pot de creme for dessert and I said I was only going to try a taste because I was full and I ended up eating every last bite. We enjoyed excellent service - granted it was Friday lunchtime so maybe not as busy but there were plenty of customers. All in all a great experience and I plan on a return visit.

iMBhHKt24xi-v2OXEp7Bkg.review_text: Had an absolutely fantastic meal at Dosa. We're used to eating at hole in the wall Indian restaurants with Bollywood videos playing - Dosa was so gorgeous and posh, it looked more like a club.   Came here after a show, about an hour before they were closing, so we were nervous about the food lacking quality. We were incredibly wrong.  Our waiter was awesome, he explained his favorite menu items, the rice or dosa that paired well, as well as wine that would compliment. We ordered the north & south samosas, duck vindaloo, and the roasted chile and garlic dosa. We were warned both were extremely spicy, and they weren't wrong. I can handle heat extremely well but that didn't stop me from drinking half a dozen glasses of water (which they refilled diligently, thanks guys!). Even the tomato chutney packed a little punch.   All entirely worth it, the food was of extremely high quality. The duck was tender, the dosa was perfect crispy, and they brought us about 6 different chutneys for everything. The tomato chutney and cilantro chutney were delicious.  Definitely will be back, would love to try the desserts with wine pairings.  Also yay for complimentary chips!

kKuJF6GFyZgp_E2rx8LNgQ.review_text: We went to Dosa for Valentine's Day and I have to say this is one of my new favorite Indian restaurants in the Bay Area. We had the fixed four course menu, which was an excellent deal.  Our courses: seafood soup and bhel puri (first course), lamb dosa and sweet potato dosa (2), kerala fish moilee and chicken (third course), apple tart and lava cake (fourth course).  I loved the seafood soup, it was fabulous, so much so I've asked my mother-in-law to recreate it.  My wife enjoyed her bhel puri, but as her family is from Bombay, she thought it could have used more sauces. The dosas were sada dosas with a stuffing, mine was lamb, hers was sweet potato.  The lamb was delicious, my wife thought the sweet potato was tasty and unusual. The third course was the real winner, the fish was delicious and her chicken was superbly spicy (even for her).  We also ordered a bature to go with it (delicious, on the thicker side, but delicious).  The fourth course desserts were tasty but not authentic.  My wife was sad they didn't have an interesting kulfi on the menu.  All in all, I think Dosa was delicious, the drinks we had were refreshing and the atmosphere is impressive.  The only disappointing thing to us outside of the food was that we were seated next to the server station, which meant the clanging of dishes sometimes meant it was impossible to hear each other speak.  But, it was a really enjoyable experience.  Will go again.

Kz6cC9zFLh-xeWbT_uss3Q.review_text: The food was very spicy which if you're not prepared for can take you by surprise. Order up their delicious mango drink or something with yogurt. If it's your first time tell the waiter and they'll help you order because it can get really confusing. The menu seems to change really frequently but it was super tasty.

HXOfPXPMvdXNpQ_l0RRjKw.review_text: I digs me some Indian food, so when the group plan was to go to Dosa I had no objections. While I've had many a plate of vindaloo'd and masaala'd items, I'd never partaken of a dosa so I knew that's what would be going in my belly.  Part thin, crispy pancake and part stuffed crêpe, I'm glad I went with the namesake dish. Wanna know the truth? I actually looked around the table and had order envy of the non-dosa menu items that were ordered. There was a pepper meat dish that I got to try and it was mighty fine, and the duck vindaloo looked something delectable.  Double love (amor por dos-a?) for the restaurant's ambiance. Nothing wildly fancy, but too often I find myself in divey Indian places so it was nice to get a good sit down meal with Indian faves.

NzRgdftH9ny_nMj-4TmVag.review_text: I'm no expert on Indian food to be honest but this was really good.  The dosas were amazing as well as the lamb kofta. Chicken was also great, really tender and tasty.   Love the fact that you can sit at a round table with your friends and share the small platters.   Totally recommend this place for everyone who wants to try out Indian food. Friendly and patient personnel that have great tips especially if it comes to spices. I'll definitely check out this place soon again.

qQN5WDFijhsD--Z3NpEJWQ.review_text: Truly amazing - thank you Yelp for helping me find this place  Great atmosphere - exquisite food - awesome service.  We tried their rava & moog dosas and vada pav.  Both were excellent. I am definitely heading back for more soon.

wEOvyzYqy37DNlQc0gJN3Q.review_text: I came here last Friday for their Dine About Town menu. Made reservations, showed up on time, made to wait for 30 minutes while plenty of others that came after were sat first.   No big deal, it's Friday night, I'm sure they had earlier reservations or something.  Anyway, onto the food. Phenomenal.  I was expecting expensive "organic" butter chicken but I was pleasantly surprised.  I got the seafood soup for a starter. A heaping helping of the soup, that, while very sour and off putting at first, really grows on you. I slurped up every drop. The scallop, expertly cooked, the fish? Subtle and flakey.   Onto the Dosa. I had no idea it was named after a type of food, cool.  Tasted like a crepe with potato filling, nothing crazy, but the dipping sauces they gave were great. I really enjoyed the minty one.  Finally the mains. The lamb course was delicious, but my girlfriend's vegetarian one was even better.  Sorry I don't recall the names.  The curry was flavorful without being too spicy. Complex and robust. Too bad we were so stuffed to really enjoy it.  I'll be back for sure.

xfrRKuHXbvz7J_dShdsTHw.review_text: Thank you Dosa on Fillmore for having an amazing selection of vegetarian-friendly dinner and brunch options; for consistently adding new menu items (appetizer salads and dessert mostly); for employing happy people; for making my go-to drink (the Divya cocktail) perfect every time; for staying open late when every other restaurant in the area has been long closed; and for always keeping my taste buds satisfied.    Keep up the excellent work, and I will keep coming back.  Bring back the banana creme pie, and I will never leave :-)

7WwUINIgTxi9c7whC8mbnA.review_text: One of my favorite restaurants in the city. The panear and peas dosa with a dipping stew, incredible! The drinks are unique very tasty. Also, give the Channa Bhatura a shot, incredible and super fun.

l91pXxTZGS5CNWjNBsyg7g.review_text: We walked in 5 minutes after their afternoon closing time, the super nice Manager and hostess let us grab a table and order, they were honest about setting the expectation we had to order quickly since the kitchen was closing, very fair, I value straightforwardness.  We ordered a number a things, I cannot remember a single dish name, but every single of the 6-8 items we ordered were AMAZING. This was my first time trying southern Indian food, which apparently is a deviation from the usual dishes.   Nevertheless...  Food: is fantastic, the best Indian i have ever had. Their 'breads' (chips and the like) were to die for. Service: the staff was super nice and attentive, they all seemed happy which makes a tremendous difference. Presentation: very nice, orderly and clean. Quantity: proportional with price, this is not a cheap Indian buffet but it will get your stomach what it needs to survive while pleasing your palate. Price: its expensive for Dinner, but very moderate-average for lunch.   Ambiance/Decor: modern, very nice and clean.  I am SO coming back!

0G-QF457q_0Z_jKqh6xWiA.review_text: South Indian food is pretty much the only kind of Indian food I can tolerate at times. I had Indian food for both lunch and dinner (not by choice) the night before I tried Dosa on Fillmore, on this night I found myself attacking my idlli with glee (not ghee). It's just such a different experience from typical Punjabi food and nowhere nearly as oppressive with rich sauces and butter. Most dishes start out at a moderately high (for American taste buds) spice level that can only be increased so that it reaches "gun powder" status (ie, perfect for *my* American taste buds). Not spicy enough (you cray cray?), they'll gladly provide you with ways to get your mouth on fire, ie coconut chutneys (different from the kind you're used to).  Dosai is typically vegetarian (vegan in traditional places), but our server informed us that protein-heavy dishes could be found in the small plates. In addition to the idlli, I ordered the veggie sliders, which were tasty but I removed the rather pedestrian bread from the patty (?- too loose to call it that), which didn't leave me with much. I also wasn't in love with the rasam (soup) which I'm used to being much, much spicier. I do recommend the idlli with sambal. I unfortunately didn't get to try a dosa.  What I do appreciate about DOF is that it's aesthetically nothing like my regular dosa haunt on Long Island, which has a dreary interior that I will gladly suffer because I just love the food so much. DOF has a sumptuous ambiance that lends itself well to both large groups and more intimate dinners as well.   *Do* take advantage that this isn't the most authentic Indian restaurant and order a craft cocktail. I sampled enough of them to be able to say they are good at these. What? I'm all about taking advantage of situations.  Although I typically avoid desserts because I can't enjoy it on a full stomach, I tasted a variety of what they have to offer and I'm afraid I can't recommend any of them (especially the coconut custard). No big deal. I doubt I've ever had an Indian dessert that I liked.

l3S1srqK1CvjB_S4r-ZBeg.review_text: You had me at habaneros.  Yummm yummmm.   On a sunny summer morning in June, 2011. A bunch of girls walked in to this beauty. We all cheered, ate ,marveled over our food ( I was the ONLY non Indian person in the group) and flew back home happily after.  Yum! Dosa is pretty magical. It's not what you expect from an Indian restaurant yet it has everything you would expect. I love their dosas (obvi), chaats and even curry dishes. The service is always fantastic. Spice level- true to the cuisine. As a spice fiend, I hate Americanized spice levels.   Dosas- pretty damn magical! All perfectly cooked, fluffed, flaky and tasty. We had Masala dosas,  Regular plain dosas  Truffle dosas!   Pani puri - these little things are my favorite to eat. You get to break the little balls of puff pastry, putt condiments and spice water in. And eat it.  I get to play with my food before eating it? Double score. So yummm Chenai chicken- tasty tasty! Oh and that one time last summer ( June,2013) my sassy waiter brought me exactly what I wanted. Extra spicy mind blowing Dosa! So spicy, it was laced with habaneros. It was so spicy, nobody at the table except me could eat it!   Respect you fellow blazer wearing person. Respect for blowing my mind. ( He was fierce in his velvet blue blazer- I had my non velvet blue blazer on. Of course we got along. ( He was a restaurant manager perhaps?) My fellow brunch people had to cool down with lassi and bloody mary to get that spice out.  Teehe. It was pretty mind blowing though. So hot! My friends always say I know way too many Indians. I do. And I love their food too.   Having tried a few too many restaurants and home cooked dinners/feasts , I can easily say Dosa kick ass. It was right up there with being my favorite indian restaurant. There are many in the bay area but I have always returned here on my visits. Not planning to stop that anytime soon.

KGacP4DKdaEtjUG5QDzvUQ.review_text: I eat Indian about 3-4 times per week (mostly made at home). When I first visited Dosa I was suspicious because most of the diners were white folks.  And I was shocked by the sticker price; it's certainly the priciest Indian restaurant I've eaten at.  It certainly doesn't have the atmosphere of your typical Indian restaurant, but in this case I'd say that's working in Dosa's favor.  But I have to give it 5 stars, as it's also one of the best restaurants I've enjoyed.  Between my wife and I, I've tried about half of the menu so far.  Everything has been good.  It's all so flavorful and just tastes so bright and fresh, I'm not even sure how to describe it.  Most of the dishes are prepared in an authentic way, though a handful of them show some creativity by the chef(s) that could be called Indian-fusion.  Almost every time we pass through the city my wife wants to stop there to eat (she's from Hyderabad).  And if it weren't so pricey, we probably would.

Re1fJH9aICIMieZoANFJaQ.review_text: Had the spicy basil dosa and it was fantastic!  The chutney sampler with papad was also nice. The atmosphere is very modern and the bar tender was very friendly. Wish we had one of these on the east coast!

htR5samHwfbl8Jn2hCjrrQ.review_text: So delicious. We couldn't stop ordering stuff and all of it was amazing.

7Q_eNRLuRhZk6HDAYmCLsg.review_text: Great drinks. I mean they're serious about their drinks and have every right to brag about em. I mean the Peony alone is worth a first born. The bartenders are cute, knowledgeable, nice, but not too chatty--perfect.  Then, the food. Everything we've ordered has been scrumptious. I mean really, this place is down. The only reason I can't do 5 stars is it's crowded, expensive, and has kinda strange hours. Happy hour could be a lot more creative, but I am hoooooked.

GFqYO2AJe6YKh-taEnY1Cg.review_text: Always a great place to go..

P7zeUALL2nMDc4Ll4ZiP6g.review_text: Great food. Love the cilantro fish and prawn masala. Ordered the paneer peas dosa and chennai chicken  which was good too.(not great). Overall a great experience. Has to be one of the best restaurants in the bay.

Lra95s4svKD2b8zPrFT3sg.review_text: The ambience is great for a date or family get togethers. We had to wait 10mins on a Saturday evening even though we had a reservation.  We ordered these: 1. Vada pav - excellent, must haves, especially tastes awesome with the gunpowder chutney. 2. Kaju Paneer Masala - the paneer was tasty  but the paratha was basically the 'Kawan Paratha'  (anybody who shops at Indian grocery stores would know) which disappointed us a bit since it wasn't 'home made'. 3. Paper Masala Dosa - the dosa and masala were regular, nothing out of the ordinary (being an Indian and having eaten dosas growing up).

jV2b1Q7tnhnaIcoPPLE3Xw.review_text: I refused to pay so much for a meal, but I have to say it was worth every penny!!

WJ4pGSUjvIa4sDyTA_fSyQ.review_text: Really quite okay for the prices. Do like the drinks there though.

jO2ExV9YIfTAyQLcUjkleA.review_text: I just finished my leftover Dosa and am currently regretting not having ordered more food for leftovers while I was at the restaurant last night. I had the spicy basil dosa which is apparently the most popular dosa on the menu and rightly so because it tastes fantastic! I was not a fan of their sambhar (seemed to have too much curry powder) but their coconut and tomato chutneys went along really well with the dosa. My hubby got the Uttapam sampler which was also pretty good except for the mushroom uttapam.. the mushrooms were too chunky and they did not go well with the rest of the uttapam. We also had --   the Mung salad (which was decent) the squash pakoras (they were alright) the dahi vada (vada was on the dry side even though it was submerged in liquid yogurt and chutneys.. not quite like the fresh home made vadas!)  I would definitely go back here, but mainly for the uttapams, dosas and sweet lassi.

FSH3nUYSmSGq2Z2t4iofSA.review_text: Stick to dosas which are awesome btw. Idli and other starters were not that great at all. Dosas were amazing. Chili, moong and rava dosa were great. I would totally come again. Dinner has more options such as North Indian dishes as well.

N8wsEh3_NTUwm4kNp1pLHA.review_text: Environment: Fun and hip.  Drinks: Delicious...expensive but delicious. Food: SO SPICY. Honestly, I don't have a high spice tolerance but my boyfriend does and even he had to stop eating his food. We honestly didn't even want to pack it to bring it home because it was too spicy. Also, and this is my lack of cultural awareness, I didn't realize that South Indian food does not have naan. :( Sad day. Service: Great. Super friendly. But it always kind of sucks when the waiter's switch in the middle of the dinner and you get the feeling that they are telling you to pay now so you can tip them. #awkward

Qumkkx8MXTkBBxkYNxoozw.review_text: I like the smaller Dosa on Valencia.  Last time I went to Dosa Fillmore before a film at Kabuki (~6 months ago), it felt like too much of a cattle call for my liking.  The food is tasty, but over-priced for what it is, in my opinion.  Easy to find lots of better down-scale (or divey) places around SF.

OO7v2zxAQbkj432uve08ow.review_text: I'm not really sure how to grade this restaurant since I loved the layout but the food seemed too spicey for my taste.  I did like the mint chutney and their dosa's are pretty good but once again left me on fire afterward.

bDuvA0GR04RrMawj2kkD6g.review_text: had an amazing meal the other night. shared a bunch of small plates and bites.  first time here. seasonal dosa was amazing! service was excellent. food full of flavor and not so hot that you can't enjoy all the wonderful flavors. place packs up, we were there on a Thursday night full by 8pm. nice wine options. will for sure be back!

h53MQqQ16regkL2aEl-3WQ.review_text: Unfortunately, dinner at Dosa was a big let down for me.  We had the coconut seafood soup, which was the best part of meal, the chennai chicken, truffle masala dosa, green mango & paneer dosa, prawns masala, and Hyderbaldi lamb.  The saltiness overpowered any spices used in the curry and sauces to the point where I was downing more water than usual. Service was impersonal and aloof. I left the restaurant disappointed and very dehydrated.

qUTFXbMFAo9Lasfe1DEhnw.review_text: Tuesday night was not my first meal at Dosa on Fillmore. It was my go to place before a movie at the Sundance Kabuki. This time I made the mistake of making a reservation through Open Table. After a polite greeting at the desk the hosts quickly found my reservation, and whisked me and my date up to the stuffy, and dimly lit mezzanine level with its own bar. It didn't even feel like the same restaurant. It was so dimly lit I could not read the menu. When I asked for an extra candle or a flashlight for more light, the waitress sneered "use your cell phone flashlight app like the other customers". The advice would have been fine if I had a flashlight app or a cell phone.   I would still recommend the food and the drink but only on on the lower level--even sitting at the downstairs bar-- but the very unpleasant and dark mezzanine is where they punish customers who bother to make reservation and punish their workers--forced to descend and climb a steep staircase for every trip to the kitchen. Never eat in a place where its so dark you can't read the menu or see the food.

UVs_7nPjqK_W_ap96IClpA.review_text: Enjoyed a delectable lunch with awesome company, courtesy of my boyfriend =D  Dosa has been on my bookmarks for awhile now, and we finally got our butts over here to try it out. After checking the menu out online I figured it would be better to go for lunch (to spare our wallets a bit), and we didn't have to fight the crowds to get a table so it was win-win.   We arrived when they opened at 11:30 and were seated immediately. The interior is very large and floridly decorated, but it's tasteful and interesting (definitely eye catching). The service is impeccable; our waiter was very nice, attentive and even answered my random questions when it came to identifying items of my thali.   The BF ordered the Chennai Chicken as an appetizer, then the Prawn Frankie for his meal, while I ordered the vegetarian thali. First off: ORDER THE CHENNAI CHICKEN. This was the most perfectly cooked, tender chicken I have ever consumed, and it was coated in a combination of spices that enveloped your mouth in such a satisfying way. As if it couldn't get any better, they add a side of cucumber yogurt that you can dip your chicken it, which calms the spices and makes it even better!! That sauce was just as yummy as the chicken, and both my BF and I resorted to using a spoon to scrape the last remnants out of the cup ;)  The prawn Frankie looks like a wrap but it's filled with delicious shrimp and it's quite filling. As for my thali, when I received it I freaked out a bit because it was so gigantic! There were at least 10 little individual cups on this tray bigger than my head, and in the center were rice, and two kinds of bread. I couldn't name everything I had if I tried but I remember there was saffron rice, basmati rice, cucumber yogurt, veggies, a pickled vegetable of some sort, lentils, a spicy soup, a rice puff with ghee (tasted cheesy to me), and veggie curry among other things. There was so much variety but I was able to taste so many things for a reasonable price. LEGIT.  Overall this was a great dining experience. I would definitely come back, although the prices for dinner are a bit steep... then again they have a lot more entree options on the dinner menu so I bet it's worth it! Gotta come back and try the chai tea as well =)

8Z9ugoA4MGwiJVh-CB8bhQ.review_text: My hubs and i had enjoyed a great dinner here at Dosa. Get here early as it tends to get crowded pretty quickly. When we were seated the restaurant was only half filled. By the time our orders arrived, the place was PACKED.  We had an order of a Dosa, a curry dish and a side of coconut rice. It was a lot of food for two but we somehow managed to scarf down the whole thing.  The dosa was this crepe like pancake with potatoes under which we were advised to smash down to flatten out the potatoes underneath to dip into these dipping sauces. I've been to several authentic Indian restaurants and to be honest I've never had a dosa before so it was quite nice being able to experience something new. I do want to mention while this dish was tasty it was HEAVY on the potatoes. But portion control is key so i was glad the hubs was with me to help attack this dish.   A great spot with and highly recommended to vegetarians like myself!

aaXANaiPk9xzMEqo3t5l_g.review_text: Alright Dosa is awesome. The food is great, albeit a bit on the spicy side, flavors are authentic, a good break from the usual "chicken tika masala" Indian food most of us are so used to!  Ignore my 3* rating from their first few weeks. Give it a shot!

iGYZktrrMZp-0HFlu03VsA.review_text: Walked it on a Wednesday night ~8:30pm and there was a 25 min WAIT for the dining  hall - this is just how popular this place is! Lucky for me - I was in a rush so chose the bar seat anyway. No wait (but bar was full too).   Chennai chicken blew me away - so tender and juicy. The dosa was amazing too - the texture was brilliant and so was the flavor. I found the sambar a bit too salty, hence knocking off one star from the review.   Must-try if you are in SF!

QX1UciS9sSwgYoanAPyUFA.review_text: Is this place overpriced, yes; there's no debate there. But that's the ONLY con. So if you can get past the price, stay tuned, because everything else is so damn good.   Ambience? Great. Two stories, great service, romantic lighting at night, bright during the day/for brunch.   Cocktails? Truly some of the best in the city, if you're looking for interesting flavors and new combinations. The Peony w/ coconut milk, gin, and fresh chilies is my go-to, and you can't really get anything similar elsewhere. Same goes for many of the other cocktails.   Beer/Wine? List is huge, and includes hard cider and multiple sparkling wines by the glass.   Food? Fantastic california-indian food, that's fresh, interesting, and well presented. You can get your basic masala and rice, or get adventurous and pick something you've never had before; same goes for dosa. They also do a very relaxed brunch on the weekends, that has great dosa filled with scrambled eggs and indian spiced potatoes on the side.   If you're a first-timer or a little worried about heat, I'd get the panner & pea dosa; even kids could have that. But if you want to branch out, do the tasting menu; it's totally worth it. The salad they had during the spring with fried goat-cheese balls, watermelon radishes, and curry vinaigrette was REALLY GOOD. The biryani are also great, as are any of the dosas. The uttapams are small, compared to everything else, but are a nice snack or small plate.   If you're visiting SF, want a great night out, or want to take an adventure with food, this is totally the place. Use OpenTable to book a reservation online, as it's a busy place and the wait can be 45+ mins on a Fri or Sat night, without a reservation.

4XIjdvV3bz-e_NYzJRJLHg.review_text: This is our favorite place to take out of town guests. I love this place. Must try the paper dosa with all the great chutneys. There is also an amazing chicken dish, the chennani chicken which is a little like spicy fried chicken. We've had most of everything else as I love to try new things, and everything was worth it. Be sure to make a reservation.

08mOpJRCpZe3D8UHszP4FA.review_text: I've tried out Dosa in the Mission so I knew kinda what I was getting into when I went into the Indian restaurant.
