I only ended up eating here because the Ramen Festival was horrible and this place wasn't too busy when I went yet and I was able to get a seat at the bar to eat my lunch.  I picked Mini Masala Dosa w/ side of Soup $14.  I got some FREE papadam chips - I liked them fine.  Soup was a served hot & was spicy - I liked it.  Mini masala dosa was fine too.  They have that SF Employee Mandatory Healthcare fee.  Before tip my bill was $15.83.  Charged it.

YgzX0h_Nfrdmk_PGXhdNNg.review_text: Fabulous Anniversary dinner at Dosa!  I love Indian food but feel like my experience of it is limited to "hole in the wall" type places or general greasy take out.  Ms husband booked this reservation based on rave reviews from his Associates.  What a treat to go somewhere that felt hip and upscale but SO authentic.  I loved trying all the dishes that were new to me and not just my usual Chicken Tikka Masala or Saag Paneer (not even on the menu!).    We each got the tasting menu because we felt like we wanted to taste lots of different things.  It was ALOT of food and we didn't come close to eating at all.  So I would only recommend that choice if you really want a taste of everything.  Hard to point out highlights because we loved everything we tried.  We loved hot hott all the food is, but if you happen to not love spicy food--speak up!  100% going back my next time in SF!

i_Rti8t2smo-UI6aqn68Pg.review_text: This place is amazing!  I had some scallops for an appetizer and they practically melted in my mouth. So delicious! The decor is also awesome! Definitely an impressive place. The service was great too with multiple servers pitching in to make our dinner flow smoothly.  Highly recommended as one of the best restaurants on the Fillmore!

VarPmrQsBeeLZ9suKpxYug.review_text: I haven't like Indian food in a very long time. The wifey wanted to go here and was making me feel bad about not taking her. So we went and damn she was right! This placed is tops in my book. All of the dosas should be tried. The dipping sauces are so good I started spooning them down my throat. Dosa made me a happy man. The wait staff was great and explained the menu thoroughly.   Dosa didn't just prove to me that I was wrong about not giving them a chance earlier, dosa also proved I married the right girl.

Y9ewgHSTmxVYPMb4QP9PHg.review_text: The dosa we had was burnt and the service was very slow. We had to wait to one hour due to a mistake the kitchen made to receive our food. Unfortunately the food (uttapam & dosa) were mediocre at best. Based on our experience, I can't really recommend this place to any fellow southern Indian food fans.

BXAZB-k-NDKcFRPleYF7GA.review_text: Great ambiance really nice place.  Our server David was very good and attentive.   We started with the fan favorite chennai chicken.  It was very flavorful.    We then moved to the thali with lamb and the masala dosa.  The thali was an explosion of tastes wonderful flavorful yet not overwhelming.   The dosa was also very nice.   There are many Indian people that come by but the food is not a traditional Indian. The delivery method is not as a typical Indian food rather is more westernized.  Which means you will be treated to great quality with great service.

qkreXL6AorI19QA3f2wvlQ.review_text: SF Restaurant Week, part 4: Discovery Menu at Dosa on Fillmore  At first, I wasn't interested in even looking at the discovery menus for Restaurant Week.  I knew I wanted to go to at least 4 restaurants this time, and the $85 put me off.  Well, I looked at the menu at Dosa on Fillmore.  My roommate and I looked at each other and then it became the "I'll go if you go" situation.  So we went!  We started with a sparkling wine to go with our appetizer.  I ordered the petrale sole porichadu.  The sole was fried to perfection and went well with the winter chutney, which I think was made from squash.  The side salad had hints of coconut and other spices.  It was a great way to start the dinner.  For the second course, I ordered the khageena dosa, which had scrambled eggs, ginger, ghee, and cilantro.  The dosa came with coconut chutney, tomato chutney, and lentil soup.  I really liked the lentil soup.  It was fragrant and spicy, and went well with the sweetness of the carrots and red bell peppers.  I wasn't a fan of the tomato chutney.  I preferred the coconut chutney with this dosa.  Which, by the way, was delicious.  Despite all the ingredients, like ginger and cilantro, it didn't overwhelm the flavor of the egg.  It was overall a balanced dish.  The wine that was paired with this was a chardonnay that was very fruit-driven and not buttery.  My roommate's white wine that went with her Winter Uttapam had no flavor.  I thought she was crazy at first, but I tried it.  And it really did have no flavor.  It was the weirdest tasting wine I've ever had.  I got the paneer and almond kofta for the third course.  The dish consisted of two veggie meatballs made up of parsnip, butternut squash, and potato buried in a curry sauce with coconut rice on the side.  The meatballs were drowning in the curry sauce.  I think it would've been better if it was just poured on top.  It seemed like a lot was wasted when I was finished.  The coconut rice was aromatic and softened the spiciness of the curry.  A red wine was paired with this dish.  And for dessert, I ordered the banana almond date cake, that was paired with a sherry dessert wine.  It was okay.  The cake itself didn't have a lot of flavor.  It relied on the banana and the spiced cashews for it.  But I think it was that way because it was paired with the sherry, which was very sweet and strong.  I actually preferred the kumquat fruit tart that my friend ordered.  Oh, and the waiter was very nice on giving us extra papadums.  They were delicious!!  Would I go back and pay full price?  Yes, but only for special occasions for dinner, or lunch.  The décor merits a fancier dress code, and the dinner prices reflect that.  There's a casual South Indian restaurant I go to in the Mission where you get more bang for your buck. But Dosa is definitely worth trying if you need to impress anyone.

6-AA014-IT2FJjcEqJBZYg.review_text: 16-September, Sunday: I imagine that in my former life as a lady of the manor in my estranged green-card marriage, my boudoir must have been outfitted in the same fashion because this place felt oddly familiar and cozy even though it was new territory for me.  I was completely taken by surprise by Dosa on Fillmore, it is a stark contrast from its more casual Valencia location. The 'white table cloth' atmosphere here boasts high vaulted ceilings, a lower level of seating upon entry, an upper level that is more intimate, along with an option to sit along the fully stocked bar.   I enjoyed a subtly tart mango prawns that had just a subtle tinge of spice to it, although I do not proactively crave curried things I will admit that this was quite the exception in my book.  Especially when served with aromatic lemon basmati rice.

s81VRLqYFEpXPIQtGx2mnw.review_text: I love dosas!  Many are familiar with Indian food, including naan, curries, tikkas, etc.  However, people are not as familiar with Southern Indian fare such as dosas.  A dosa is a thin crispy crepe-like dish with curried potatoes in it... they are fantastic!  And while these are usually best found at hole-in-the-wall Indian restaurants, Dosa is an exception to the rule.  This place is a great place to enjoy some delicious Southern Indian food that has a slightly more upscale ambiance.  Good food, nice atmosphere, makes for a wonderful sit down spot for some lunch or dinner with friends.  Southern Indian food is not just excellent for their dosas, but for their other dishes as well!  If you are not sure what to order, I recommend the Masala Dosa, Channa Bhatura, some Uttapam (get the Uttapam variety plate if you're not sure which you want to try!), and Dahi Vada.  These were all delicious, and some great ways to experiment with Southern Indian food!

XiMeEDyrd-rSE7vn2DenWg.review_text: Must haves: Hyderabad Chicken Biryani Mixed Mushroom & Truffle Oil Uttapam  Drinks: Peony Wry Rajah

esUa4AjxIJBP0ejVQ8-F5w.review_text: One of the best Dosas I have had in the recent past. The Sambar simply tastes great. Saravana Bhavan always had the best Sambar and I think now Dosa is giving an excellent competition. Seasonal Spring dosa was excellent. the big surprised was Bhel Puri was!! I would definitely recommend that as an appetizer.

OXZaMIH_cjw77Is0djJfzQ.review_text: Good Indian food with numerous variety of dosa....

tuFmPmxwkTAn2sPUQebHZA.review_text: This reataurant definitely deserves the rave reviews. The food is Excellent! My favorites were the chicken shanai, the kale crisps, and the lamb dosa. Our waiter was very helpful and didn't let us over order.

peuxbSQwXed-81cSqL7Ykw.review_text: Wow! A little envious of the San Franciscans for having this fantastic restaurant so close in proximity!   I love Indian food and since I've moved from Washington DC to LA its been hard to find authentic Indian food. All the places in LA are extremely casual and nothing too exciting.   Enter, the perfect opportunity to eat some great Indian while in SF! Dosa on Fillmore is Southern Indian. I had never had southern Indian before and it's different dishes than the Northern Indian but same flavors and perhaps more spicy.   We ordered a lot of food - in hindsight, way too much food! We started with the chennai chicken - a glorified and much more flavorful version of the chicken nugget. This nugget had it going on! It was organic (yes organic at an Indian restaurant!) marinated in organic yogurt with cumin and coriander and fried. But they really didn't taste fried.   For entrees we ordered the lamb chops (omg these were good), the chicken biryani and the white truffle dosa (a potato filled crepe). The lamb chops came with a mildy spiced lentil sauce that had a sweetness to it that I loved. The chicken was shredded and tender mixed into basmati rice with caramelized onions, peas and cashews and was tender and amazing! The dosa smelled of white truffles but didn't really taste like truffles much, which was a bit of a let down.    We also got the bhatura - this large puffy bread that reminded me of a donut in the best possible of ways. Yummy!   Everything was much spicier than I anticipated. I was really feeling the heat, which I loved, but I know for someone who is spice averse this would be a turn off.   I would have loved to try their desserts but I was SO full that there was no chance.   The space is big, open and modern. It was very lively on a Wednesday night at 9pm. I Will definitely come back here when I am back in SF!

StdoIOlqqbzpRqff5nEZ3A.review_text: Dosa on Fillmore is flashy, vibrant but the food is far away from an experience that the location and everything else promises. The lamb appetizer did not offer any delight and the biryani was served luke-warm. The lassi was too thick. I can go on and on.....  For $60/pp this place has to really improve a lot in my opinion. I would any day prefer Amber, Sakoon over Dosa.   Will I come again? Maybe Expect to pay: $60/pp with no alcohol

JjqDGZUwz0aCAPG8PjmFqA.review_text: The first thing that catches your eye the moment enter is the ambience and the beautiful decor. Let's just say that they spent quite a bit of money on the items they have chosen to decorate the place. I won't go into detail with the pieces because I don't want to spoil it for ya. Go see it for yourself. I love the high ceilings and the top floor seating. Although the downstairs area is nice too.    THE BAR AREA- I must say that they have the most legit bar staff in the whole Bay Area. They are quick and the orders just keep coming in and the bartenders just keep pushing them out. Sometimes we come in just for drinks before our movie next door at the Kabuki Theater and I always love sitting at bar to watch  bartenders. They sure do know how to put  on a show.   Cocktail drinks- I absolutely love love love the PEONY! So delicious. It has this hibiscus masala nectar and kaffir lime leaf top off with birds eye chili and orange blossom water and of course the alcohol choice is a gin and the coconut milk. Doesn't that just sound so enticing! They have a variety of great cocktails on their menu but the Peony is my fav.  The food- There is a tasting menu which gives you a selection of their popular dishes, three course meal. Wine pairings are also suggested. Other wise they also have full menu of all their wonderful and delicious Indian Cuisine ranging from different levels of heat. I tend to go for all the lamb dishes. Lamb meatballs is the best.   I love the staff here. Everyone is so friendly and you just know that they all mean business and I can see why Dosa has received so many different awards for their food and drinks. This place has to be my all time favorite Indian Restaurant. The Peony alone is worth coming in for a quick drink. This place is alway busy so be prepared to wait but patience is a virtue because you will not be disappointed.

6LEkFsXUwjO3_6RXYzohvg.review_text: What a wonderful surprise ! Came here on  Tuesday February 18 for dinner. The staff are super friendly and attentive.. Steve the bartender guided me through an amazing dinning experience .. Great wine list with wines from all over the world. The food runner described every dish articulately with passion making me want to order more.I had the tasting menu and the flavors were warm and comforting. Sweet potato Dosa and Lamb were particularly delicious. Can hardly wait to bring my friends .They get it and do it right! Fantastic !!!

yNeYATGhykZhyQ6bDq_TjA.review_text: Really nice decor. The food here has a more modern take on indian food.  I had the prawn frankie, it was a wrap and it was delicious.  Though I really wanted to have the other foods that the other people in my group had. Can't even remember the names of the dishes they ordered, but I know I will be back for more, I am intrigued- and that's a good thing!

hT7Gm1Kowe1sTBnQNqilGw.review_text: Really nice interior, the inside is very classily decorated, two levels of seating, dim lighting. Went for dinner in a Sunday night, did not have a  reservation, but we were quickly sat at a table upstairs. Service was great, the waiter was extremely patient with how long it took me to order as my friend explained the menu to me.  Ended up ordering the mint lemonade and the vegetable dosa, so different than when I was expecting, but so good. I liked dipping the dosa into the soup and the sauces, and the veggie potato mixture inside was delicious!!!  Would definitely come back and try more dishes.

j0gY7NSFJi2Rym82BYWbVQ.review_text: Amazing food. And most importantly the drinks were fab. Couldn't get enough of the cocktails server here.

UmnbpTGOJ7Jo1I6yx2ShyQ.review_text: Great food, excellent drinks. If you are looking for spicy, amazing Indian food then you are going to the right place.

JN44pEvNhBzfVKmiAFYbzg.review_text: third visit - started off rocky, couldn't be seated until 15 minutes after rez time, then literally didn't have a server for another 15 minutes, but all was good after this - server was very friendly and extremely knowledgeable - food was attractive and, more importantly, excellent -the huge puffy bhatura was fun for all - we went "family style" and ordered several appetizers and entrees for the table - the halibut, prawn masala, tamil lamb, etc were all wonderful - we even tried the mixed chile uttapam for grins, but it will destroy your tastebuds and, combined with wine, will light you up, so eat that last! - great selection of wines to complement spicy and flavorful food

ew3YIsnR2wSaRtKNrHHcpA.review_text: A very Dosa-pointing experience!  A group of eight of us went on a Sunday for brunch and while the service was good,  but there wasn't a single thing on the menu that wowed any of us.  I've been to the Valencia location a couple of times (now several years ago) and I had good memories of the place which does not translate to Dosa on Fillmore.  First of all, we have a four year old and we told them this from the get-go an asked whether or not we should look elsewhere because we didn't want to inconvenience anyone by bringing a toddler.  They said 'come on in' - Dosa is a kid-friendly place.  That  might be true in terms of service but there is not a single thing on that menu that a kid can eat because of the ridiculous amount of spice in everything.  They brought us some $10 version of a grilled cheese sandwich and the kid hated it.  I didn't like it either.  They brought us a bowl of coconut rice that was super spicy. And then they made a mistake and brought us popadoms with pepper in them.  So, the kid was not happy.  Now, onto the adults.  We all ordered different stuff from tasting plates to Dosas to udapams and the consensus all around is that all you could taste from one plate to the next is spice , spice, spice.  There's  no reprive from the amount of heat from one dish to another so pretty soon everything tastes exactly the same.  Maybe this is how people eat in India - I got the schpeel from our waiter - but you've got to tone it down, Dosa.  We don't eat Chinese food in America the same as in China because Americans don't like that kind of food.  You could say the same about a lot of ethnic cuisine.  You have to make the food work for the palates of the people you are catering to.  And none of the eight SF-foodie gringos at our table liked what you had to offer or your prices.  $15 for a pancake and a smattering of cheap ingredients.  Give me a break!!!  It was a disappointing few hundred bucks that we spent and I'll stick with my Indian favorite - Mehfil - the next time we decide to go Indian as they pack huge flavor into their stuff without overpowering the spice factor.  I recommend you do the same!  And don't ever bring a kid there.  Big mistake!

Qd1KGikCmSWlEafDJkLLVQ.review_text: One of the best ambiences for an Indian restaurant. Food was decent but the dessert was awesome. Must try the coconut custard cake.

b3-r05rOXxg_E1AVyyuTzQ.review_text: I think this place ought to hang a sign on the front stating "stupid white people please come in and enjoy" because that's about all that will really find this place to be the bomb. The owner is from East India not South. The food is totally different in the two regions. There are only a couple of South Indian cooks. Look in the kitchen they are the dark skinned ones. You will only see maybe 2. All the other cooks were your typical Mexican or Chinese looking. Most of the patrons were white. White people in an Indian restaurant is not a good sign. Indians go to really good Indian restaurants, Indians know how to cook and are not going to pay to eat lousy food. Especially $11.00 for a dosa.  In short I think the Mumbai/Bombay owner needs to thank all you stupid whities for making him so bloody rich.

hTPpjgbfMJs_drlTqTdluA.review_text: In my opinion the highest quality Indian food in SF.  Ambiance is great, food is always high quality, great service.    Great for sharing plates.  Also a great date spot, but probably want to call ahead and make a reservation as it very popular.    My favorites: Veggie sliders, truffle dosa, chana bhatura, all amazing!  Kudos Dosa!

Sj7HxTlCJB0UF4vdTQdAUA.review_text: Favorite indian spot in the city (and i'm indian). Get the Rye Raja for a drink if you like Manhattans. All of the lamb dishes are awesome.  Get there early on Fridays and you can usually get a spot at the bar if you're just going for 2 people.

aYrrzXlu-beXf-KsWPhm-Q.review_text: Dosa sf is expensive indian fare. They have a lot of good things going for them.  Pros: Great ambience.  They have the best vada Pav dare say better than the ones in Mumbai. There I said it. The trick - Carmelized onions and perfectly spiced.  Their warm toddy is absolutely amazing.  Pumpkin soup is awesome.  Uttappam and sambar is amazing.  The papad that is given free is soooo good.  Moong salad is very nice.  Coconut rice and stew is out of the world. The spices sort of make love in your mouth in a very nice way :)  Cons: Expensive indian food and drinks.  Dosa is ok.

HDQjLgm0u8WwlkQU6oHmqw.review_text: I think there's a big unmet need for upscale Indian dining and I wish there were more places like Dosa in SF!  Loved virtually all of the food and most of the drinks.  Tip: GO!  Food:  - Bhel Puri: nice and spicy - White Truffle Masala Dosa: this blew my mind, honestly. So creative and so delicious! - Raita: don't skimp on raita, the food here is spicy and you'll need it - Prawn Masala: definitely the standout curry of the evening. You have to try it! - Chennai Chicken: bit like Indian KFC, super delicious!  Drinks: - Mango is the new black: I loved the name, but this was way too strong for my taste - Mango Lassi: really solid lassi. Thick, not too sweet, and no artificial coloring. - Ginger Ante: what a fabulous drink! Kind of like a jazzed up ginger beer.

c8FOqDRhtL7q_YsQio6bog.review_text: When friends from out-of-town ask me for an SF restaurant recommendation, Dosa on Fillmore is usually in my top 5.  This place just works on so many levels. The food is always good, the cocktails are among the best in town (and infused with Indian spices, house-made tinctures, nectars, cordials and bitters), the decor is exquisite, and the dining room and bar area is always packed and lively. This feels more like a New York night club than a South Indian restaurant. Once you walk through the door, you just want to join the party.   I always like to start out with their Chennai Chicken (fried, boneless chicken bites marinated in yogurt with coriander and cumin). This dish is technically an appetizer, but it's big enough to be a whole meal. I also recommend the Samosas "North & South" (savory pastries filled with caramelized onions and veggies (South) and spiced potatoes (North). Both North and South come with sweet and spicy dipping sauces.  Obviously, this restaurant is famous for their Dosas (a large, savory rice and lentil crepe, served with fresh coconut & tomato chutneys and sambar, a lentil dipping soup made with veggies and spices). My favorites are the basic Masala (a classic dosa filled with mashed potatoes, onions and cashew nuts), and the Spicy Mung Masala (made with green chilies, chopped onions, cilantro and spiced potatoes). This is finger food at its finest! You definitely won't walk away with an empty stomach. Warning: the Roasted Chile & Garlic Masala is incredibly spicy! Don't get me wrong, I love spice. But this thing had my eyes watering for 20 minutes And then I made the mistake of rubbing my eyes, and it only made it worse.  The restaurant also offers some other tasty (non-Dosa) selections, including some seasonal curry dishes, a chicken biryani, and vegetarian dishes. One of the best items on the menu is the grilled lamb chop (marinated in spices, and served with lentil sauce, spiced potatoes & cauliflower, and raita). It's out of this world, my friends.  ** Reservations are definitely recommended. ** This is a great spot to hit up before or after a movie at the Sundance Kabuki Theatre (across the street). ** Food prices are reasonable (but more expensive than your average Indian restaurant). The cocktails are delicious and go down easy (but they ain't cheap). Be careful how many you order because your bill will quickly add up.

z8XDjqSf4gvqpX0uO6OhUA.review_text: Ahh...it was ok. I probably wouldnt go back again as I didnt particular like most of the food. The service however was A+.

aSPF1OP2N-0EkHKotNfDQw.review_text: Alright, so rolled into Dosa at the least optimal time. It was about 4:30 on a Sunday afternoon while they were prepping for dinner. Fortunately, me and my main gal prefer to post at the bar so that wasn't a problem and sampled the bar menu.  Had some beers and tried everything on the bar menu and would have to tip the cap to the fried chicken bites. Fortunately the main dinner menu opened up and we were able to roll up the sleeves.   The duck vindaloo is an absolute joke - so good. Just fall off the bone duck served over some basmati rice. The heat was solid but not overwhelming and just couldnt have been more tender - literally shredding off the bone. This was my first experience with this regional Indian cuisine and it was money.   Definitely recommend giving Dosa a try but bring a benji at a minimum.   Also had the mushroom nan - not my bag but my D8 loved it, so there's that.

5CQ6uuPReWQ2fa6hwbkYlA.review_text: Great atmosphere, great service, and great food. Obviously try their dosa. Don't know which one? All the staff is knowledgeable and can set good recommendations.The waitresses are super polite and not to mention,really attractive.

DmiRrIw45rvbHFa_H-eShg.review_text: Dosa is a solid choice and they always seem to have an open table in a pinch. The restaurant is spacious and the atmosphere would work for a business lunch/dinner or a night out with friends.   I'm usually good with a paneer dosa and the dahi vada lentil dumpling and yougurt appetizer.

94GxshAQal0Pa84eDAvxcQ.review_text: Growing up around some of the best dosa joints in South India, I gotta say - this place feels like home! All of the items I have tasted so far, taste very authentic and even the new age-inventive ones are really good. You know how annoying it gets when foreign cuisines taste completely different in the U.S because they have been modified for the American Palette? That has NOT happened here. What i mean is, you will not find either bland or extremely stereotypical - spicy curry like food here.  That being said, I can only vouch for the dosas, idli, vada and the other typical south Indian dishes. I have not and will not try other dishes here ever.   White truffle masala and fried idli (appetizers) are especially good. There is usually a long waiting time if you go without reservation. Even if you have to wait for an hour, I think it will be worth it!

LHGKvE9Q2lLgQXEHNZP58Q.review_text: Great food and service. I recently visited and reached 30 minutes early, but they were friendly enough to take us in. Highly recommend the Vada Pav appetizer there. The bartender was friendly and engaged us in a fun conversation as well. I would recommend this place to my friends/family. Quiet ambiance, Good lighting, Friendly people.

eAv8E68tQZBqRrmOxkfsvw.review_text: My friend invited me to meet her here after work on a Friday evening for drinks in the Fillmore. I arrived seconds before she did around 5:45 and we were seated immediately at the communal table near the bar (we were the first to sit at this giant table). I didn't read any yelp reviews prior, so I only knew it was going to be Indian food. When I peered at the menu, I was a little bit shocked to see the prices (~$30 for curry). Since it was my first time, I only wanted to test the waters and thankfully my friend didn't intend on eating a full dinner either. We each got one drink and shared an order of lamb keema dosa, which was super delicious. It was flavorful without being overwhelming, and it didn't make my stomach hurt like most Indian food did afterwards. Also my friend got the peony gin cocktail, which she swears by. I'm totally getting that next time. I got a virgin drink that had mint and a bunch of stuff in it, reminded me of a mojito. What really blew me away was our waiter. I think he worked at the bar. Even though we didn't order a whole lot for a typical evening at Dosa, he still was super nice and friendly. He even asked complimented me on my nail polish and asked about who did it. (Um, yeah that would be me... And I just did it to cover up old gel polish I didn't have time to go get removed). He was so sweet, you swear you were high school BFFs. Thank you! You were so fun! I didn't end up getting the bill, since my friend was treating me (and wouldn't let me pitch in), so I don't know how much we tipped. But for the friendly service and tasty food, despite the cost of the food itself, I would totally return!

IGkZa0eanufzVv9FR7kSUg.review_text: It's HARD to get in here on weekend nights! Even to sit at the bar. :( I think we walked in on a weeknight around 8:30 and were able to squeeze in for a 2 person table. It's a classy venue--great for a night out or a fancy dinner before or after a movie at the Kabuki theater!  We got the Duck Vindaloo per Yelp reviews, but it was a bit spicy..even for my Indian boyfriend's tastes!   The truffled masala dosa was very interesting--frighteningly oily to the touch, but tasty in moderation. A little heavy after a while. If heavy foods are not for you, share with one or more other people.

kOll36Me-rM9NsqoDnejKA.review_text: Good things: - Nice looking decor - Interesting cocktails (hit or miss, but definitely interesting) - A few very good dishes (particularly the chicken biryanni, which I know is not spelled right)  Not-so-good things: - Too expensive for Indian food - They do not serve traditional naan at all, and if you want any other type of bread and/or chutneys, you have to pay for them! - Dessert menu lacking some traditional Indian staples, such as gulab jamun!!

AIItwMHenH6w3tqwJVIBDA.review_text: The tasting menu is very affordable and the portions of the dishes are all very generous.    I don't know if I would make Dosa my goto spot for Indian, but it was definitely an enjoyable experience.  One thing that my friend and I both noticed was that the floors in the dining area were pretty slippery.  I thought I was going to take a spill when I was walking to the table

j0w0ARyo3fMr57m7azvA6A.review_text: I went to Dosa last week with my boyfriend and it was very disappointing. Admittedly, I have been there twice before and had a great experience, but this time that was not the case. I had made a reservation for 7pm, but when we got there the hostess said that our table wasn't ready and that we would have to wait "a few minutes". Twenty minutes later, they finally seated us.   We ordered a few things, and the waiter was initially helpful in telling us which items had cilantro in them, since my boyfriend can't eat cilantro. However, he neglected mention that the side of rice we had ordered had cilantro in it, so when it arrived my boyfriend couldn't eat it. Also, my boyfriend ordered an appetizer that never arrived and was not on our check. Other than that, the food was delicious, and the drinks were fantastic. I got the channa batura and my boyfriend ordered the mulligatawny chicken. We shared an egg dosa, which was surprisingly good (I was a bit skeptical about the eggs).   Then the bill came and the total was over $90, so our damage was over $100 with tip. I know this place is expensive, and the food is really great, but for that much money I expect stellar service, which we did not have. I give them four stars for food but two for service. I can only hope that it will be better next time-- if we go here again.

xzDP9rukDxUaozo8K673Bw.review_text: Meh  I don't know many authentic Indian places that don't serve Naan let alone Chicken Tikka Masala. I guess I'm"m a bit old fashioned.  Overall this place is very Fancy Shmancy. Nothing wrong with that though, It would be fun for a great night out with your Boo. But me and mine were not quite looking for that. We did however love the samosas, and the bread that came with the dipping sauces. One of them was like a soup and that is exactly how we ate it. I must say that soup/dipping sauce was the best part.

mz-ongPkeXFaX7HL5ef7Og.review_text: Good place, clean and a wonderful ambience. Mixed bag when it came to food - some wonderful dishes like the dahi wada and bhel. And some of the dosas were very good. The chutney (which is the soul of a good dosa) left much to be desired - didn't expect it in such a fancy place to be made of dedicated coconut. The Frankie's were mediocre at best. Overall expected slightly better quality for the price.

ebUEL_l3eA1Jo9uh6Qs8Xw.review_text: Amazing foood!  Hella delicious.  Definitely get the masala dosa if you go, you'll love it :)

xrtk_wS48TsGQi0qWIHNQg.review_text: This Dosa is larger and more upscale than the one on Valencia. The quality of the meals seems the same--very good. The menu is also varied, with choices for vegetarians and meat-eaters. It's possible, too, go easy on the spices (I've noticed that people who shy away from Indian food seem to think it's all very spicy.) The person who seated our party of four took some time to deliver a kind of mini-lecture on the nature of the cuisine, etc. That seemed a bit odd, but probably it's welcomed by diners unacquainted with Indian food. Overall, the experience was very good--not overly loud, no rushing, hearty fare, etc.

9U30DANobkrn3Zlu6T9p6Q.review_text: Dosa is ridiculous. Bhatura is probably one of the most memorable things I've eaten this year - basically a crazy inflated naan. I've never seen anything like it. All the plates we tried were solid. No question it's pricey, but well worth it.   I'd come back.

jxdGL90JR1b6UTvfxwW9TQ.review_text: Dosa is going to be my inaugural entry for my new list: Places to Eat Alone and Not Feel Like a Dork. Yes, I'm single-handedly bringing back the word Dork. So there.  Dosa has a regular bar where you can eat, but I love the big community table just past the hostess station. It makes you feel like you're still part of the bigger restaurant as a whole, but you don't feel like you stand out when you're eating alone. I will often dip in somewhere to grab a bite, as the teens have all their activities and I've sometimes gotta kill some time and it's mealtime.  So Wednesday night, came in around 7:30 and no problem to sit at the community table. Very friendly, very competent service. After asking a few questions, I landed on ordering the Bhel Puri and just the straight up classic Masala dosa. When the Bhel Puri came, I had completely forgotten what was in it....but it was so delicious that I gobbled it down pretty quickly. Looking at their online menu now, it was puffed rice, roasted parsnips, potatoes, tomatoes, onions & tangerines, flavored with spicy mint and tamarind chutneys. I highly recommend it. Then the dosa came...and it was just fine. It's not the first time I've been here, and not the only place I've had dosas, but it had been awhile so I was somewhat surprised when the filling seemed to be all plopped into the middle of the crepe-like outside. No big deal - I spread it around as I tore it off and dipped it sauces. But just a little odd.   Anyway, of course I started chatting up the ladies who were seated across from me, as we had seen each other in line at the film festival we just came from, so I spent most of the evening talking with them....so never felt like I was alone. But if I had never talked with anyone, I still would have felt extremely comfortable here eating alone.

qEQuMbZ8MDOFhwFzFhmFdw.review_text: Rating for the bar: came to bar before our dinner reservation at a different restaurant. 4 people, 2-3 drinks each, and an app...I highlight to show we spent money and weren't just taking up seats. I ordered one drink that I really disliked. I asked bartender if I could exchange it as I wasn't a fan. His response? In a very disgusted tone "did you read the ingredients before you ordered it??" What type of question is that? Of course I did! Every drink you make is custom for the restaurant. How could I have ordered it without reading it first! It is this type of attitude that makes me not want to visit again as there are so many great places.  In the end, he did replace it. But we definitely left on a sour note (given how much I like this place!)

ahgpV2YpOZawgIHJEZCtxA.review_text: Well - in short, it's a place that's trying to be what it is not. The setting and ambience are definitely good, and the servers try to be at their best, but I couldn't care for all the hype if all your genuine attempts still fall short. I tried the Rava Dosa, which is my barometer for how good you are at dosas, and it was a 3/5 - which is, not too bad. Next was the Hyderabadi Chicken Biryani - which was not even a 1/5. Too salted, no biryani flavor, et al. All this would have been still fine if the servers hadn't taken over 5 minutes to re-fill my glass with wine, as well as just taken the glass away after 2 drinks without caring to ask if I'd like some more. So, overall, meh. There are tons of better Indian cuisine options in the bay area without the pretentions and hype that this place fails to deliver on.

q3h0fB3d4zECXC5H9E3Wog.review_text: It was great experience; from great food to awesome service. We have dine in almost all Indian restaurants in Bay Area and there is no comparison or equal  to Dosa on Fillmore. Each dish was perfectly spiced and cooked. All suggested side dishes complimented the main dish. A+

rY0FQO9EN9ZBtFTvvhr8Mw.review_text: Best place in SF to get India food. It has the small restaurant vibe with brilliant service and great food.   Must try: Masala Dosa Not to try: Garlic Masala (only if you can chew habaneros)

Mz8UNnWUNs__JObPLtw06Q.review_text: Giving a star for good food.However, horrible service and rude waiter(Alejandro) left a bad taste. The management of this place is pathetic. We got 40 mins before closing and every person from the hostess to our first waitress (who disappeared in 5 mins) to the second waiter kept on reminding our party of nine about the last call and  how we need to make sure all our order is in. Alejandro our waiter tries to dictate how he likes to take food orders and he goes crazy if that order is not followed.  He didn't like any interruption and got irritated if any questions were asked on the menu. Note to the management: Make sure good quality consistent service is provided irrespective of time.  We really wanted to visit this place ever since we moved to SF . There were nine people in our party and everyone was utterly  disappointed.

AVSylpAISyFs1cDryDpskQ.review_text: Came here for restaurant week.  The restaurant is just absolutely stunning looking and the service was excellent.  The reason it's a 3 star is that the food was just a little too much for us -- most of the dishes were too spicy in various ways.  The cocktail was quite good so I might come back for drinks and perhaps light snacking at the bar.

We4TatIKeQS4xE5aEar0eg.review_text: service is great as is the food. Great place to share plates!

G7l_KK1OjJMAGWlNFcWQVQ.review_text: This is an upscale Indian place that specializes in Southern Indian cuisine (their own description). The ambience is nice and romantic. Well, but that was ruined because we were seated at a communal table, across from each other. On our right side, one guy and two women in their middle ages were talking about some serious mid-life crisis stuff (at some point, they talked about an ex-wife who did voodoo right in front of her son). On our left side, a couple was dining and talking about some classy movie stars like Keanu Reeves. It was amusing to umm not intentionally overhear everything they were saying, but it definitely did not make a great date spot (the communal table, that is).            They offered a $42 three-course meal that can be shared between two people, and my boyfriend and I took the deal after making very quick calculations.   It was definitely enough food for two. We ended up getting:    1st course: Seafood vada - not recommended. This was more like a seafood pancake that doesn't really taste like seafood. They could have told me it was a potato pancake and I would not have known the difference. Get something else!   2nd course: Dosas with lamb (+ we got masala on the side). Meh. Dosa tasted like a not as tasty version of Ethiopian sour dough rolls. They provided two types of chutney with dosas, but that wasn't flavored strongly enough to complement the sour taste of dosa. The lamb was okay, and the masala was okay. But I didn't think anything was great or amazing. Also, they only gave us one roll of dosa and we thought given the price, we would have liked one more.      3rd course: Chicken Xacut. This was actually pretty good. It was spicy (pretty spicy), red Indian curry with chicken in it served with rice.    All in all, I thought it was a good one-time experience. But I would not seek this place out again, especially at their price.

v33h5lhnhrr-JqnHVTrUfA.review_text: Dosa does amazing in some cases interesting original creations inspired by South Indian Cuisine. We went for a mid week lunch. The ambiance was very good, very quiet place. The wait staff were super fast and very efficient. We tried a few original creations and liked everything. Dosa and Sambar were very good, Vadai in Sambar was yummy. I can have these all day.  Other original creations were very tasty and interesting, quality of food was very good, portions were perfect.  Tried their desserts,  Red Chili in Caramel and Chocolate... ummm.. it confuses you, but I liked it. Curry leaf in a dessert...bold move, it did not backfire though.

NEOSYsubf7SVeVm8RytxYA.review_text: WOW!  way to tickle my taste buds Dosa!  This has always been on my SF restaurant list. My friend lived in walking distance and I would always see the fancy chandelier, which made me immediately say "YES, I am going to try this restaurant one day!"  Lo and behold! I finally arrived.  I am used to the usual Indian food like Chicken Tikka Masala and Naan.  Boy was I in for a delightful awakening.  I had no idea where, what, and who to order on this menu.  In the end, my friend and I shared, which all I highly recommend!  Watermelon, paneer salad- very very interesting texture and flavoring  Corn and curry leaf Soup- very tasty and with a spicy kicker at the end of each bite  Summer vegetable Curry- really tasty and great with the rice!  Spicy Basil Dosa-  YUM!  The sauces are unique to each other.  You are supposed to eat it with your hands, so get ready to get down and dirty!  Bottom Line:  you can't go wrong with anything on the menu, cute fancy spot especially for a date night

rUFgjrq2Dq9GAug1YayHYw.review_text: Great food + good service + Good ambiance = great evening!  I love south Indian food & this place does it with a twist that's quite interesting (Like an uttapam made non-traditional ingredients like broccoli!). The Sambhar (which every one knows, can make or break the deal) is very tasty; & my husband thought their pepper lamb was to die for.  Their desserts are very creative too. Besides, you start out the meal with a bowl of their complimentary fried papad :) Oh, & did I mention that they have a top shelf bar with really tasty cocktails too.... Whats not to like!?!  :)

5PVKSvCF5PMOA8G48way0w.review_text: I was visiting for the weekend and tried to get a reservation on a Saturday night for a group of 4, but wasn't able to get one till Sunday. Even though the place was packed when we arrived Sunday night, we were seated quickly. There is a cool vibe and a more upscale ambience than what I've experienced in the Indian restaurants I'm used to going to ( the kind that serve the inexpensive lunch buffets). I liked the variety on the menu - in addition to the curries and vindaloos and variations of lamb, there are dosas and uttapam. I have to admit I hadn't heard of the latter two before, so of course that's what we had to try. First though, we decided to go for the cocktails. I chose the "peony" because peonies are one of my favorite flowers and I thought it would be interesting as a drink - wow, it was delicious and unique! From what my companions said about their drinks, this would definitely be my choice again.   Instead of bread, we had pappadums (or at least that's what I thought they were) - kind of like Indian tortilla chips and really addicting. For dinner, we started with an appetizer - we went for the standby North and South Samosas, which were basically yummy as you would expect. We also ordered the Vada Pav (vegetarian sliders) on the recommendation of the server, but those didn't show up until we were nearly done with our dinner so we just brought them home. As I said, the restaurant was crowded and maybe that is the reason for the spotty service, but it seemed they should not have charged us for something that was their error (we didn't ask, but if a restaurant has really good customer service, you shouldn't have to). Since the entrees tend to be expensive and the name of the place is Dosa, I think it's a good plan to go with ordering dosas for your meal - very filling!  My choice was a Spicy Basil Dosa, which came as all the dosas do, with fresh coconut and tomato chutney as well as sambar (lentil dipping soup) - delish! My friend loved the dips so much that even when she was done with her dosa, she scooped up the rest with her spoon and enjoyed every drop. We were all too full for dessert. Overall, Dosa was a great experience for the food, and hopefully the service will be better next time.

Xf5KPJimu8cLFndTL8WPJQ.review_text: How could I have never tried the Spicy Mung Masala (Pesarattu) Dosa? SO SO SO good!! Very different from your usual dosa, since it's made with mung lentils, but what an amazing flavor! I highly recommend you try this variety if you've already had other dosas - better late than never, but clearly I was missing out!

Ae1atVuqSF8r5QkchacXVg.review_text: Yum. I'm a sucker for high-end Indian food. The decor is immaculate, and the food is great. The service is a little slow for such a high-end restaurant, which is the reason for knocking down a star. The spicy garlic dosa is (shock) SPICY. Make sure you eat it with the potatoes. I had to get a lassi (which was excellent) to help with the heat. The bhel puri was ridiculously good and beautifully presented.  A little expensive, but well worth it

mhTqDLCPQO-N4x9s6swv_g.review_text: I love the food. I always seem to eat too much. The dosa pancake is a big hit amongst my family members. But boy is the food salty. So salty. I am soaking up water all night and all next day. My face is puffy too.  The duck vindaloo was quite dry, not living up to the expectations. The prawn masala was delicious and definitely my favorite. My father favors the lamb curry.   The food is very salty. If it wasn't so salty, it'd be much more delicious.

zW1EKuqvhqhFy_X095TeMQ.review_text: Went here on a Saturday night, party of two with reservations. Seated right away on the second floor and had a very amiable and attentive server. The ambiance was great: beautiful lighting structures, not too loud, and a wonderful crowd of families and people on dates. The food is probably not authentic but I found it to be well-done and very delicious. The kabocha squash small plate was great, not too oily, thoroughly cooked. The lamb dosa was amazing! The crepe was huge and while a bit greasy, it complimented the spicy, herb-y lamb filling nicely. My mouth was on fire (though I do have a low tolerance for spicy) but it was so good I kept eating. It also came with a spicy soup which was flavorful but not overpowering. I found the portions to be generous and barely managed to finish my dessert, which was also great - the cheese balls in a rose water cream (don't know what it's called).  Overall, would come again on a date and definitely getting the lamb dosa again.

qZyFSNJ2n7hLITQIDP9SrQ.review_text: Cool spot , great food, the old fashion was on point , try the masala dosa and the lamb chops .

Q8O3qnuNWqpYijIszhG2LQ.review_text: Dosa is great and offers southern rather then northern Indian cuisine which seems much more common in the US, the flavors are complex and the food really comes to life, the drinks are great and the service is right on par with everything else here; I recommend Dosa!   Order the Papadum with Chutney sampler as it is the best I've had and Chennai Chicken is delicious as well.

CMdFQ0y0zvzBS2x6tjZcWA.review_text: I came here years ago and had been dying to come back for a long time ever since.  The perfect opportunity came into play to have my graduation lunch here.  All the staff was courteous and solicitous for the entire experience.   Our party of 7 was served upon by AC.  He was every bit patient with some of us who weren't real sure what to order and answering questions about the menu.  For some who weren't too keen on "spicy" he suggested the Papadam with some yogurt sauce.  Good call!  Several in our party ordered a Dosa, but I couldn't get past the Lamb "Frankie".  I asked for extra spicy, and they did just that!  It was yummalicious, juicy morsels of lamb combined with South Indian spices rolled up in roti.  It hit the spot.  I can't wait to come back with my bf and sample some small plates.    The decor inside is beautiful and themed appropriately emanating South Indian motifs and colors.  -love the lavish chandeliers and as I remember, the lighting gets dramatic and creates a perfect date night atmosphere.  The only thing I would say is despite many people being in the restaurant for our late lunch the drinks came out kind of slow (wine and dirty martinis) or we were drinking too fast.  -guess that's what happens when you're having fun. lol  They were good with keeping our water glasses full though and clearing the table.  -awesome spot and definitely one of my favorites.    Heck yes, I'll be back!

047SxW0HHAncxomaxjLP5Q.review_text: Amazing vada pav sliders, loved their chicken kheema. Must visit!

7-60JxBf0l0x-o8jzcXAvg.review_text: Excellent and festive!!!! Packed house.. Went on Friday pre-show at Fillmore! Got a few martinis and 2 appetizers! We told bartender we were in rush and he accommodated! Ordered a seafood cake and duck, I think! Nice portions, pricey but my mom was paying!!!

QXZbn6z_QeZ78XVQ8KScMQ.review_text: Utterly delighted to know someone out there is spending time, money and energy to make Indian food elevated and fancy. And not losing the essence of good taste and exceptional variety that Indian food offers. And yes, am one of those to order Dosa at Dosa. Keema dosa it was...not divine but was very happy with it after a long walk and accompanied by good folks in SF. The best on the table was the very well presented Dahi -bhalla. The cocktails were innovative but not many vodka choices. Emerald Monk was spicy and punchy. I'd be happy to recommend Dosa to anyone- it showcases the wonder of Indian cuisine well to any global gourmand.

ZS4sfBM_nhEBO35m9L-qsw.review_text: Great ambience and amazing food!  What more do you need?!  I loved this location better than their other one.  More hip and trendy. Their dosas are probably one of the bests I've ever had. If you eat here it's a just to try a non traditional dosa.  We had the spinach and fennel so freaking good!  I also had a bowl of rassam- spicy, tangy and savory just leaves you wanting more.   The only negative was the dessert.  As a group we decided to order 1 dessert and share. We ordered the pistachio item on the menu. How can you go wrong right?!  Well it was horrible.  That said I said I wouldn't dwell into it much and rouine the amazing meal I had.  I'll def be back here again just will pass on the dessert.

7InRgIYSokM_PSHYMs6x6w.review_text: Everything was DELICIOUS. Chef did not hold back on the spices...and that doesn't mean just making it "hot", just very flavorful. The dosas were awesome. Our party ordered the paper dosa & spicy basil dosa. Never tried a basil dosa before, and loved it. Also, someone ordered these little Indian veggie sliders (LOL, I'm sure it has a name), and it was yummy. When I asked my friend what it was, all I got was "indian street food". If that's Indian street food, then please let me roam the Indian streets for more of that!  But, check your bill. They added tip to our table of 5, which is not customary at other restaurants. So we ended up double tipping.

2LL48iJQWFeZcbb9WeLYHA.review_text: It's good a little bit on the expensive side but worth it

Al2_PuJueQ1llSXu3CyhJQ.review_text: As always and expected, DOSA on Fillmore lives up to its name and reputation. Named after a famed bread of South India, DOSA rocks this jazzy part of town night after night with its curries and beautiful South Indian flavors. The restaurant is stylish, chic and innovative. It is upscale for sure. But nice to know a place prepares delicious dishes that combine fresh ingredients and uncomplicated layers of flavors. DOSA is no bs -- it tells you that Indian food does not have to be difficult. This restaurant not only provides inspiration for food lovers or a self-proclaimed foodie like me and easy- to-eat dishes that begin with basics for those who are less assured in an Indian restaurant. With its visually enticing plates, this place makes a great place to share a great time and good, I mean really good Indian food, with your friends. As an enthusiast cook who specialize in Indian food myself, I believe good food is a combination of fresh ingredients and uncomplicated layers of flavors. When you start with quality produce, a few simple flavors will just complement and contrast with your base ingredients to create the perfect taste experience. Think of food with passion, not anxiety, and feel free to substitute as you please. This is often how personalized culinary masterpieces are created. That's DOSA. Tonight, just like everytime, the dishes were spiced, flavored, curried and cooked to perfection and all arrived lavishedly drizzled or bathed in light raita and sauce. Getting in, we knew what this place is all about, the air inside flavored unmista y... We asked for two major curry dishes and  the go-withs -- the lemon and coconut basmati rice, and four other small plates including its biggest star -- the dosa itself. It is truly a star dish to say the least -- favored so beautifully to perfection, light, crispy, fluffy and folded perfectly on a flat white plate. Scratch it gently with the fork and the flavors burst out... The other small plate that I truly enjoyed tonight is the scallop dish -- perfectly seared and served over a light raita sauce. Coming from Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, where Indian food is everywhere, my girls know the delicate southern taste of India and were pleased with their maincourses and side orders tonight. The craftcocktails were unbelievably delightful, too. I am giving them another double thumbs up! We ordered the vodka-based Peony, Half Moon, Hanging Gardens, and Ginger Ice Tea. They are DOSA's prize fighters and truly refreshing. If you are a light weight like me, tell them because each kicks in nicely and warms you up almost instantly. Tonight, the food/drink pairing was spot on--light lamb and fish curries were beautifully paired with sweetened cocktails instead of its famed Sujata wines. The service was really sweet to say the least -- by that I meant relaxed and unhurried. Drinks unpushed.  The noise level was good. The price? A little pricey but it is an upscale restaurant and a great place to celebrate with loved ones. Go!

626y2W3N3SzIyphj133DxQ.review_text: The Service was horrible. We were made to wait an entire hour even though we had a confirmed reservation. They did not have a table ready for us and made us wait 45 minutes at the bar. When enquired about the table after waiting so long, the waitress blatantly lied saying that since the entire party is not here we cannot seat you. Why was this not informed to us upon arrival or even when making the reservation. The most horrible service you can ever get if you waited for an hour before being seated.

t2bHB_tyFfp4jukuVeNryw.review_text: Excellent service, large delicious dosas, great ambiance. We had the classic and the sweet potato dosas. Also had a Wry Rajah cocktail which was super delicious!

tGgTIueZy1JNTzQD9rkZLQ.review_text: 01.26.10  Hurray for no one falling off chairs this time around!  Seriously, this place is too popular.  I feel so uncool walking in here that I immediately had to order a glass of $10 wine to calm my nerves.  We started with the samosas again.  They were still fabulous.  I tried the tamil vegetable curry with cauliflower, green beans, potatoes, carrots, cherry tomatoes and coconut rice.  It was SO delicious and complemented the glass of sauvignon blanc well.  And, number 67 on the 2010 7x7 100 Things to Eat+Drink Before You Die list - paper masala dosa.  My word, this thing could feed a village!  A definite order, every time.  Dosa is also known for their delicious cocktails.  We had the Emerald Sound (Domaine de Canton, rye whiskey, mango gastrique, absinthe rinse, mint, shaken over ice) and the Peony (No. 209 Gin, hibiscus masala nectar, coconut milk, lime, orange flower water, kaffir lime leaf, birds eye chili, up).  They were both quite tasty, and with a kick to boot!  Positive experience all around.

pypZb3V5TXHOnlTj-qLSrw.review_text: Dosa on Fillmore is pretty darn good, but do you see the three $$$ for this place?  It's cause you don't get a lot of bang for your buck.  I enjoyed the white truffle masala, not so much the chicken korma (which was inexplicably expensive).  But overall, I'm excited about this place.  It's pretty apparent that they care about quality.

hW3kd-nzihHjGvP0EYLhUQ.review_text: Tried dosa and a daily cocktail. Liked both . Sambar was good but more spicy than I thought. Will visit again

TmAX3Az4O34oH7Kxj1AcIA.review_text: Yummy food and cocktails.  We went last weekend and I would say that the food wasn't the best I've ever had or incredibly memorable but it was good and that atmosphere and service were nice.  I would definitely go here again, maybe before a movie at Kabuki since its across the street!    PS - this is also a great option if you get negged (like we have now twice) at State Bird Provisions down the street.  Good way to turn around the buzzkill of being told there's a 4 hour wait after you already stood in line for 30 minutes before the restaurant opens (as you can see, I'm still a little bitter about it!).

4YZNnqeOjPvxUXsMP6xd_g.review_text: Service was great - the waitress explained the entire menu for us! Food was good - not too heavy, but flavorful. Nice ambience and affordable wine.

USB-WW1Y4-N5vVz-89D9TQ.review_text: A stylish departure from your typical, neighborhood Indian place in many ways, the Southern Indian menu offers some familiar as well as the more "exotic"  presentations of dishes.  Many dishes have heat, many more have high presentation value and the large menu deserves to be explored. I prefer the dosa over the uttapam but you should find out for yourself by coming to this more modern, sexier location.

buR0zf3kLTMV4cQsS--IDA.review_text: great tasting food, if you're in the mood for something different, this is the place. the service is great too. Ive been here twice now and i have nothing bad to say about the place, except it might be hard to find parking at times

PMPOxuDcSTyOLzFf-Vnv3w.review_text: Love every thing that they serve here including the cocktails. The Rye Rajah is my favourite. The Sambar is truly the best you will have in the Bay Area. And the Ras Malai!! uufff... to die for.... The only con is that the place is pricey for Indian food, but once in a while one can surely afford it...

hdMq0DDBzelwEsNEUFJmlA.review_text: Contemporary flare on South-Indian.  Good food and good drinks.  Definitely get the Dahi Vadha and Rasam.  Do not eat here before going out on the town though.

eXD_rMgwm0IaSfCSJbsqYQ.review_text: I got here around 5:45p on a Thursday, and managed to get a table for 4 at the bar for happy hour instantly.  FYI--Happy hour is Monday through Thursday from 5:30p-7:00p  It got busy quick, and by the time my party of 4 left around 7:30, the bar was pretty packed.  So get here early!  Disclaimer: I never finished my PhD in Indian cuisine, so I cannot attest to the authentic-ness of the food here, but I enjoyed Dosa's food along with the chic-lounge atmosphere.  My happy hour beverage of choice: -Chili-margarita! ($6)  Your basic margarita with a spicy kick.  I'll take two!  It might not be on the menu when you go, because I think the happy hour drinks rotate.  Happy hour menu choices: -Samosas 'North and South':  Maybe it was the chili margaritas, but I couldn't really tell the difference between North and South (i'm talking about the food here, not my motor skills).  Regardless, the dipping sauces are what really made this dish. -Chennai chicken (2 orders): I love the popcorn chicken at Tapioca Express, and that is basically what this is, minus the spice.  Served with a creamy, tangy yogurt sets this apart from your typical TapX chicken.  The chicken was crunchy on the outside, yet juicy and tender on the outside.  One order should be sufficient for two people if you are sampling other goodies.   -Vada Pav (vegetarian slider):  Two sliders per order.  Not my favorite dish of the night, but definitely worth a try.  Dosa choices: -Paper masala:  Delicious!  Pretty simple dish consisting of a paper-thin crepe served with Indian potatoes and dipping sauces.  This is a definitely a staple dish that I order when I go to Dosa.  -White truffle masala:  Delicious x 2.  Essentially the paper masala, but with the Indian potatoes drizzled with truffle oil and stuffed inside the crepe.  I'm drooling just thinking about it.  At $34 per person, this isn't the cheapest happy hour I've been to (then again I've probably dropped more at other happy hours on booze alone), so I take back my statement.  Overall, a fun place to go for happy hour--great food, delicious drinks, and a chic atmosphere!

eLwBpaKnlbKEhOZGy7bnyQ.review_text: Out of the two locations - Valencia and Fillmore - I preferred the one on Fillmore.  This location is 3 times the size of the one on Valencia.  It is fancier with spacious seating and spotless bathrooms.  There are two things that differentiate this place from other South Indian restaurants: (a) This place does not smell like Indian food and neither does your hair/clothes after you leave. (b) This is one of the very few South Indian restaurants that offers non-vegetarian food.  We went here for lunch and didn't really need reservations.  Now to the food: - Vada Paav: to die for.  Probably better than what I have eaten in India. - South Indian Bhel: not bad but not the best - Rava Masala Dosa: AMAZING!!!! The dosa comes with two chutneys....coconut and tomato. Both the chutneys were delicious.  TIP:  If you are like me and prefer the masala on the side and not inside the dosa, make sure you emphasize that you dont want extra masala, but just the masala on the side.  I was charged $4.00 because I said 'masala on the side'.    Overall - one of the best dosa places I have been to.  Just try it to believe it!!!!

hlbsfR2VwAIcdF_PjrttjQ.review_text: Note: I'm half Indian and a lot of this is me nitpicking and offering constructive criticism. If you're reading this on a phone and don't want to read my novel length review, here's the short version: Delicious! Go here!  After all the hype, I knew I would have to try one of the fabulous Indian places in SF--and as it happened, one of Dosa's locations is right down the street from the Hotel Kabuki, where I was staying. It also happened to be right across from the theater I had been planning to see a movie at later that night. Dosa and then the Hunger Games--it seemed as if it was meant to be!  The building took me by surprise--I was expecting classy, but not this much grandeur! Our waiters were helpful, though somewhat socially awkward--not really picking up on our cues and there were definitely some awkward silences that were a little weird. Overall they were helpful and good natured, however, and were happy to explain everything to us.  I am half Bengali and have been to India several times, but I have only been fortunate enough to make it south once. I also lived in Los Angeles for a long period of time, and frequented Artesia, so I'd like to think that I know my way around south Indian food pretty well.  I was intrigued by some of the cocktails, but the waiter sold me on the Ginger Ante, which was quite good--had the warmth and the bite of ginger, rather than just the taste.  My boyfriend and I decided to make the most of our experience and try a little bit of everything. We ordered the South Indian Moons (5 uttapam sampler) and a tasting menu with the things we had read the most raves about: Chennai chicken, the white truffle masala dosa, and the mango prawns.  In all of my experience, South Indian food is sort of like an inferno of deliciousness in the mouth. This definitely seemed like the white people version, with the spice toned waaay down. The dosa itself was sour, but not quite at the level you usually get. That does not mean that it wasn't delicious, though! I was having a love affair with that potato filling, like that annoying pop song by September. "No I can't get over, and I don't know why..." Seriously tasty. The sambar was right on par and the chutneys were delicious as well - the coconut lime one went exceptionally well with the delicateness of this one, I think.  The Chennai chicken was pretty good, but again, I was wanting more spice! I used to get samosas every day when I was in Calcutta and their Northern interpretation was good--they came to our table a little less than piping hot, and if they're anything less than piping hot then the breading can seem a little heavy handed. The southern version was fantastic, though--creamy sweet onions and very well spiced.  The uttapam sampler was one of my favorite things. They brought out sunchoke, paneer, tomato, potato, and green bell pepper (?). The sunchoke was pretty good--the crunch from the sunchokes was a playful element, though at times the pieces would fall out so it seemed it could be a little better married (maybe smaller chunks?). The tomato and potato were my two favorites, with the potato definitely coming out on top - a light, fluffy, slightly sour dream of an uttapam. The paneer I left to my boyfriend because I cannot eat cheese, and he said it was good though it did convey the sometimes spongy quality that paneer can have--nothing wrong with that per se but he is picky about texture. The green bell pepper--question marked because I am not sure if that is exactly what it was--was delicious, whatever it was, crunchy with small enough chunks that it was a seamless part of the uttapam. It had the freshness of green bell pepper without the bitterness, which was really wonderful.  Finally, we were served the mango prawns. The prawns themselves were succulent, the coconut rice fragrant. It took me some time to realize that the chunks were actually mango, though that should have been obvious. If you get this, try to eat them with the prawns--they are quite intense on their own. Overall, no complaints on this one--I was full to bursting and still ate half of it.  Overall, we had a really great experience. Dosa makes South Indian elegant, and while I was missing some of the fire, it was still a delightful experience.

gZJimqt15wp2HSahRcLL0A.review_text: Good Food, good presentation, friendly staff. We sat at the Bar. It was great.  Thank you Binod,

ET8n-r7glWYqZhuR6GcdNw.review_text: It has been a while since my visit to Dosa On Fillmore in early March, but I didn't want to skip a review for the place since it was one of my favorite dinners during my last San Francisco trip. Definitely worth a revisit next time I'm in town.   Dosa does upscale Indian right. The food is great, the environment classy, drinks excellent, and yet you don't feel completely robbed after paying the check. In my opinion, you can't go wrong with the tasting menu, a three course meal for $35. Add on the wine pairing for just $18 more and you will be served pours that are practically full-size and perfectly complementary to your courses.   I'm a little hazy on the details of each dish I had but I know the samosa I started with blew away the samosa I had during my lunch at another restaurant earlier in the day. The second course is a choice between some uttapam and dosa variations; I had never tried either before but the the dosa I ended up ordering was absolutely delicious. The lentil dipping soup served alongside was the perfect accompaniment. The whole thing reminded me of an Indian version of an American favorite: grilled cheese and tomato soup. My third course was some sort of spicy boneless chicken which was also very nice.   Just thinking about this dinner makes me smile because I was also in great company. What's better than sharing an awesome meal with awesome people?

Z88N6qly3Dp5C06XbZ9IMQ.review_text: Dine About Town is here!  My gf has been wanting to try this spot and since I haven't been back in awhile, how could I pass it up?  Their DAT menu is short, with only 3 choices for starters and 4 choices for the main dish. She opted for the Chennai Chicken to start and Lamb Kofta for main.  I wasn't that hungry, I had a huge bowl of oatmeal for breakfast, so I just opted for the Paneer & Peas dosa.   Our Chennai chicken app came out quick, it's boneless, it's fried, it's tender!  seasoned with coriander and cumin, it had a smokiness to it and   I was surprised it didn't have that much heat.  It was served with an asian slaw.  The Lamb Kofta was absolutely tasty and served with saffron rice.  My Paneer and Peas dosa was filled with shredded farmer's cheese, peas and cilantro.  You can dip your dosa in your sambar, which is a spicy lentil soup with veggies.  Or you can dip this into your tomato or coconut chutney.  I chose to eat my sambar separately and had sweat beads on my forehead by the time I was done. Everything was delicious.   The resto was full with every seat in the main dining room occupied and some people at the bar, but we didn't have any problem with service, although I had to ask for a water refill in the end as we paid the bill.  The DAT 2 course menu is $17.95 and is offered Wednesday thru Sunday. Don't forget, they add 4% SF healthcare charge to your bill.

fTr-OWE2xo8tvzEzN6PKSg.review_text: 3 points for the ambience and service.  The food isn't as pleasing as it looks to be.  Not a authentic Indian food.  I got fooled over by the descriptions in their fancy menu.  Masala potato was a huge mistake. Madra coffee-No!!! Not even closeeee!!

zaBtZetjNHClBLFU85tvFA.review_text: Never tried Southern Indian until tonight, the best! Loved every dish ordered and the service was impeccable. Definitely coming back!

dXdXagdSU6od-w6TjBFKbg.review_text: My husband and I stopped here one night before catching a flick at Kabuki. I absolutely love the décor. It was so hip yet traditional. We started out with the Chennai Chicken. I highly recommend this. It was tender and had a nice spice. We then ordered the Masala Dosa and the Prawn Masala. We loved the Prawn dish and the sauce was fantastic! The Masala Dosa on the other hand was not a huge favorite. I think it was the spice that they used that was off putting. Not terrible but not good enough to finish. Overall I would say our visit was pleasant (service was great) but it won't be a spot we will be hitting often. I might venture back with a girlfriend or two since the bar looked lively and fun.

GRnCvRFE6Wgh8mPcVrerew.review_text: I was in a jam finding a venue for 26 people the night before our company holiday party when our previous restaurant wasn't able to accommodate a few last minute additions to our table.  First of all, I lucked out, but Daniel was super helpful in planning our party the blink of an eye and everyone really really enjoyed the food and ambiance.  THANKS FOR SAVING THE DAY!

kUXozMM-hvcSW87bM21RMw.review_text: I like Indian food, but when Lester W. told me that we'd be ordering all vegetarian dishes, I was a bit skeptical.  I'm a girl that likes my meat, but I was willing to give it a shot.  We ordered Samosas 'North & South' for our appetizer.   The dough was nice and crispy and the filling had so much flavor.  They give you two dipping sauces which helped bring out the flavor in the samosas.    For our main dishes, we went with the Paper Dosa, Paneer & Peas Dosa, and Tamil Vegetable Curry.  All of the dishes had their own unique flavors.  We liked all the food, but our favorite was the vegetable curry.  We pretty much wiped the dish clean with our paper dosa.  The portions are definitely very filling.  Its probably better to go with three or four people so you can get a variety of dishes to share.  I guess eating vegetarian once in a while isn't so bad after all.  Good food and good service.  I'll be back for more of that veggie curry!

jkklQQMr1JpFXmN-HCEcJw.review_text: Great service and love this spice! Just a little pricey for lunch...$20 at least per person. Great, hip ambiance. Extensive selection of GLUTEN-FREE entrees!!

P3usQcIegPCl-cdH4IDirg.review_text: Okay, first things first... giving credit where credit is due... the food was amazing. Every single dish was delicious, aesthetically pleasing, and served hot. From a flavors/textures/yum factor, this place is WAY up there.  But the service... God... the service...  Now understandably, it was a challenging day. There was a Ramen Festival about 10 feet away from their front door and as a result, the street was closed off, there were people outside everywhere. We get that. Also, because of said event, traffic was nightmarish. It cost me almost $20 in an Uber to go 1.8 miles to Dosa today, a drive that would normally be about five bucks. And we hopped out and walked the last block, because that last block would have taken us another ten minutes in the car. Fair enough.  But our party of eleven trickled in as best we could under said circumstances, as people were helplessly stuck in gridlock and/or desperately seeking parking. Like everyone else at the restaurant, we were doing the best we could to get there and get seated.  And the restaurant just wouldn't quit bugging us about when our party would arrive. Now, we had 8 people there out of a party of eleven. Food was being ordered. Cocktails were being ordered. We weren't only NOT squatting, but we were still a large party ordering a lot of food and spending a lot of cash.  But part of the reason lunch took so long, and actually the part more responsible for the delay than our transportation issues, was that EVERY time we wanted to order more of something, or someone new arrived and had to order, it took FOREVER. Half of our orders had to be placed again, 15 minutes later, on three separate occasions because someone on the staff dropped the ball. Reminders were not handled gracefully. Coffee was never refilled, until the third time asking. A few times we (very politely) asked the staff to take new orders, were told to wait, and never returned to.  Delicious food, good location, reasonable prices, and beautiful aesthetic. But why didn't anyone bother to train the waitstaff to wait tables?

vv8NRb04olNjcc5lSWLd1w.review_text: Ok I realize I am giving it 4 stars compared to the other million 5's. Here goes my reason, the price they charge for a dosa does not seem reasonable. Dosa unlike a prime steak or things of that nature that deals with pricey raw materials, does not cost all that much to make. So when I think of the folds of profit they make on an item, it does not seem to add up. Well on the flip side, its more of an upscale locale with a great decor. The waiters seemed seriously concerned about my satisfaction which is always nice. The dip dishes was intense. I am from south India where this dish originates and no kidding they have nailed their sambar recipe.

ZNQgqENlQhmoyqAdrsv1OA.review_text: This is definitely not the place for butter chicken and garlic naan, but it's still oh-so-yummy!  Love the batter on the Dosa Masala, so flavorful, and the bread that comes with the Prawn Masala, yum!  It reminds me of chinese green-onion pancake.  They have a good selection of desserts, which is different than most (southern) Indian restaurants.  We got the pistachio chocolate mousse with salted caramel sauce - it was good, but the salted caramel sauce was really really salty.  We also had the banana goat cheese pie, which was very different, and it was really good.  I'll definitely come back!

Z311voqJFnpSmGZZZ8VrSA.review_text: Way way overpriced!   Pretentious, small dishes at outrageous prices. $10 for a two-bite desert. $20 for kofta with three little koftas (and you need to pay extra for rice)  The only thing that is somewhat reasonably priced is the dosas. But much better - go to Udupi palace instead.

vZoPMM9Sq30blYH1dxj9xA.review_text: Place and ambience is really good. The waiter was great and so was rest of the staff. I just did not find the food very creative. The DOSA's were just ok . This is a great place if you want to consume south Indian cusine in upscale setting without fixating on pure taste. Drinks etc were fine and par for the course for an upscale resturant. Chef can let the creative juices flow and throw in some creative DOSA combos which would make this place really great.

IOqWvwIR0KT_YImo7xyqJg.review_text: Great food, fabulous drinks and a romantic atmosphere.

1D50CsY556YbbfAk5Ut6vA.review_text: This is the best Dosa place I have been to in US and in ages to be frank. This is the pure South Indian cuisine restaurant I have visited in a long time. The ambience of the place is good.  I went there with my family and oh boy I felt that I made the right decision. We ordered Rawa Masala Dosa, Vada Sambar, Masala Dosa and Uttapam. The dosas were crisp and well cooked. The quantity of chutney and sambar was also good. I always wanted to have a good Rawa Masala dosa and I am happy to find this place after 2.5 years of stay in US on my maiden trip to SF. I would definitely recommend this place. They have a good variety of Dosa, Uttapam in there menu and hope to visit this place again in near future.

qU_Cd1KgMLy3HhCdsgsFxA.review_text: This is one of my favorite restaurant.! I just love this place! Great food, great service.

YPrVkcsfdYOLVZ27-egaIg.review_text: This place has great stuff.  Cocktails: The Bengali Gimlet Appetizer: Chennai Chicken Main course : Tamil Lamb Side: Mixed Chile Uttapam (They are pretty serious about the "Spicy" warning)

S3N46-Ym9_rec9ZU5iWoxw.review_text: [gluten free]  Couldn't have predicted one of my favorite spots in the city would be Indian food. Just didn't think it was my thing. Then BOOM. Dosa.   If you're looking for gluten free options, you've got a ton of choices here. Ask for the separate GF menu.   Favorites: - Masala dosa and the sweet potato dosa - Chutney sampler - Chennai chicken (yes, it's GF)  So, why not 5 stars? Service isn't out-of-this world and why are those beaded lights above the bar at Dosa Fillmore so dusty?

mWovMFEZgWE40UVchWHlWA.review_text: After my 3rd time here, I'd say focus on the small plates and the specialty cocktails. Don't expect an intimate setting but some of the music (loud) is pretty great.  I love their presentation of the mango dessert and small plates. I'm def going back because for $104 I got 3 small plates, 3 cocktails, a dessert and a small, sweet Late Harvest Zinfandel! I felt stuffed!

0lDl1Jg1Qz2KhvkfJKk6fw.review_text: I'd been to the original location years ago and always remembered it fondly. When we drove by this location, I was wowed by the look of it. The exterior signage was inviting but the interior was even better. The welcoming hostess seated us, the server was friendly and knowledgeable. And the food. Fantastic. The portions were large. We went with the 3 course summer tasting menu and we would have been fine splitting it and maybe adding some naan and an appetizer. It's not inexpensive but it is highly recommended.

37HswRimgBEf7_US-c3CDA.review_text: Fall Menu Alert at Dosa on Fillmore!!  Coming here for a pre-Fillmore dinner & boy were the fates smiling on us!  It's Fall Harvest Tasting Menu time!!!!!
