Mr & I indulged in:  Kabocha Squash - the squash was a bit over-fried & greasy - maybe a tempura batter would have been better suited but nevertheless, it was still tasty!  Came with a spicy garlic tomato sauce as well as a sweet onion sauce - both were awesome.  Paired w/ a sparkling white & was a nice compliment to the heavy, fried squash  Pumpkin & Potato Dosa - tender potatoes schmeered w/ a wonderfully creamy pumpkin curry sauce & served w/ a spicy soup, spicy tomato sauce, MORE pumpkin sauce & a mild coconut - paired w/ a dry Riesling - really cut the spice & added a nice creamy flavor layer to the pumpkin.  This was my fav part of the whole meal - that pumpkin really shone & got an added boost form the tender fall-apart potatoes.  Yum!  Veggie Curry - just as delish as all the times before & packed a nice kick which was immediately tamed w/ their lovely yogurt.  White & purple potatoes paired w/ corn, green beans, peas & I'm sure a whole lot of other things....paired w/ a Malbec & this is where the pairing fell short - we thought the wine was too full & berry to go w/ the curry but 2 out of 3 were definite winners  After crying uncle & getting most of our main packed away, we decided to share dessert & got the Coconut Custard Cake.....wowsers!  Infused w/ curry leaves, this custard was more like a panna cotta - but hopefully there was no gelatin!  Tender, flan-like consistency w/ the chew of the coconut - this was pure awesomeness!  I like how they ask if you've been there before & will happily educate you about the dipping process or order suggestions - friendly crew, fab ambiance, delish food!

JUT0U3HTSB3kz9Wh7N0GqA.review_text: The tasting menu with wine parings is a healthy Dosa flavorful food!

GCuDiPUKYxhgFHP5LqJa2Q.review_text: 3.5 stars  No drafts, all bottled.  Complimentary chips of some kind, a bit salty for my taste but hubby liked it.  I didn't see the non alcoholic drink menu until after we ordered.  I would have liked to try their chai.  Sudwerk Lager - $6.5 Sam Smith organic apple cider - $10 - tasted like Martinelli, maybe a good way to start drinking sardine - $12 - 2 whole sardines fried w/ a bit of pickled veggie salad.   Rasam - $4 - spicy broth, lots of spices and flavors South Indian Moons - chef's choice of uttapam - $13.5 - there were 5 or 6 uttapam, that are like mini pancakes.  hubby said they are all a little different but they tasted the same.  There were 3 sauces - only wish the waiter or the person who brought the plate over could have told us what they were.  There was one large cup that was hot with a hint of curry and other Indian spices and two small cups of chutney/spread?  One is sweet with a very strong coconut flavor and the other was a bit more subdue with Indian spices.    May have a different experience if we came with someone who is more familiar with Southern Indian cuisine.   While tasty, walked away feeling a bit unfulfilled...and wanting some meat!

mPv2DJKprmUcndSi9QuURA.review_text: Excellent food, service, and atmosphere.  Just lovely! Make sure you book with time ahead, Plan your night at DOSA, and enjoy the best service in town. Absolutely amazing food, the service is five starts very patience people, very friendly hostess too. They will work all night to make sure you are having the best time. Absolutely want to try this place.

IZFFuUSa1LaumN7XQJkG4w.review_text: The restaurant has modern decor and furnishings. The ambiance is really great but unfortunately, I wasn't impressed with the food.  With all the hype surrounding this place, I was really excited to eat here but my expectations were not met.  However, I do really appreciate their effort in providing special dietary information about their menu. Being lactose intolerant, I usually avoid Indian restaurants since most of the usual dishes contain some sort of dairy product so it's really great that Dosa provides special dietary information so I know exactly what dishes are safe for me. They also try to use mostly all organic ingredients in their cooking which is a plus.  Paper Dosa ($11.5) -Huge and good dish to share with the table. A nice crispy crepe with tasty chutneys and sambar. Sambar was a bit too salty but the potatoes were delicious. Eat this dish when it freshly arrives because it became soggy once it got cold.   Pepper Chicken with coconut rice ($18) -The chicken and sauce was a bit too salty. The chicken was tender and juicy, and actually did "fall off the bone" as how the menu described it. The coconut rice had actual shredded coconut flakes in it and was delicious.  Mango Lassi ($5) -Smooth and creamy but a bit too tart.  The prices are reasonable. The ambiance and service is great. Parking is a bit difficult (street parking or nearby parking lots). Overall, a good dining experience but it wasn't spectacular as I had expected it to be.

PYzWU5txGNFQpBTsNu3pRA.review_text: A little baffled as to why these ratings are so high. I've had FAR better indian food than what I experienced at Dosa. Both the food and service was extremely lack luster. I went with a group of friends, really with the intention of just doing drinks and grabbing  a bite or two.   So naturally, we started at the bar, but then made our way to an actual table. We reviewed the menu, and since many of us weren't tryna order a huge meal, settled on some dosas to tide us over. the store manager was rude, rude, RUDE. He came over to take our order, and upon learning we just wanted some dosa's to go with our drinks, he kept trying to majorly upsell us. "how about the chicken dish?" "what are you, vegetarian?" "How about this?" "How about that?".... me: "How about we just order?". I've never felt so forced to buy something. Like... if I wanted the chicken... I would've ordered it without you breathing down my back. SO RUDE.  Definitely not coming back here. There's WAY better indian food elsewhere, especially in SF.

lWYikGsSiTMhGKvUcd1xjg.review_text: Upscale-y, bistro-y Indian that still has a soul. Dosa is as sophisticated as any place on Fillmore, it has a very lively, young bar scene and it has killer Indian food. Not a bad combo for a change of pace. If I had a nit it would be that it could be spicier, meaning hotter. The flavors were great, but I kind of expect duck vindaloo to light my head on fire. Dosa's tasted great, but there was no fire. Oh well.  The signature item, dosas, are really very nice and they come with wonderful dipping sauces. My wife and I said that next time we might just make our dinner several dosas and leave it at that.

PZqro4o591aDuKF6UliklQ.review_text: Excellent! one of my favorite restaurants in the city. Consistant quality & Nice wait staff

QuUb652DIcyWVlRh8Pb9wA.review_text: Great Place ! Definitely worth a try. It is a fancy place and is expensive but you won't regret spending money on good food. This is not a place you would eat every other day or every weekend. I was there two days ago.  We were 3 people and ordered their 3 course tasting menu. It was $42 per person, by the end of third course (small portions) we were full (right amount). I am used to eating lot if food so it was not enough for. Food was still great.

NR6Y46Ni2JjQcj4vDbqKUA.review_text: I've forgotten how much I love Dosa.  Went here for our company holiday dinner and just fell in love with this place all over again.  This was the first time that I got to try their special cocktails.  The only one I can remember is the PEONY.  I thought this would be a sweet drink (it was) but it's served with birds eye chili that gives it a spicy kick that I loved.  Has coconut milk in it so it's a thicker in texture but I definitely recommend this drink to anyone.  The other drinks I tried were whiskey or bourbon based and all very good also.    We ordered a bunch of small plates to start: CHUTNEY SAMPLER, FALL PORIYAL (brussel sprouts), CHENNAI CHICKEN, SAMOSAS, BHATURA, and probably a couple others I can't remember.  My favorites were the chicken and brussel sprouts.  The Bhatura was a good add since we ate it with our entrees too.  It's just a big puffed up bread that deflates when dug into.  I was indifferent to the other dishes.  Best part of the night though was the Lamb Chops entree I ordered.  SOOOOO GOOD I'm drooling as I type.  Incredibly tender and covered in a curry sauce that is SPICY.  I really wanted to keep eating but I was so full from the drinks & starters that I only finished half.  Took home the leftovers and ate it the next day and it was still just as good.  This beats everything I've ever eaten at Dosa.    Finished the dinner off with 3 desserts that I honestly can't really remember.  If you read my other reviews, I'm clearly not a dessert person so I could care less.  I do remember they were very pretty to look at though.  Our waiter was so nice and informative and made great suggestions so service was on par too!

Kb4prI_ulN4UCi8sZfVDoA.review_text: we got there just 2 minutes before the midnight. To our surprise, its kitchen was open yet. in our mind, it was too modern and fancy  to have a open kitchen that time.  we got one dosa (small but filling for me), two drinks and one dessert.   60$ , expensive but it is worth it. By the way, service was great

PjjxS9YFL8TwkyzEUH91-g.review_text: Bottom line at the top: 3 stars for food, rounded up to 4 for impeccable service. -- Came here with a(n Indian) friend who has been convincing me to try this place for so long.   After an exhausting day of shopping in the city I had no willpower to read through the incredibly long menu. So we went with the pre-fixe that had three options for each course (no dessert).  We had (the menu online isn't current so i can't really remember the last two dishes): chennai chicken, lamb kofta, broccolini dosa, spinach fennel and mustard greens dosa, another type of lamb, and cranberry chicken.  the chennai kofta was soo good but pretty spicy (at least to me, my spice tolerance is pretty low). this would turn out to be a recurring theme for the night so if you don't have a high spice tolerance i would maybe reconsider your options haha. the lamb kofta was way too spicy for me and also had a little bit of a weird texture.  i did not like the second course at all. there was a sauce that came with each dosa/uttapam that really did not sit with me. and the fillings inside both were kinda weird. i would recommend asking if you can get them to be served plain, with no sauce or fillings. they would be much better this way.  we were so absolutely full at this point so we took the last course to go. it was just okay. so overall i probably wouldn't recommend the pre-fixe.   i can't remember out waitresses name unfortunately but she was absolutely fantastic. she was very helpful in explaining stuff to me and definitely slowed down the pace for us since we were talking so much not really eating. the bus boys were very funny, polite, and attentative. they noticed that i'm a spice whimp so they were constantly coming by to offer more water.  the bar area was also super nice and it would definitely be cool to come by during happy hour. this place was absolutely packed on a monday night too!

3dcFnCZzBZrcKDeIYgiScw.review_text: Okay seriously, this place on the corner of Fillmore and Post has been calling my name for like over a year now and I've never gone in.....(as an Indian food lover, shame on me I know)  Finally came for lunch on a weekend and was REALLY impressed! Was able to be seated instantly at the bar area.  The interior is wonderful, bright lights, marble floors and a nice bar area for ordering drinks AND food.  The Indian food here is unique because it's not your typical curries and stews you would find at most Indian food places around. Here they serve Dosas and Uttapams which are like basically Indian savory crepes!  It was my first time eating it and I was sooo happy! Yum yum. We also got the Chennai Chicken (which is like an Indian version of Chinese popcorn chicken) and a Mango Lassi! Seriously, it was the CLASSIEST mango lassi I've ever had.....hands down.  Seriously, come here for classy Indian lunch/dinner that's out of your ordinary curries! You seriously won't be disappointed because the food is BOMB and reasonably priced! (For SF that is hahahaha)

z_idULm9m1ac7NDYEw4fSA.review_text: This is an upscale indian restaurant in SF. The place looks really cool when you enter inside. It has a full bar and there is no way you can imagine this place serves indian food. I have tried the watermelon, panner and moong salad, vada, uttappam and panner dosa. All of them were really very tasty. Dosa is served with two different types of chutneys: coconut and tomato chutney and also with Sambar.   Its an upscale and elegant place. I could call it a fine dining probably. The food is very expensive compared to the same quality of food in south bay. However, I think the price is only for the location. Something to try when you are in the SF area.

1A-geB-PQr1uveSFOS7Feg.review_text: Fantastic food.  This was our third time to the restaurant.  Our first was during Restaurant Week 2013.  Great three course meal with wine pairings - I'd recommend trying it out during Restaurant Week (f.k.a. "Dine About Town") if you have yet to try out this restaurant.  Our second time was shortly after that - we had been blown away by the quality of the food the first time, so my husband and I booked a date night at the location on Fillmore.  Once again, AMAZING experience.  This past time we went with another couple.  I think this was my favorite experience thus far, as we opted to do family style and ended up being able to try several different dishes.    Here's the items we tried:  Shredded Duck (5 stars) - spiciest of the dishes we tried (which I loved, as I'm a fan of spicy foods); the flavors were so well balanced and complex, pairs perfectly with the sauces (which helped tame down the spice).  Fresh Seafood Vada (4.5 stars) - so fresh and light, with a great kick of spice.    Chutney Sampler (4 stars) - All of the sauces were spectacular and full of flavor, with a range of spiciness.  All of them were great.  Sweet Potato Dosa (4.5 stars) - This was my favorite dosa of the evening.  The sweet potatoes were so soft and creamy, and I loved the ginger flavor.  Spicy Basil Dosa (3.5 stars) - This was in my opinion not as good as the sweet potato dosa.   Still good, just didn't have the same creaminess, and I preferred the flavor profile of the other dosa better.  Wish we would have gotten the white truffle dosa instead of this one, as we've had that before and it's fantastic.  Tamil Lamb (4.5 stars) - Such an excellent dish.  Once again, great flavors/spices, and the lamb was oh so tender.  Prawn Masala (5 stars) - The best dish of the night.  The coconut sauce was to die for, and the prawns were perfectly cooked.  And the coconut rice that came with it was excellent - went back for thirds on this dish ;)  My personal favorites were the shredded duck starter and the prawn masala.  But honestly, every single dish was fantastic.    A must go if you haven't been.  Can't wait to try out the DOSA on Valencia, which is a short walk from where I live.  The location on Valencia is more "cozy" and small whereas the one on Fillmore is more trendy and kind of an "experience."  Both have their own charm - just depends on what you're feeling more in the mood for :)

1SjayTzcMgOiy0iIUtwvHA.user_location: West San Jose, San Jose, CA
1SjayTzcMgOiy0iIUtwvHA.review_text: Absolutely love the place . Only place my husband loves South Indian food.   South Indian with twist...  Never though dahi wada could look like an art :)   Must try

b5hX-0dzjrHvtZfyUdIEtA.review_text: I have read some of the bad reviews of this place and they should be ignored on the basis of their ignorance of indian food and the intense labor required to prepare.   This is the first place I have been to where I felt the price matched the quality of the food. This is expensive, but where are you going to go and find a upscale restaurant with high-end decor that offers traditional south indian food that is healthy.   I frequent Darbar in Palo Alto and that restaurant pales in comparison to DOSA. I have never been to a South Indian, or any Indian restaurant that serves healthy meals and uses organic or locally sourced ingredients and free-range meats.   DOSA is by far the best south indian restaurants I have visited because of how they prepare their dishes. Most places you go, the dosas are beyond greasy, the "masala" (spiced potato filling) is either bland or too spicy and lacks in complexity of flavors. DOSA makes their masala dosa's with your health in mind. The dosa I received was amazing, the filling was delicious and the chutney served along side the sambar was amazing.   Once thing to note: the sambar is super spicy, however, this is to be expected with south indian food. I had two bowls of it and wanted more, but my tongue was already on fire. This is not the restaurants fault, this is traditional south indian cooking at its finest. the only negative was that the sambar was a little heavy on the tamarind, though I didn't complain as I loved the gorgeous color.    We also ordered the Kale Pakora (we ordered two rounds of it) and that was equally amazing.   The couple who started this restaurant knows what they are doing and understands their clientele. They know that San Franciscans appreciate fine dining and healthy cuisine. San Franciscans have a plethora of ethnic dining options and will frequent those that use ingredients found at DOSA.

gerYEXDvopZYkXph3Yv_sA.review_text: I've been to Dosa now twice and it was fantastic both times. The staff is on point - very friendly and responsive. This place is a bit pricier, but it's honestly so worth the cost. It's not one of those places that charges $10 more for a burger just because they can. The food, decor and cocktails are noticeably high quality and delicious. It's for sure some of the best Indian food I've had.   Try the Mango Prawns (great sweet spicy combo) and any of the Dosas. The cocktails are also a huge bonus of dining at Dosa. Each one is completely original and delicious. My favorite is the Peony - a lavender and coconut milk flavored concoction. I've never had Indian dessert that I like except at Dosa - the gelatos are perfection. If you're brave, they even suggest forgoing silverware and going the traditional route of eating with your hands.   This is a prime date or special event spot. It's located right across the street from Sundance Kabuki Cinemas - my favorite theater in SF and a great spot to round out a traditional dinner and a movie date.

TWcqLHYI4xRWlodtNZvoHQ.review_text: Great Service, good yet niched flavors.  Not the same kind of indian food flavors you are used to seeing in your everyday buffet.

fL7pZpYTmIUrHgi1vWuhKg.review_text: This is my FAVORITE Indian place of all time! I am a huge fan of dosas!  Had the Paneer and Peas dosa, Uttapam sampler, and Spicy Basil dosa.   A dosa is kind of like a thin crepe filled with delicious goodness. My favorite is the Spicy Basil, and I've eaten it two days in a row. I love the sauces that come with the entrees, and dosas feel a lot lighter than your typical Indian food (e.g. butter chicken, lamb vindaloo, etc).

4wp4XI9AxKNqJima-xahlg.review_text: I'm not too familiar with Indian food at all. I'm not opposed to it (even after an ill fated try years ago), I just haven't sought it out. But with the crew heading here, I was happy to give it a try again.  I love a good tasting menu, so I was happy to see one. Especially being unfamiliar with the food, it was nice to try a bit of everything. I ordered the chicories and Asian pear salad, the sweet potato dosa and the hyderabadi lamb.   The salad was okay, but not mind blowing. Although I could have eaten a whole bowl of the fried goat cheese balls they had in it! The sweet potatoes dosa was good. I know that this dish is supposed to be a lot of dough and a little bit of the main "stuffing" but I wanted a little bit more potatoes!   The lamb was awesome though! It was probably the right amount for a main dish, but it was so good I wanted more! And it came in this dish with a bunch of thick sauce. It just made me want more lamb! It was also so tender. I just love lamb, and they did this right!  A fresh modern atmosphere and great service made it a fantastic evening to catch up with coworkers!

us8qvqWWJWp4ihALNS1DLg.review_text: My favorite restaurant in SF.  I usually make a visit about 2-3 times a month.  They have the perfect equation for a restaurant:  great food + great cocktail + Great service with a dash of a colorful ambience and great decorations.    My fav dishes are:  Vada pavs (the best indian sliders in america), the Chile Uttapam (be careful, you will feel it the next day); the chana butura is good, not great; and of course the dosa's are very good.  A hidden treat are the idlli fries..  Basically, cant go wrong here with anything.

lX89A57ZsdTGx2BXaVLlYQ.review_text: I usually follow the Spice Route to Dosa Valencia, but Dosa Fillmore is a good place to alight, much like the Cape of Good Hope. Liquor=good hope.  Spice Route cocktails feature some new world wonders-lime, curried nectar, allspice, mango juice, jackfruit! After one cocktail, you'll need the feast to come.  While variety may be the spice of life, the paper masala dosa is the bread and butter of Dosa-sans butter. I love how it looms menacingly off of the plate, and with each bite of crispy dosa, potato, lentil, and cashew it becomes somewhat more contained. Usually I'm full by the time it reaches the confines of the plate, but I keep on going because it is part of the journey.  To ensure that you have adequate provisions for the voyage ahead, you must order the South Indian Moons uttapam-five savory pancakes selected by the chef, accompanied by chutneys and sambar.  I've veered off my beaten path on a few occasions. The Hyderabadi Chicken Biryani is a basmati rice bowl of tender chicken with Indian aromatics, and the masala dosa is a triangular pocket of potatoes, onions, and cashews. Both worthy excursions from the uttapam-paper masala route that I've carved out for myself.  Even though Dosa Valenica is obtaining a liquor license soon, I think I'll voyage here more often. The interior is so beautiful, the space so expansive, and the location perfect for a pre or post-Kabuki theater meal.

lFdcgrMkHCmvTjMEw4CVDQ.review_text: OMG how did I not come here sooner?? I guess because when I'm hungry, I don't pick Indian food as my first choice. I came here for lunch last weekend and immediately fell in love.   Complimentary lentil chips as you sit down and endless chutneys, veggie options and dosas galore. I tried the Masala Dosa and it was big enough to share among three people but the bf and I stuffed ourselves to finish it. We also had a little of the Paneer (not dosa but the thicker pancake kind) and that was good too. Since it's a thicker bread, it was more filling so we didn't end up finishing it. We also tasted these onion pieces dipped in a chickpea batter (forget the name, hehe) and they were reminiscent of the Awesome Blossom/Blooming Onion at Chili's and Outback.   Service was outstanding and the servers were very hospitable. Very prompt  on food, checking in on us and refilling our water. Will be coming back again soon!

nTi9KaRnpNIpJ9CIiC4E8A.review_text: I go here twice a month on average and it is consistently good. The free pappadams at the beginning of the meal are a nice touch and are delicious. The location on Valencia does not seem to offer these. Their masala dosa and accompanying sauces are divine. It is certainly enough for a meal, which is a bargain at $11. They are also vegan-friendly. Just make sure you ask them to leave off the ghee. Again, we found that the location on Valencia is less able to make vegan-friendly adaptations to the menu because they pre-cook some ingredients in butter.   Additionally, the cocktails are delicious. I like to order a gimlet when I go. With the swanky atmosphere and attentive service, I am compelled to leave five stars. I would probably give the location on Valencia three stars.  One tip: you almost always need a reservation, even on a weeknight. Otherwise, expect to sit at an overcrowded communal table or the bar. Overall, a great restaurant worth visiting!

rP1JhMcc7sZTzW3KzLpL9w.review_text: What a unique "little" place..  Feels like a tea house during the day and lounge at night. Decor is elegant without being too ZGallerie Service is friendly without being overbearing The menu is a bit overwhelming because everything looks good, so let the waiter surprise you or check out their site ahead.  We had the uttapams and dosas, which were really tasty You can definitely taste the southern-Indian spices in them! I appreciated how light they both were, but maybe a tad too light, as I definitely needed additional food to go with them.. The desserts at the tables around us looked delicious, but we passed them as my girl friend was craving taiyaki across the street.  No complaints at all about this place, solid 4 stars!

_tYdp-NhWaKnwYveFE2JnA.review_text: I LOVE DOSA. Their cocktails are amazing as is their food, though you should be forewarned that it is very spicy (says the white girl)!   The -1 star is for the price, you could easily spend $75pp for a nice dinner here.  Try the Emerald monk cocktail--it has chile agave and is awesome!

lppPzNz4eXAI21CFofE6mg.review_text: This was our first visit to Dosa. We were delighted. Our waiter walked us through the menu and made helpful suggestions. The food was great. It was a very enjoyable evening. We'll definitely be back.

tPbm5JALK1xVnCWIbqCwBA.review_text: Food is fine but overpriced. (I prefer Udipi Palace at half the price. But I do not go here for the food...)  Beautiful decor. Lovely presentation of food. Excellent "Peony" cocktail.

VhEm35lO3z6ID90Z2t0xEg.review_text: The menu is not the standard northern Indian fare that I'm used to but the waitress did a great job explaining and recommending dishes. Everything was delicious and presentation was excellent. This is definitely not your average Indian restaurant.

egfZwiPKothb9-kL6r7L0g.review_text: UNREAL. Maybe one of the best dining experiences I've had. The cocktails are amazing. Some of the best I've had. The Peony was the best gin drink I've had. The Hideaway was a great spicy cocktail Seeing the mezcal mist was pretty cool. The food is fantastic, not your traditional Indian food. Our waiter was patient and helpful guiding us through. We tried many of the small plates and also the White Truffle Dosa, which was good, but I'd stick strictly to small plates next time. I will defintely be back.

E0hnzH2Kx50pYjIOhMxfuA.review_text: Pros Holy Flavortopia! Gorgeous ambiance (great date spot)  Recommend: Kale Pakora, Masala, any of the Uttapam! Gin and Tonic was amazing, Peony was good but really sweet  Cons Expensive but well worth it  Overall Thoughts  Wow, just wow....

17NeiWyqirN9okmfgczP2Q.review_text: I've never really been a huge fan of Indian food in general, but came here with some out of towners for dinner.  We came with an Indian guy who seemed to know his food, so we let him handle the order... We had the South Indian Bhel Puri, Channa Bhatura, Tamil Lamb, Chile-Cilantro Fish and some Dosa on the side... Plenty of food for 4.  My favorites were the Bhel Puri and Channa Bhatura... The Tamil Lamb was also good (I'm usually turned away from lamb due to gamey-ness), and the Chile Cilantro Fish was tasty... Overall a good mix of different flavors.  I'd say this would be a good date night spot for some classy Indian food if you don't mind dropping a few dollars... Drinks were a bit on the pricey side, but they were good... I'll probably find my way back here again in the future if I feel like having Indian.

gkjkDvLv4fsMP8b6-Z1d1g.review_text: What a great find!! Walking around japan town on a Saturday and found this beautiful restaurant for lunch. Had heard great things so thought we would try it. Walked in at 1pm on a Saturday and were greeted by great bollywood music, a grandly decorated interior, and a friendly hostess. Got a table for two immediately.  Place is full of couples, families, and professionals. Hence great place for everyone. Big bar and great seating.  We had a wonderful waiter who took great care of us. Now let's discuss food:  - chennai chicken is so delicious! Crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Great pairing with the raita  - spicy basil dosa was great. Perfectly seasoned, huge portion. Highly recommended.  - lunch chicken thai was okay. Can subsitute one vegeterian plate with chicken but I didn't like the chicken dish. Some vegetarians options were not yummy but dal was amazing (probably best I've had) and the plain dosa was delicious and soft. The ras malai was great too. I wouldn't get the thali again because the other options on the menu look amazing.  - finished with the chai chocolate pot de creme and it was amazing!! Comes with three shortbread biscuits that were most delicious biscuits I have had. Creme was light and perfect.  Overall great place for good indian food (and I'm indian so that's saying a lot)

xyDdIB6hC0U5Gr92UHZxDw.review_text: A very nice upscale South Indian restaurant offering a variety of Dosas. We tried the Uttapam platter, Paneer Dosa, Medu Vada and the Mimmosa. The uttapam platter and paneer dosa was really very good. Found the Medu Vada to be decent.  I would recommend to make reservations at this place.

ZJofh3rrsXQYnz35CYOYSg.review_text: Jazzy, spirited, upscale South Indian dining.   Dim lights, soft tones, gorgeous lighting and chandeliers with jazz melodies playing in the background. That''s Dosa. We heard we had to go here so we listened, we cabbed it, we conquered.   Anxious to get started on some dosas, we skipped appetizers and dove right in to ordering our entrees. One thing I will say, the complimentary papadum served as we waited was perfectly crisp and I filled up a little bit too much on that alone. Delicious though -- some of the best papadum I've had.  My hubby and a friend indulged in some spicy cocktails and were definitely quite pleased.  Once our food arrived I knew I was going to like it.  I could smell the white truffle oil before the plate even reached me. I admit, my previous experiences with having dosa were all very traditional versions so I was very jazzed about the white truffle twist.  So yes, I loved.  My husband devoured his meal and as I watched the beads of sweat roll down the sides of his face, at the end of his cleaned plate, all he could talk about was the sambar he just had. Although it had a no-joke kick to it, he wanted more of it.    I highly recommend Dosa on Fillmore to anyone interested in having delicious South Indian food with a twist.    Dining in a fine establishment like this was a definite treat from the crappy, dingy and hit-or-miss Indian restaurants you'll find in Seattle - what a shame because we need something like this here!

beXFex7IBc8CpKctRk7Y4A.review_text: Not that Dosa needs another review. It is sublime. I had the summer tasting menu - corn soup, paneer dosa and vegetable curry. Accompanied by the kickin ginger beer soda and followed by the delicious mango pudding.   My only very minor issues was that the tapioca pearls at the bottom of the mango pudding weren't chewy and soft. I ate them any way and would have licked the glass it came in.   Our server was patient, attentive and helpful.   I wish we had more people to watch our kids so we could go back this trip.

O2WfOgwdSxIl-4UkqY88dA.review_text: Oh my goodness. This place is just delicious. And the atmosphere and vibe are awesome as well.  Dropped in after confirming over the phone that there was no wait for the community table. Everyone from the hostess to the bus servers were extremely nice and helpful with suggestions. Got to try my first DOSA and was shocked at the size and how much I loved it!  I can't believe i went this long without trying Dosa before!

f81Y2EzuRqefayCrL1Ra3Q.review_text: Dosa is good.  From its decor to the attentive service to the well put-together meals.  It might be me who does not enjoy Indian curry as the next person but I didn't think the food at Dosa was on hit.  Service was attentive, cute place to bring a date and food was attractive. I wish I had more of a liking for the food but I felt at its price, it could've been spicier and it should have brought me that  certain je nei sais quoi.  Regardless, you should come if you have a date planned or are looking for a fancier dinner. Right now, I might shy away from it unless someone wants to pay for my meal :)

Xw5USoG-KvYxxr5fxDbfkQ.review_text: Great food! Waiter was attentive and made good suggestions along the way. (Mike) asked him for both drink recommendations and food. Chicken korma was rich and delicious.  Scallop appetizer was great as was lamb and vegetable dishes. Restaurant has a bustle and is a bit noisy, but not too much so. No naan bread on the menu but the alternative is good and the rice was excellent. I don't think you can go wrong here.

6UBIQnUXxKyNXTFXkTW46Q.review_text: Dosa was burnt and served cold again. This place is going downhill. For the 3rd consecutive time I had to send the Dosa back. Also too much butter in the dosa. Bad news!! Do not  visit this place!!!

WVljAjviZwY4Y3oYC1Qw_Q.review_text: This is the classiest Indian restaurant I've been to. On first impression, I loved the interior, amazing lights, and the overall upscale scene. Remember to make a reservation, no matter how big your party! It got really crowded by 7pm on Friday night.  Drinks were pretty good. The others enjoyed their cocktails, while my monsoon was interesting at best - I did not like chucks of ginger going up the straw and the taste was too savory for me, not refreshing enough. Our nice waitress gave us advice on how many plates to share amongst the 4 of us. We split 2 appetizers and 3 dosas.  - Chennai chicken was delicious as everyone has pointed out. The only meat we had for the meal. Large portion too, great for sharing. - North/south samosas were decent, but not exactly worth the $9 for just two. - Dosas ($12-13) - white truffle, paper masala, and basil - each were humongous and the stuffing in the truffle and basil was not spread out enough. The edges of the dosas were basically just the crepe. As soon as we hit the middle, it tasted amazing though. None of them were bad. Overall table consensus was for the paper masala, enjoyed with the different dipping sauces.  Those dishes plus a few rounds of drinks came to about $40 per person with taxes. Not extremely bad for a classy dinner and an adventure trying new things. But for the everyday takeout of tikka masala and rice, go to a more affordable Indian joint.

tGvvuwLa-yGrLYKdarVVcA.review_text: Service and Food were great. I totally recommend the tasting menu if you have a large party. You get to taste everything on there. I love the shrimp and lamb, it was spicy. Lighting needs to be alittle more brighter so i can see the menu instead of using my flash light on the phone.

Syt_iQqW_c9T2_lrvsddqQ.review_text: Only 4 stars as we didn't experience the full on dining experience (altho we look forward to returning for that) in this beautiful space.  But wow! ...we stopped in for Happy Hour on a summer Wednesday evening to find it relaxed and quiet, the drinks cheap and the limited bar menu amazingly delicious. I could have eaten 20 servings of the Vegetarian Sliders.

fXKRTax3LU5mLat_-Z13zQ.review_text: We came here for the first time in a whim when deciding SF Restaurant Week spots to hit up. RW just started a day ago and we were in Jtown. Perfect.  We sat down expecting to order from the RW menu, but we did not. It was $85 per person for 4 courses each. We ended up ordering 4 plates ala carte and walked out with food left over for $85 total.  The samosas (chicken and potatoes) were great. Probably the best I've ever had. The chicken filling was especially flavorful. The lamb keema dosa was also memorable. The dosa was crispy and light. Perfectly paired with the lamb.  The fiancée was also feeling adventurous and ordered the chili uttapam. It's got Serranos, jalapeños, habaneros and Thai chilis. It was extremely spicy for me, but the heat and the flavor just left me going back for more. Make sure you get your water refilled often! The green coconut chutney helped cool it down as well.  My disappointment of the night was this chicken dish under the curry menu. Chicken chennai I think? The curry it came in was more like a gravy. Obvious cinnamon taste, but it's salty. My first impression was literally WTF. Salty, creamy, cinnamon-y taste. I did not have more than 2 bites of the uttapam that I dipped in this.  Extra points for accepting apple pay through open table!

4c2RYnS2mdDSMwyY9xWBaQ.review_text: Awesome Indian food...what else can I say?  The ambiance is perfect for a date or an intimate get together. The noise level isn't too quiet but it's not loud like a bar either...perfect loungy atmosphere.  Ordered three dishes and shared them family style: chicken biryani, some lamb kofta and mango prawns. All were amazing. Coconut rice to go with the dishes and bhatura which I didn't know about but was an amazing bread dish. Drank a mango lassi and some type of beer/cider to wash it down. Ended on a perfect note with a dark chocolate cake.  Most Indian places are either 1. hole in the wall and good, 2. shady and gross, 3. a street cart or 4. Naan and Curry. It was nice to see an upscale Indian restaurant for a change (kind of like Typhoon in San Diego but even nicer). Definitely better than Gaylord.  The prices are a little on the higher side but you are paying for the ambiance. I think the quality of the food is also better but only marginally than some other good hole in the wall places (I'm thinking Chutneys here). Probably wouldn't come back regularly but definitely if I'm in the mood for some good Indian food and don't wanna make it down to the Tenderloin, will probably hit it up here.

TV5KN43yjxKNylOkH1u1Pw.review_text: Really fun restaurant. Amazing food and great service. I've been a twice, both times were birthday dinners and it was the perfect place to celebrate. The waiters and waitress are also very helpful with the menu items and recommending dishes. For sure going back.

Fy3GU-WH7tNCn6BW8Ir41Q.review_text: Had valentine evening dinner here.  Good ambiance. Tables are too close to each other, you are paranoid that you accidentally don't start eating from your neighbors plate :) .   Food was ok, just too much hype. Appetizers are very very expensive with very small serving size (samosa's and bhel). Chili garlic dosa was ok, not great.   Will not go back.

9_CkxKmxAcEToovYgf9vow.review_text: I had the truffle dosa and it was delicious! The fusion of Italian and Indian ingredients made my experience super interesting and keeps me wanting to try more on the menu. Oh also, the dosa's are gluten-free which is convenient.   The dim lighting and soft music makes for a romantic evening. The food was great, our server was nice. I will definitely come back!

YnCQKWg25d9S1a6sUObnqQ.review_text: Great south Indian food. The Dosas were a bit spicy but everything else was great! Very very busy on a Saturday night, and service was a bit slow. Our app came out before our drinks. Overall very good though!

xJafm7vGSkUI5ocgYkCWkA.review_text: Ok so I have to admit of all the food that I love Indian food has never been my favorite.  Time and time again my Indian food loving friends have tried to convince me I just haven't been to the right places. Well then somebody take me there dammit!  That is exactly what happened tonight.  Yes I'm in San Fran and there are thousands of Indian restaurants to choose from lucky for me I had some locals who knew the area well.  Remember at the beginning of this review how I said I didn't love Indian food?  Tonight was the night that I fell in love with Indian food.  It turns out I just really needed to experience Indian food the right way.    Now I realize Dosa is more of a high end Indian restaurant.  The restaurant was beautifully decorated, two floors of amazing dining area with a modern look. The food was top notch and yes as a recommendation and well the name of the restaurant was Dosa after all so I went for the roasted chile and garlic masala dosa.    So what is a dosa?  The menu describes it as a rice and lentil crepe.   When it was served it was a large triangle crepe (it was huge) literally falling off the plate served with sambar, coconut and tomato chutneys.  The servers were all very educated on the menu and super helpful when it came to how to eat the food.  For an Indian food newbie I appreciate any help I can get.  The food was outstanding I ate every bite of my Dosa it was simple, spicy, and delicious. This will be a meal I won't ever forget.  Did I mention my cocktail? The "peony?"  There was quite a selection of specialty cocktails to choose from, almost all included ingredients made in house.   The peony was nothing like I had before, gin with hibiscus masala nectar, coconut milk, lime, and birds eye chili.  The drink was a pretty purple concoction, creamy, spicy and served up in a martini glass, my kind of drink for sure.  I highly recommend checking this place out, the fact that I will make sure to visit here next time I'm in San Fran says a lot because we all know this city has a ton of options when it comes to food.  This non-Indian food lover has been converted.

kxChgiW1RtaMGYkoriqQ9g.review_text: I am not the biggest fan of curry but I really liked it here.  The food was really lovely and not sloppy at all!  I did book way in advance though for Valentine's Day and got seated rather disappointingly in the bar area.  I think it would have been much better to have been part of the restaurant opposite or upstairs.

LlZhpU7q-93Sx12rFv_E2Q.review_text: Beautiful restaurant, spacious interior, nice atmosphere.  I'm mixed on the food.  Everything starts out good, flavors are bold and distinct, but depending on what you order, everything starts to tasting similar.  I guess I come away feeling like it was a "one-note" dinner, rather than variety and intrigue.

l77MWiqsIw6vPizKUj-8aA.review_text: IMHO the best Indian food in SF. Its South Indian so for an Indian like me its hard to compare this against your generic North Indian restaurant. But if I had to choose, Dosa trumps the competition.   The food is flavorful, clean tasting and true to its roots. You will find South Indian standards here beyond the eponymous Dosa that you would be hard pressed to find in most cities anywhere in the US. You can tell that the ingredients are fresh and carefully chosen. The service is good and the ambiance is pleasant.   Not much more you can ask for. Go and try for yourself

WlY8gDPTYqKB_VzRTASjOw.review_text: Seriously always delicious!  The food is so good, the quality is amazing, the atmosphere is fantastic, as is the service.  You should definitely make a reservation but if you have time to kill, you can wait at the bar for your table.  It is totally vegetarian friendly, and just delicious!  Love.  It is pricey but you get what you pay for--so that is a deal! It is great for a romantic date--the Kubuki Theatre is across the street, go for dinner and a movie--bingo!  It would also be good for work dinners or whatever!  Just go, it's yummy and lovely.

5iJcfluUjqxbEaQelZctIQ.review_text: Eating here left me really confused. I was baffled because it was a miss on all levels - the food was not authentic, nor did it do a good job of bringing in a fusion element to the different items. In my opinion, everything I tasted just fell flat - no flavor, no element of surprise, no nothing, FLAT.  I'm a South Indian. I know the food. I ordered a pesarattu or the Spicy Mung Masala. What I got was not really a pesarattu, I make better pesarattu and I won't even pretend to be a good cook. Others on my table ordered:  Paneer & Spinach dosa -  marginally better than everything else that we ordered, but still not on par with dosa I've had in other bay area establishments.   Okra Kolambu - no flavor, I was hoping for a nice coconut kick to the whole dish, but apparently it was too much to expect  Persimmons & Iddiapam - we were warned that the dish was sweet, but we were intrigued by the usage of persimmons in an iddiapam preparation and wanted to try it out. Will not make the mistake again!  Overall, it was a very disappointing, uninspired and expensive meal ($73 + tax for 2 entrees and a drink, per couple). I don't think I'll ever go back. And I don't know how this place has such great ratings, especially when there are so many more great South Indian restaurants in the area *facepalm*

lLfcbYGTeVxQN5Ig0ompJg.review_text: A gf and I stopped by in June of last year for Dine about town (DAT) but ended up ordering everything a la carte. I wanted to try a bunch of things so we decided maybe a la carte was the better choice. I love the standard chicken tikka masala, but I'm not very versed in Indian cuisine. We discussed various dishes with our server and ended up ordering the following:  -Chennai chicken ($11) - Yum! Crispy, moist and tender!  -Dahi vada ($10) - I wasn't sure what to expect from this, but it was a nice contrast to heavier and spicier dishes. Cool and refreshing.  -Lamb kofta ($15) - I love lamb! And in meatball form?! How could I say no! -Duck vindaloo with side of Lemon rice ($24) - I love duck! But since it's a fatty bird, I found the sauce a little too oily. The lemon rice went great with it though!  -Uttapam: Mixed chile ($11) - So I ordered a dosa but ended up with a uttapam. If I had realized this at the restaurant, I probably would have said something. But I didn't find out until I got home. I did enjoy this though! Nice and spicy!   Given that this restaurant is called Dosa, I really wanted to try a dosa! But since I'm not super familiar with Indian food, I didn't know what we got wasn't what I ordered. I still enjoyed the dishes regardless. This just means the gotta come back for their namesake dish!

Qw4QuhsDUA_955AcgpasEg.review_text: Although I love the dosa on mission. This one doesn't match up. Other than the fact they don't have the mango habernaro dosa, their service has been dissapointing both times I was there. Food has a wierd greasy ghee like aftertaste and the servers need to be more alert while taking orders.

8xZeyRBqo7ubQJ9wWycBJw.review_text: Love this place! The sliders, the cocktails, and truffle dosas are truly one of a kind. The curries are decent, but slightly overpriced for what you get. The pappadum appetizers pre-dinner are also great and highly addicting. I've already been twice and can't wait to go back again to try some more small plates, the chicken biryani, and the different dosas.

KEwcug_FL4lUy2SsmdLQ6A.review_text: Great quality food! Tried the vada pav- 5/5 for creativity and taste. Also had the truffle dosa- was great and impressive. The truffle oil could be a little heavy later as regular dosa eaters like me r new to truffle oil with dosa. I am going to try this dosa at home :) only suggestion would be to serve indian pickles with curd rice. Our curd rice had no pickles, that's like a pizza with no cheese :(  Overall A Fab Place And Is My Absolute favorite place

skar1XyXyjTKKUawy-NlyA.review_text: This place was great!  It's much more spacious, and we didn't have to wait on a weekend evening, which was great since we walked in one hour before our movie at Kabuki!  Compared to the Valencia location, parking is better, and there is a much larger waiting area (at Valencia, it's super cramped at the bar and it's hard not to feel like you're sticking your behind into someone's meal next to you).  Service was great too!  We sat at the communal table and got quick service.  Ordered the sweet potato dosa and my friend ordered a spicy chile and garlic dosa.  Both of us devoured them.

eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg.review_text: 4.5 STARS I don't eat Indian food as much as I want to. Why? 1. Hot flashes. 2. Bubble guts. 3. Poopy poops. Sadly, my body and muffin top just doesn't agree with the bold and fiery spices. Knowing that we were going to Dosa, I came armored with my pink bff. You know how it is, the older you get, the more you become a walking CVS. Lactaid, tums, pepto, beano, aleve, benadryl, dramamine, emergen-c, etc. I even have preparation h. Puffy eyes, begone! Having been to Dosa on Valencia, I already knew what to expect: trendy and full bar. Of course, the latter being the most important. This Dosa location is massive with two levels making it a perfect place for dates and/or large parties. I'm no South Indian food aficionado so I can't speak for the authenticity but I will say, I didn't have the sweats or skid marks during/after (like I usually do from the spices). Not to say, the food was bland because it wasn't, it was flavorful without assaulting the tastebuds with spices and heat. It's pricey though for Indian food (we spent $80 pp including one cocktail) but the quality is top-notch with service to match. Do start dinner with one of their unique, Indian inspired cocktails. Kinda pricey at $13 a pop but where in the hell will you find a cocktail with housemade hibiscus masala necter, coconut milk and birds eye chile? Um, no where. The creamy Peony (gin based) cocktail was damn delicious and stiff: bit.ly/1BKakyU so I recommend this one. Our group of 8 decided to order several apps to share and then go with the 3-course tasting menu for $42 (yah we eat a lot). This definitely the way to go as the average price of entrees was $26. They don't skimp on the portions either; the girls left with doggybags. For our shared apps, we ordered the Bhatura ($5), a gigantic fried puffy wheat bread: bit.ly/1to5x2j and the White Truffle Masala Dosa ($13.50): bit.ly/1q12snB. Both are must trys! The Bhatura was crispy, soft, and airy; great for dipping with the chutneys. Not authentic by any means, the White Truffle Masala Dosa was filled with mash potatoes: bit.ly/1muFQqP and had a great earthy flavor. For the tasting menu, I started with the Kale Pakora: bit.ly/XFmlGt which is kale dipped in a chickpea batter and then deep fried. It was a little too heavy for me so I shared it with our group. For my second course, I choose the Lamb Keema Dosa: bit.ly/1l0NhKY. I really enjoyed this course; kinda like a deconstructed crepe. The paper thin dosa was super light and crunchy. Tear off a piece, top it with the ground lamb, and enjoy. The tomato chutney added heat while the green coconut chutney helped cool things down. Having had the Prawn Masala at their Valencia location, I knew this was going to be my third course. It was as delicious as I remembered it. The four large prawns were meaty and sweet. Loved the delightfully creamy masala sauce that was robust and spicy but not overly so. They made for great leftovers since the spices developed more overnight. The Indian fusion desserts looked too enticing to pass up so we ordered the White Chocolate & Turmeric Pot de Crème ($9): bit.ly/1l0QiLo and the Fresh Coconut Custard Cake w/ infused curry leaves & coconut cookie ($8): bit.ly/1tsqJ6o to share. I can't comment on the pot de crème since someone hoarded the entire thing to himself. Hmmph. The coconut custard cake had a flan like texture. It had good coconut flavor but I wish the bottom crust was crunchier. Service was phenomenal (so rounding up my rating). Our super sweet waitress, Ilem and the busboys rocked! Usually with large parties, service sucks donkey balls. However, not at Dosa. They were very attentive, quickly cleared out empty plates, kept our water glasses filled, and food came out very timely. When it came to packing our leftovers, they put the rice, masala and raita in different containers. The ocd in me thanks you! As I mentioned earlier, Dosa is a very trendy place. The upscale décor is stunning and the amber and red color scheme is inviting. If you want to impress a girl (or guy) with something l-o-n-g, this is THE place to bring her. I'm talking about the dosa here, you pervs! ;)

CQ8OSQFPCCoo0ujxEyEVRA.review_text: 4.5 stars  Now this is yelp, the thank you economy, and pure customer service done right. The owner reached out to me regarding my A-OK review and welcomed me to come back and try a few appetizers on him. I literally live 4 blocks away so my roommates and I stopped by here on Tuesday night for dinner.  Their dinner offerings were excellent. All the items provide very generous servings and they definitely kicked up the spice a notch with these dishes. We got the following:  Chaat -- Mangos in chaat? Who would have thought. Apparently this is a South Indian norm to put fruit in chaat and I don't know why us Northerners haven't picked up on how good that is. Dahi Vada -- Amazing presentation and great taste. They really know how to take Indian street food and make it classy Pakora -- To be fair, I'm not a fan of these generally so I have a bit of a bias against this dish. Clever take on the chutneys mimicking ketchup and mustard.  Paper Masala Dosa -- Solid traditional dosa dish. Ask for extra of the orange chutney. Nom. Basil Dosa -- 3/4 of us are Indian and have grown up with all this goodness. This dosa made all of us take a step back and admire how they made this. It's like pesto meets masala. Very good. Channa Batura -- Seriously, the batura was bigger than my head. INSANE. The channa was excellent. The batura was definitely a little oily for my liking but that tends to happen when its deep fried.  Needless to say, I definitely had my mind changed and cannot wait to make this a neighborhood regular. Cheers to your restaurant, Anjan.

E8dFifVN6_CdDxJeJZgOYg.review_text: The food is great. I love their Chana batura. Unfortunately the service is not as good. We wanted to have a table and were told that we have to wait for two hours. After half an hour we got a text that our table is ready so we went back only to find out that no table is ready and that we should wait another 2 hours. We were promised a text message when the table is ready which never came. Ended up eating somewhere else.

pHGvulAeyC5SFOMfE-h4eg.review_text: Never has dosa before so it was fun trying some. They were good but we weren't blown away.   20 or so per person without drinks

PClMJ-_57E2G_Xql-amqfA.review_text: Worst restaurant experience in a long time. Went to Dosa for dinner on a Tuesday night. The restaurant was 60% empty. So we were seated immediately. The slap in the face was that the waitstaff there enjoying themselves and never had the decency to cater to their customers. We are locals, and I can't say I have ever been treated so poorly. These people have such a bad attitude. We chose to leave before we "inconvenienced" anyone to pay an ounce of attention. IMO the only thing Indian about this restaurant is their rude waitstaff.  From a previous experience, everything here was too salty, but entrées were over the top salty and otherwise over seasoned and cooked for the wrong amount of time. Without the hype, I think their food still deserves 2 stars but because I hate hyped up places that can't deliver to the amped up expectations, and with a complete lack of customer service, Dosa's only receiving a single star, and that's only because Yelp wouldn't let me do anything less.

pszTatGBYGPbRYbSFXkauQ.review_text: Brought here by some friends of mine and I have to say that the ambience here is great.  Loved the music that they were playing at the time and it felt like a pretty posh place overall.  We came in on a Friday evening around 9pm and found it solidly packed, which attests to its popularity.  We were seated after 45 minutes and I ended up ordering the Chennai chicken and the lamb dosa.  The Chennai chicken was tasty and came out in a fairly large sized portion for a small plate.  The chicken was fried and had a slight spiciness to it that gave it a nice little kick.  It came with a side of yogurt sauce, raw onions, and a lemon that added some nice additional flavor to the dish.  I thought it was a solid appetizer.  The lamb dosa was ok and not anything amazing.  It came out with a bowl of sambar, cup of coconut chutney, cup of tomato chutney, and a bowl of lamb.  The dosa was perfectly made, but the sambar and chutneys were not particularly flavorful / spicy and the lamb had the taste and consistency of a bowl of chili.  I was not impressed by the dish and it may be that I should've ordered another dosa.  Overall, I really liked the environment of this place and would come here to lounge at the bar, but I wasn't particularly impressed by the food.  I found it very overpriced for the quality of what you received... but then I've never thought of dosas capable of being fancy.

iDVtNw1D1OFzJ08jHiO3XA.review_text: Surprisingly authentic South Indian food.  The ambience and the crowd makes it seem like a sellout restaurant catering towards white yuppies. I was proven wrong.   Had some great dishes here.

IcdxwCBX6rNHwlcFJEVVtQ.review_text: While the food and drink at Dosa are amazing, these five stars really belong to our server. I can only imagine waiting on our table of many-a-loudmouth to be a bit like herding cats, so my hat is off to you, bespectacled gent with great taste in cocktails. Sadly, I forget your name. Happily, I have not forgotten anything about the food.   We all opted for the three-course tasting menu, so I was able to pinch off of my neighbors plates to get a better sampling. It all started with a fabulous Chicory and Pear Salad: so fresh, so bright, so thoughtfully put together and then dressed with the single most delicious cilantro dressing I've ever had. I also nipped a bit of the shredded duck which was rich and decadent and totally special. However, my next course was the absolute stand-out: Winter Uttapam with caramelized fennel, sun-dried tomatoes and a smattering of root veg. The star was the actual pancake -- dense without being doughy and subtly flavorful.   Where I ran into a bit of trouble was course #3, the Chicken Xacuti. Now, I like spice. I like spice this side of hot. I can throw back, seriously. This, however, was the kind of snot-inducing, drool-triggering, heartburn-churning heat that my wee Scottish stomach is just not built for. I silently suffered until I saw my colleagues around the table fanning the flames, as well. However, if you are a scoville scholar and enthusiast, this is the dish for you.   Another component worthy of noting: the drinks! I stuck with my favorite, a bourbon Old Fashioned but several of my fellows wadded into the creative cocktail pool and all were delicious and refreshing. They're quite unique, so this is where your server will come in handy -- just ask and (if you're as lucky as we were) you'll be perfectly paired with a terrific tipple.

PbtVwl8LLaNvNZwF5J9X2g.review_text: One of the best South Indian Cuisines in SF Area. Ambiance adds a little touch to the experience. Definitely a must go.

KRfRO8yMi4pCb9Sh8-vGzg.review_text: I love Dosa!   I always get their dosas and some appetizers and I am always happy.   This time, I really liked the grilled calamari. It came with a little baby octopus. So tender and delicious. The trumpet mushroom uttapam was also amazing. So many mushrooms, so much flavor. Didn't even use any of the sauces they brought.   The dosas this time were ok, I think I'll need to try one of the entries next time.

w1tI3Oh7GB-fUYzECYrnlQ.review_text: Grab a spicy lunch here and get your weekend off to a LIVELY start! My bf and I found ourselves by Dosa on Fillmore today and decided to give it a whirl because we really enjoyed Dosa on Valencia.   First off, hellllo SPACE! I have never been inside Dosa on Valencia and it makes Dosa on Fillmore feel and look like a walk-in closet. Whereas Dosa on Valencia is dim, intimate, and cozy, Dosa on Fillmore has soaring ceilings, floor-to-ceiling windows, and light, light, light! Add to this, a beautifully decorated interior to enjoy a Sunny SF day in the Fillmore.  We started the meal with complimentary fried crisps/chips with fennel seeds. I'm not sure what they were, but I would liken them to some kind of Indian "tortilla chip" but much thinner and lighter. Yum! I wanted another bowl!  We split a Prawn "Frankie" (spiced sauce, marinated onions, cucumbers & cilantro chutney wrapped in Roti, w egg-white brush) and a Spicy Mung Masala Dosa (mung lentil dosa with green chiles and spiced potatoes). The server noted these items were SPICY!   And SPICY they were....but enjoyably so, allowing the complex flavors of the entrees to still sign through. The Prawn Frankie was similar to an Indian "burrito" (Curry Up Now lovers, rejoice!). Juicy prawns in a red fiery sauce wrapped up in a soft roti wrapper.   The Spicy Mung Masala Dosa was also very tasty. The earthiness of the mung dosa was a tasty vehicle to enjoy the savory spiced potatoes and spicy chiles inside. I enjoyed experimenting with the tomato, fresh coconut chutney, and sambar (lentil dipping soup made with vegetables). I tried the Paper Masala (a thin, crispy, pliable dosa) at the Valencia location and prefer that because I like more texture in my food, but this was still very good.   Spent about $30 for 2 people, including tip.

KI7gPbRvdngGcgq3-RD7Gw.review_text: Such a great place -- authentic ethnic food with awesome upscale ambiance not typically found with Indian restaurants.  Service was great, drinks were great, food was great, pricing was great.  The ONE drawback was the amount of salt they used in their food -- must have been shoveled in... X____X.  Hopefully it was just an off night.  I ordered: --Lotus Steam Day Boat Scallops ($12) -- highly recommended.  4 big and perfectly seared scallops served w/ crispy chips of lotus stem (for anyone that doesn't know what that is, its the starchy root that grows under water, beneath lotus flowers) --Duck Vindaloo w/ Coconut Rice ($19, +$3 for rice) -- pretty darn spicy but meat is very tender and super flavorful. --South Indian Moons Uttapam ($13.5) -- good sampler of 5 uttapams, super soft and thick savory pancakes.  It wasn't mind blowing and  I'll probably go w/ the dosa next time (crispy and thin), but glad to have tried it.  We came with a big group for a birthday dinner -- worked out so well.  Open Table made it easy to reserve, we had a booth that was both private and comfy, delicious drinks made toasting a blast, and Dosa even coordinated a special birthday dessert for the bday girl at the end.  Thanks, Dosa!

78KCvBHRmDGQsiLCQEYl7A.review_text: I am going to set the record straight for DOSA.  This place is really good!  My husband and I come here as often as possible.  I have read some of the other reviews about DOSA and can't understand that anyone would rate this place lower than 4 stars.  ATTENTION DINERS: Indian Food = Spicy Food - - - DUHH!  :P  If you do not like spicy Indian food, then this might not be the best choice for your ultimate dining experience! I am an American; raised on pasta, pizza, & fried chicken - but LOVE the wonderful way the chef creates his Indian dishes. Always delicious!  My husband is from Bangalore; raised on spicy South Indian (vegetarian) food and loves everything about this place too - - He craves the vada sambar.....  The PROS and CONS of this restaurant:  PROS:  1. Convenient Parking in the Japantown Parking Garage at Fillmore/Post 2. Beautiful Ambience - soft lighting & nicely decorated 3. Delicious South Indian dishes (mostly vegetarian) but also lamb, chicken, & fish 4. Some North Indian choices - like chaat 5. Wonderful bar - unique drinks with the flair of India! With or without alcohol... 6. Great service 7. #1 Chef(s) 8. Great for a "date" if both like spicy & delicious food (and if you're vegetarian)  CONS: ....I can't think of any.  I have never dined here in the evening (only during the lunch hour on the weekends) so I can't give you advice for the evening crowd.  I have had almost everything on the menu at least once, and can honestly say that EVERYTHING I've ordered was enjoyed ~  If you like bland Swedish food - - go to Harry's Haufbrau.

mIysRk_cJ5K_BMZ-r06TFw.review_text: For those unfamiliar with Indian food: I pity you when coming here for the first time. For those unfamiliar with SOUTH Indian food, you've got a fighting chance to enjoy the full potential of this incredible restaurant, but it might be a struggle.   I've never experienced an effort at South Indian cuisine like this outside of India, in my life. To be clear, the menu is obviously designed to minimize the damage from being a Southern restaurant in a society that is really only familiar with Northern, and that is, Punjabi, mom and pops named some variation of Delhi, Taj, India, or Gandhi. Cultured Americans know naan and chicken tikka masala. But even they tend not to know idli and sambar. So, there are plenty of northern stand-bys on the menu when you first open it. You actually have to dig deep into the third page before the South Indian dosa offerings come up. The less adventurous will have plenty of familiar entrees to choose from.  And that's too bad. A couple seated next to us were quite obviously confused when they got their menus. The poor things asked some silly question of the waitress, who politely tried to explain to them that there are no tandoori ovens at South Indian restaurants, which is why there was no naan. They then opted to order the one thing that they figured looked and tasted most like naan: bhatura (a North Indian bread). The world of dosas would remain untouched by them.  There are so many stunningly delicious variations of amazing Indian recipes on this menu that I almost want to fly out to San Francisco again just for the sake of sampling more. This is only my second time at Dosa. Here's to the next time.

iOEN7M84hc4Hhs2269WFvQ.review_text: Oh my oh my oh my. The Dosa's alone are worth crossing the city for. Try the Masala Chutney Dosa and share around the table (or hoard it for yourself!) The food here is creative, fresh and flavorful. It's also pricy but maybe that's just the Filmore neighborhood? Take my advice, spend some time with the drinks menu, the mixologists here are fantastic. I saw a couple of reviews here that complained about the service, but it was fine for me and everybody tells me I'm the worst service critic around.   For the person who complained that people kept joining the table and then wanting to order? That's service nightmare, How would you like to try to get all those orders in and then have to add, add, change, add and then the customer wants all the food together? Jeez. Get over it, the problem is you not the servers'.  This is why restaurants don't seat a party until everybody is there. Simply rude.

zQHIrX63BN_mEcdMSOJJNQ.review_text: First, we had a 9:15 reservation and were sat at about 10. Ok, not a great start.   Food was good... when it came. The service was GLACIALLY slow. We were sat, then 10 mins for someone to come over. We ordered everything at once since we had been there a while. We had a few pretty simple questions about ingredients, and the server had zero idea what was in any of the dishes.   Apps came out before we got wine or even water at the table. We had to ask multiple times about the wine. It was late and the bar was slammed... OK but we got a bottle can you just go snag it yourself? 20 mins for drinks is not acceptable no matter how busy it is. By the time we got started on the first dishes (once we finally got drinks) everything else started coming out all at once and they just dropped dishes all over, barely attempting to bus anything.   Like I said food was very good but not worth the mediocre service. I'd like to give it another shot -- maybe I need to go on a Tuesday at like 6 pm when they aren't busy? Seems like they can't handle what looked to be a normal busy Saturday night.

g2z3-HQIysJ4IYlRWDpz1g.review_text: Heard about this place for years from my brother (the local) & parents who love going here when they visit.     Lovely ambiance.  That goes without question.  I have to say our experience here was odd from the moment we walked in.  I called on our way over (8:07pm) stating we were a few minutes away.  The host said no problem we are still getting your table ready.  We arrive at 8:17pm and they say they gave our table away but another one should be open soon.  This opened an evening of AWFUL service.  Awful service.  When we were seated the server examined the table and welcomed me back.  I informed him that this was my first visit.  Then began his attempts to remedy that. Weirdly after getting our apps he disappeared and this condescending snooty b***h "CAITLIN" approached our table.  Seriously.  I never write reviews like this but OMG she had the most arrogant energy and tone in each and every interaction all 4 of us had w her.  Like 75% of the table is Indian but she went on and on about the difference btwn an dosa & upadam to my brother who just asked what she recommends.  Hands down.  Worst server ever.  Hence we didn't get dessert bc 1.) She basically threw the menus at us (2.) we really wanted to get out of there.    Food Picks : (apps)scallops & samosa.  Dhai bhara so creative & tasty!! Entree dosa w truffle oil!   So after years of awaiting to eat at this place we were treated poorly and left angry.  Not how u expect a Saturday night dinner at a restaurant if this caliber to be.  Shame on you Dosa.  Then (after posting this) I get a message from a manager explaining how Caitlin is shy by nature, amongst excuses for our other issues. First, if I want my business to thrive I make sure I hire people who are best suited for the job.  I've never known a personality of a successful server that is "shy".   It's pathetic how they are making excuses for their shortcomings.  Own it and stop making excuses.  Absolutely pathetic.  I was initially impressed they followed up then with the response content I was saddened that this person would rather make excuses and minimize the mediocre (at best), offensive experience we had versus take responsibility for poorly selecting his staff and owned a bad night of service.   Tsk tsk

Vzabmg5GMgboUV2302vsCA.review_text: A-M-A-Z-I-N-G!!! I went for the first time on a Sunday night with a large group; we had a reservation, they were a little slow on seating us but we just had drinks at the bar and enjoyed the ambiance. Once seated the service was fabulous! Our server was very helpful in helping us order, we went family style (which I recommend to everyone so you can try a variety) and every item we had was fabulous. Recommendations: Boti Kebab Dosa is a must (my personal favorite), the minced chicken samosa, kale pakora, chile & mint brazino, Pondicherry mustard prawns, uttapam-get the mixed mushroom truffle oil...I'm sure everything else is delicious, I can't wait to go back!

8QAHOwtLZnZJFEA8nad7uw.review_text: Very spicy food, but extraordinarily tasty. My favorites were the lamb chops and the prawns masala. The curry sauce sampler was okay, but served in a small tray suitable for no more than two to share. Their shredded duck appetizer was wonderful, but again, highly spiced!  We had good service, nothing elegant in the way servers placed or removed dishes, but satisfactory. There is no question this is a terrific local restaurant, and gets booked up quickly on weekends.

zTkWFiZm_BW1Ya3xMW5uZA.review_text: Low bang for your buck. Food is mediocre at best and the place is shabby and not in the cute and atmospheric kind of way. Not my style

zwI4tiMwpgKQ6GU1FGFH7A.review_text: the ginger ante. like 5 of them.  and all the other stuff was amazing too.

D-_5rw7GQuYhp-i5K11RxQ.review_text: This place has a great ambiance. The decor is beautiful and the atmosphere is lively without being too loud. I came with a reservation, so we were seated shortly after we arrived. That said, the food didn't quite match my expectations. My date and I ordered the Chennai Chicken, the Green Mango & Paneer Dosa, and the South Indian Moons Uttapam. The chicken was pretty good, albeit spicier than I'd have liked (although I'm a wimp about that). The dosa was alright, but neither my date nor I could taste the mango. In fact, I thought the whole thing was on the bland side, without any flavors that stood out. The uttapam, which came with a variety of different kinds, wasn't much better. Maybe my taste buds were dying from the spicy chicken, but I was expecting something a bit more memorable.

SKz3v9bPwufBu7qjFzP2ug.review_text: This restaurant was sold to us by people who frequent it a lot as "the best Indian in the bay" - and this might have been an overshot.  The atmosphere is urban-chic and it's certainly a swank stop for Friday evening drinks with friends or colleagues.    The music and ambience was nice and the servers were excellent.  I have had some amazing-to-die-for Indian food in New York City and Washington DC and it seemed like the hype was about the sort of Japantown-chic vibe of San Francisco and the "different" Indian food rather than ridiculously amazing food.    The food is south Indian, so it has menu items that you don't typically find in most Indian restaurants.  We had a couple different Dosas, uttapam, a chicken curry with coconut rice and a garbanzo dish.  And all of it was certainly tasty.  But I have to say it was quite spicy to the point that you couldn't taste the delicious flavors - one of the people we were with loves uber-spicy food and he was uncomfortably red and sweating and needed to order a Lassi right away! Not really the reaction you want on a Friday evening out!  The biggest issue I had was the price - it seemed to be quite expensive compared to other Indian restaurants.  As a last note, there were six of us seated at a table, and there was barely enough room for us.  We were squeezed in so tight that it wasn't totally comfortable to hang out for a couple hours.  I would rate this place as just okay.

Ua3GFP6jHyO4UBPNzrJ8nw.review_text: One of my favorite restaurants in SF! The Fillmore location has a nicer ambiance and more parking options than the Valencia location. It's a great date restaurant, especially because the movie theater is right across the street. The menu is a little pricey for Indian food, but well worth it. We come here about twice a month for dinner. Some of our favorites are:  - Vada Pav **Get this. You won't regret it** - Masala Dosa - White Truffle Dosa (my bf thinks it's heavy, but I love it) - Bhatura  My favorite chutney is their coconut chutney. I don't even like coconut, but the flavor is not overwhelming at all.

iPs9IaZPw0U2VxoND_AmNQ.review_text: Great food great ambience. I hope they open a restaurant in dc also..  Will definitely visit again

irkLTpGy-NJjJDgkqZXC4A.review_text: My friend - allergic to gluten and lactose and me - vegan decided to have a dinner. We picked this place which not only served delicious food but also was able to cater to our dietary restrictions.   Knowledgeable staff and special menu for the people like us.   Love it!

KSGI-i2jpKm2EJfBvvD0vQ.review_text: Not my cup of tea. The lamb chops were fatty. Everything is very spicy. Even with reservations we waited a little while for our table. Our waiter was very personable.

nw42-jPvAN8M9IKBtZa4vw.review_text: Everything I had here was delicious. Foods were packed with flavor. Truffle and mushroom dosa, pumpkin dosa, all the dipping sauces (especially the coconut!), lamb meatballs, curry chicken, and so much more. Had a good sampling because I was there with a large group. Let the champagne flow!

LqK9jxnp-X61q742Y5F_Vw.review_text: Oh gott I love that place for lunch. The dosa's (filled pancakes) are so yummy! The service is very friendly and on the weekends or for dinner you need a reservation. If you like to try something new, because its south indian food (only two currys on the menue and dishes you never heard about it before) go to this place!

eIa4QJXp5ZNmuFORnuPvDA.review_text: My boyfriend is south Indian, my best friend is Indian, and her date is British/ Sri Lankan. When all three of them love the food, you know it's legit. (I kinda knew it before. This just confirms it)  And SO affordable (it was my friend's birthday and with 3 of us covering dinner for 4, it came out to only $27 before tax)! Plus the service is great, the upstairs is a little more private and there are a few on the wait staff always keeping an eye on the tables and making sure the water is filled, your questions are answered, etc.   Last time I came I got cocktails as well and they were delicious. This time we got:  * Vada Pav - 4 stars Spiced-potato patty, chutneys, caramelized onions & "gunpowder"- ground chiles & lentils (1 for $6, 2 for $10) Really well done, really spicy, and apparently its rare in Indian-American restaurants for them to split the "gunpowder" chile and ghee and let you mix them to your liking. The potato patty was fantastic, but the bread, while it had a good buttery subtle crunch, was just a tiny bit on the stale side (only reason this wasn't 5 stars).  * Channa Bhatura - 5 stars Chickpea (garbanzo) masala served with an oversized, soft, puffy wheat bread or vegan poori ($15) Love getting this at a table. The bread is the size of a pillow and always impressive when its brought to the table. The chickpeas are cooked to PERFECTION, any less and they would've been too hard, any more and they would've been too starchy. Strong and wonderful flavor as well.  * Uttapam - 4 stars (Slightly thicker, pancake-style variation of the Dosa. Each Uttapam is also served with fresh fresh coconut & tomato chutneys  coconut & tomato chutneys and  sambar  sambar) Topped with onion, tomatoes & green chiles ($11.5) Really liked the tomato & onion one - the tomato gives it a nice tangy kick. The pancake, while soft and spongy and delicious, is just a little bit on the oily side though.  * Dosa - 5 stars (Savory rice and lentil crepe, all served with fresh served with fresh coconut  coconut & tomato chutneys  tomato chutneys and sambar sambar, a flavorful lentil dipping soup made with vegetables and spices. Masala described below is a traditional filling of spiced mashed potatoes) * Spicy basil - Masala dosa with a chutney of fresh basil, cashew nuts, ginger, shallots, curry leaves & chiles ($12) * Spicy mung masala - Mung lentil dosa ('pesarattu')  with green chiles, chopped onions, cilantro and spiced potatoes ($12) Both the spicy basil and mung were amazing. As thin as the dosa is, it still manages to have a soft interior with a slight crunch to the outside. The masala is great as always, and the basil wasn't too overpowering (we were afraid it would taste too Italian).  * Rasmalai - 5 stars Sweet cheese patties, cream, cardamom, rose water ($6) Love everything, from the toasted pistachio crumbles to the cardamom infused rose water to the chewy cheese patties.

RFJcFZO0ZOHLVR4hQla_vQ.review_text: Eat here. Now. Don't hesitate. Just go and get anything. I enjoyed the lamb chops and duck. The old fashioned on the drink menu is superb. Had no complaints when eating at the bar, but would do a table reservation next time.

PDncvv8IQWHToDzj1-UJug.review_text: Now my rating is based on my own ignorance of Indian.  So please forgive.  Of course I have eaten Indian food before...many times but the highest level of sophistication has been random buffets and other locations such as "Naan and Curry."
