Now walking into the establishment was very cool.  I love their ambiance and layout.  The only thing I might complain about is the lighting.  It's WAY too dark.  I had to use my flashlight phone app to see the details of how good the food is supposed to be.  A great restaurant should not what to hide it's pride and joy...ie - THE FOOD!  Though granted we sat upstairs on the mezzanine level.  I believe the lighting is much better at the bar and main dining area.  We started with the Idli Fries which were unique.  The outside texture starts off like any ole steak fry but the inside is soft and crumbly like rice.  Very intesting and tasty.   Nearly at the same time the FIVE Moons came (South Indian Moons).  They are 5 small vegetable pancakes with 3 dipping sauces and seemingly ginormous one...or maybe it is a chili soup?  The dipping sauces were not that fantastic but perhaps more for the subtle palate.  Our mains were the duck vindaloo which is their spiciest curry (AND IT IS!) and masala.  The duck was tender and good quality though I felt the extreme spiciness of the curry left my palate burning and wondering if the duck was good.  You're probably saying I'm stupid for saying such things.  Perhaps so.  Anyways, I did still like the dish.  Probably would've gone better with their recommendation of rice instead of uttapam.  The 2nd main was masala...an super-sized pancake folded in half with a filling that tastes like the inside of a samosa.  After the 5 moons, my utappam, and now this huge pancake...I was pretty much carbed-OUT!  Ever bread item seemed to taste the same.  The filling was good but I had had enough of the breads....We were full.  As you see my ignorance of the cuisine has subverted a probably very fun time.  It's a great looking restaurant.  And I'm sure if we ordered a more diverse assortment the experience could be better next time.  Hopefully, the server could be more helpful in this regard and stop us from doing that next time.

29KnJybaavIMuqTetQZogw.review_text: MAKE A RESERVATION. It's always a good sign when there is a line, of Indian diners, out the door of an Indian restaurant. The decor of this restaurant was perfect. The atmosphere was exciting and loud. Just like the flavors of the food. The gunpowder scallops were not a good appetizer to split as recommended. The menu was hard to navigate on my own without the help of the waiter...but once we got over that hurdle, the flavors of every course were delish!

A3j3iI4RsyS9rxpVVOHSCw.review_text: Wow. I've never eaten Indian food like this before. We went here for my birthday dinner, on our one day visit in San Fran. The decor is fun and fancy, with gorgeous orange textures and flowing flowery chandeliers dripping down from the twenty foot high ceilings, which were delightfully sparkly when the sun went down to showcase the fiber optic light display from said chandeliers. So cool.  The menu was intimidating for me. I'm used to northern Indian food (or southern?) and this is the opposite - no naan (sniff!) but the poori and bhatura were effing amazing and I didn't miss the naan at all. We all could have made a meal out of those alone, but I'm glad we held out because what followed proved to be an unbelievable romp for our taste buds. I would have had to study and agonize over the strange offerings for a long time had it not been for our absolutely delightful and very helpful waitress, Marlece. she walked us through her faves on the menu (with exclamations like "jiminy crickets, the lamb!!) and explained everything for us and made recommendations for the best selections for our first Dosa experience. She was fantastic, kudos to the restaurant for nabbing her, she's a gem.  Our dining experience:  Kale pakora- fun, battered fried kale chips, essentially. Good, but I wouldn't bother again... Save room for the rest. Chennai chicken. Holy moly. Intense flavor, packs some serious heat. Delicious, but it couldn't eat to many. Best shared with others - Everyone loved  them. Samosas - one from the north, one from the south. One packed a bit more heat than the other but both were reliably delicious.  Prawn masala - I don't do seafood, but the guys at the table politely fought over the last bites of that, so I suppose it was a hit. I did eat some of the coconut rice that came with it, and it was yummy. Green mango and paneer dosa - Hands down the winner of the meal. Sooooooooooo delicious and sweet and tangy with awesome texture. It's served like a crepe. And oh so good. Masala dosa - the classic, as Marlece put it - a must for the first timer. Potatoey goodness in a huge crepe like thing with three delicious sauces to dip into... Lentil soup was my fave. Lamp chops - apparently marinated in yogurt, these fell off the bone into the mouth, packed a fair amount of heat with immense flavor. Definitely a memorable and awesome dish... I was so full at that point, but kept at it, and it was worth it and then some!  Dessert was banana chocolate gelato yummmmmmmm and homemade chai, better than any chai I've ever tasted (full disclosure, I've never been to India, but Marlece said the chefs make this for themselves to drink. Such an awesome treat, although all other chais will probably pale in comparison, and so perhaps this one ruined my chai habit... Time will tell) (I should also say, the caffeine in the  chai kicked my food coma in the arse and now here I am, writing this epic review, so perhaps not the best choice for after dinner??)  I loved this place. I'll be back someday, on some future visit to the area. Thanks to Marlece and everything about Dosa for capping off a lovely and memorable birthday!

p_nuu2vhMdv5fNawMFfFwQ.review_text: i LOVE Dosa on Valencia and have never been to the Fillmore location until last night. after catching a movie at my beloved Kabuki Theater, a friend and i decided to finally try this location out.  my initial thoughts: this place is fancy, but not stuffy or pretentious. i'm okay with that. it's a lot bigger than the Valencia location and would be great for a special occasion like a birthday or anniversary dinner.  we ordered two small plates (the coconut seafood soup and the shredded duck) and one dosa (the white truffle masala; my favorite!). for dessert we got the pistachio dacquoise with chocolate chile mousse. the shredded duck was good, but too spicy for me. after a few bites, i had to throw in the towel (but i'm wuss when it comes to spicy eats). the soup was delicious and had a good amount of seafood in it, which i always appreciate. the white truffle masala dosa has long been a favorite of mine, but this time it wasn't as flavorful. for that dish, i'd go to the one on Valencia for perfection. the dessert was probably the highlight for me--an enjoyable mix of textures and a perfect balance of salty and sweet, with just a touch of heat from the chocolate chile mousse. i highly recommend.  service was great. our waiter did a wonderful job of describing dishes we had questions about and recommending things based on what we were craving.  the food was good, but for me, not as memorable as the food at the Valencia location. it was almost like the flavors here were more refined, which suits the decor and overall vibe of the restaurant, but next time you'll definitely find me at Dosa on Valencia.

41HLwXnR0Lm3NUp01cIOQg.review_text: There are no shortage of Indian restaurants in the bay area but Southern Indian food is surprisingly different to find. Whoever came up with the business idea to bring the staple southern Indian fare to such a trendy spot is just pure ingenious. DOSA is truly one of a kind in the city (not counting its sister restaurant Dosa on Valencia of course).  The restaurant is huge. There is a spacious bar, communal tables, lounging area as well as plenty of tables in two floors. Even then, the restaurant is a complete full house on the weekends. Reservation is not too too difficult to come by. Just need to call a few days in advance. Walk in or same day reservation might be possible but do not count on it. You don't want to wait for 45 minutes do you?  The food was good. Very authentic in taste with much welcomed Californian twist featuring many locally sourced, farm fresh or organic ingredients. I can't say it was the best Southern Indian food I have had in the area. I could still name a handful of restaurants that would beat them in taste and price. However, none of those restaurants match this level of service and quality. You are paying extra for the service, excellent wine list and a nice ambiance. Let me tell you, it is totally worth it.   The tasting menu is great for first timers. The portion is adjusted smaller so you get to try more things. Otherwise, just one order of their dosa could easily fill you up.  I love the energetic ambiance but the tables were a little too close together for comfort. It is a fun place to bring your date to but not a place you could enjoy a more intimate and private conversation.

3nRENjIkd19bMwtJQtUFdA.review_text: Dosa is such a great place. Service and the food quality is top notch. The Chennai Chicken, the Dosas and the Prawn Masala were all great. Oh, and add in the coconut rice too! This was my 2nd time there and we'll definitely be back.

C2MlFhbt7vZWBnxuS40TUA.review_text: I love how beautiful this place is and not to mention how amazing their staff is.   I came her for a birthday dinner, and the staff was so accommodating. Not to mention they make the best recommendations for those who do not know what to order. Not only on food, but on bottles of wine that we ordered as well. I love their selections!  Definitely recommend anyone to try to this place. Dont know what to order? dont worry their staff with help you!

W8yuHxwfMBXee9Wm9VMF3g.review_text: I was introduced to this place by a friend about a year ago and since have visited this place multiple times. It's a fancy Indian-fusion restaurant and it definitely brings out the wow-factor.  Personally, I think their vada pav are to die for! I have had some amazing vada pavs back home in India but this one is different and exceptionally good.  Their chilli uttapam is a must try for someone who has a stomach for spicy food. The chilli uttapam has habenero chillies and it leaves your face flushing, nose running and eyes watering. I have a picture to vouch for it!  I recently tried thier Chennai chicken and it was mind blowing. They also have some very interesting cocktails to offer.

3ebGuvvDgFEd5wu6GB2fWw.review_text: Eating at Dosa is like a foodsplosion. Although Dosa has great ambiance, I don't really care at all about the decor, the atmosphere, the paucity of indoor stroller parking spots, or the uuns-uuns dinner techno. I care about the food.  If you've eaten Ethiopian or Eritrean food, you might be familiar with injera. Dosa is like that. Less similar, but similar in concept, are roti, tlayuda, tortilla, pizza, etc. Dosa is the food and the utensil. There are several kinds of batter available, and some dosas are smeared with chutney. There's mung (MOONG) bean, semolina, wheat... They offer vegan and vegetarian dosas.  If you really want to get adventurous, get the Thali. It's a variety of incredible little dishes including rasam, curry, a rice thingie.  Disclaimer: I'm white. If I like it, yes, you might like it too!

ykV0Wn0SGQM9WD1do2lQww.review_text: Every time I come here I have no idea what to order because there are so many delicious options.   Being that I am gluten intolerant Indian food is always an easy go to for me...even though I spent most of my time resisting the delicious naan and dosa. Usually when I come here I either have to bring an Indian friend with me or ask the waiter what I should order. I could probably come here every month and never order the same thing!   Everything I have ever had here is delicious and the atmosphere is just Devine. The waiters are always helpful and attentive which are the two most important things that I look for in customer service. So if you haven't been here before I say go and give this upscale Indian a try.

Le1nK8rFONlbxYjvGO3TMQ.review_text: Dosa on Fillmore-You Rock on multiple levels. Great food and exceptional service. I never knew south Indian food could be mashed up to this dizzy heights of flavor. The food is spicy and right. Visit this gem.

cvoxqeZgLM0si4d3kN_M6g.review_text: Good food but not honest.   We went there and paid 120 for 3 dosas, and 1 uttapam and 3 non alcoholic drinks. The manager came and said the tip was included. We were a party of 5.   The part that sucks about this is that I didn't get to look at the bill. It was my fathers treat that evening and he didn't question and look at it properly. :( he then felt something was fishy. Out fault for not asking!   Overall I feel like we got cheated and I don't trust this establishment. It's not a good feeling. This happened on sept 22nd so it has been a few weeks but this image of dosa has still stuck in my head.   I just wanted to warn people out there when they dine at dosa on Fillmore.

KU1jpjtvoIlzmKz5MZdZDw.review_text: Food and service was great.  The music is very loud though - like a bar/lounge. It got me very confused.  We came hear for a date but since the music was clubby, it was hard to keep the atmosphere romantic.  Very pricey too!

HGIPjk7Zsoquf5san37HKQ.review_text: We had lunch at Dosa, Fillmore recently wanted to share our experience. We decided to go to Dosa, Fillmore because of really good Yelp reviews and also based on what we had heard from our friends. Let me start off by saying that this review may be a bit biased because I am originally from Bangalore, India where Dosa is staple breakfast and the bar for Dosa is really high for people from Bangalore and Mysore.  Let me start off with what I liked, the ambience is good, the place is huge and tables are setup with people's privacy in mind unlike most other indian restaurants where they put tables really close just to maximize profits, this is where the good part ends!.  The service was ok, though I expected more for the price, oh did it say it is priceeeeeey, our waiter looked really stressed and forgot a few things we ordered but was quick to fix it.   Now, let's talk about the food, if you are brave enough to name your restaurant Dosa, you got to make sure that your Dosas are absolutely the best especially if you are going to charge $15 to $20 for a Dosa. I am absolutely cool with paying that kind of money if the quality and taste is up-to the mark, sadly it isn't. I and my friend ordered the Mysore Masala Dosa, these types of Dosa are suppose to be bit thicker, crispy on the outside and fluffy on the inside, it was thin and soggy, it was horrible, I can get better dosa for less than half the price in south bay!. The chutneys were not made fresh and quantity was tiny, Dosas are eaten with a lot of chutney, this place needs to double or triple the quantity of chutney they serve. If you have never had Dosas before, you can try this place, if you know what good Dosas should taste like, avoid this place, save your money and pick any hole in the wall south indian restaurant, you will be more satisfied!.

fGF4pZ7yMpFnK6JVCOwzSw.review_text: Tried only the egg dosa - only thing worth mentioning is the red chutney. I did not like the chennai masala - the chicken appetizer. Amazing ambience - good for a date

ynQ3-2f_cGVYSz3H5Ek7mw.review_text: An amazing restaurant! The ambience is great but the food is greater. Authentic taste, considerate servers (Mike was great!) and a huge selection in the menu make this a must-go restaurant! Will surely go back again!

1y24ataICzIEMLOJdA8R8Q.review_text: We came in on a Saturday afternoon with a 1:45 reservation. We were there 1:42 and were told to wait and we waited until well past 2pm to be seated. Bad start. The place looks decent, nice a big, but the seating is squished into a smaller section of the large room and hence is quite congested. The tables are quite close to each other and we could eat right off the plate of our neighbor if we wanted to.   Now granted this is not rare and there are several places with space constraints, but not Dosa, they have a huge area in the center going completely waste. They could've easily spaced the tables out more and made things a bit more comfortable.  We placed our order for 1 Vada pav (clearly stated one, not two), a Thali and dosas.   The Dosa's looked decent enough, price is a bit high, sambar was flavorful but lacked body, chutney was "okay" have had better more innovative ones. The Masala was completely devoid of any flavor at all, its just a huge pile of BIG chunks of boiled potatoes. This is not how its done, a good dosa masala has smaller chunks, green chillies and a lovely hint of spices and heat, with ginger giving a finishing kick.   Onto the veggie thali, This one is a complete head scratcher. It comes with one small cup of rice (this makes no sense whatsoever, rice is the core ingredient in a thali that holds the whole thing together, in India, the rice is not even served on the plate so as to not fill up the plate, its either on the side on a large bowl or served seperately by someone who will give you as much as you want!)  The combination of dishes on the thali made no sense either. There was one idly (again makes no sense, not only is Idly usually not served in a thali, no one gives ONE idly, its practically unheard of). One uthapam which was decent tasting, but then there was what appeared to be a Veg Kurma which wouldnt go with anything on the plate.   Then a really odd tasting Pineapple Pachadi (Pineapple with Yogurt based sauce) which was really absurd tasting and one vegetable, yogurt, sambar and a sweet. All small quanitities, which is sort of ok but badly thought out. Its quite clear the person has possibly never had a Thali in a South Indian restaurant before. You have a certain order in which you eat  a Thali, and hence the dishes are all laid out in a logical manner to accompany the base items (Roti, dosa, rice) and you move along one after the other until you complete all dishes and end with the dessert, instead here we were left with hardly enough to make sense and unsatisfied.  We got our appetizer midway through eating our dishes and were given 2 Vada pavs instead of 1. This was actually quite tasty, but had way too much grease from butter/ghee and hence hardly qualifies as an appetizer IMO, especially if its served after main course!  Overall, its really nice to see someone bring South Indian cuisine with a fine dining approach, and while the namesake Dosa is decent, the core taste, culture and tradition seems to be lost. Sure modern day Restaurants requires everyone to come up with creative dishes to stand out and make an impact, but you need to get the basics right and the core concepts and ideals correct and then improvise on top. Clearly this person is filling a niche and taking advantage of pricing the cuisine beyond anywhere its been, but not quite comprehending the core cuisine.  Price : 1/5 Ambience : 2/5 Food : 2/5 Service : 2/5  Overall 2/5

8kgQupO4TS2bpCGSPhTTIg.review_text: Mmmm who thought that a potatoes on a thin, crepe like wrapping would be so delicious!!  I've heard amazing things about Dosa and was excited to see what the hype was all about. We made reservations for 5:30 on a Sunday. The place wasn't poppin' when we got there, but it was definitely crowded when we left.  Between three of us, we shared:  White truffle dosa - 5 stars- delicious. Comes with three amazing sauces, each unique in flavor.  Lentil dumpling - 3 stars - was confused with this dish. It's a lentil dumpling covered with yogurt and other sauces. I was expecting something else, but this was definitely an interesting dish. The yogurt was cooling, and perfectly offset the spicy flavors of our other appetizer.  Grilled calamari - 4 stars - came drenched in a sweet/spicy sauce. Delicious grilled flavor!!  Vegetable curry - 4 stars - it was recommended that this be eaten with coconut rice. The rice wasn't as coconutty as I liked, but I definitely appreciated the variety of vegetables that came immersed in the curry. Taro, cauliflower, potato, carrots... and more. Yum!!  Definitely would come back to Dosa, if not to have a meal, then at least to grab a few drinks and share a Dosa with a friend.

rI9vP_OCuimA2Aqi5y4zGA.review_text: WOW, the food here is amazing the decor beautiful. I like the change and up-lift of Indian food. YUM I will be back for more!

kHTpRKU5ulUdDy1Lg-RNHg.review_text: A friend chose this location for his birthday dinner. We were able to get a reservation at 6pm on Saturday night for a party of 8. Even though we arrived 15-20 mins. early, the staff was very welcoming and they were able to accommodate us. We were seated even before our entire party arrived.   Dosas are delish here! I'm used to eating sweet crepes for more of a dessert-like snack, but Dosa on Fillmore proved that I can happily enjoy a savory crepe for a dinner entree as well. This was my first time trying dosa of any type (I should really expand beyond curries and naan for Indian fare) and I was very pleased.   {food}  For a seasonal fall flavor, I say go with the PUMPKIN MASALA DOSA. The pumpkin masala with ginger and cinnamon created a really unique taste that you don't usually get with Indian food. Even my Indian friends were intrigued and impressed with my dish. I like how it came with an extra side of pumpkin chutney along with the sambar (lentil soup) and tomato and coconut chutneys. With the Bay Area weather turning a bit crisp and chilly outside, the spicy soup and warm dosa made for a very satisfying dinner. And the description of the portion as "the size of a large plate" is a bit of an understatement...I am pretty sure the dosa was the size of my face.   The UTTAPAMS were also yummy and a couple of my friends chose the SOUTH INDIAN MOONS to get a selection of five different flavors to try. The texture was similar to potato latkes. I personally prefer the thinner, crepe-like consistency of the dosas.   {drinks}  All the SPICE ROUTE COCKTAILS are pretty tasty. They are on the smaller side but they pack a nice punch. I've been in a tequila and spicy cocktail kick recently and went with the HIDEAWAY (the tequila, ginger, spiced agave, and birds eye chile caught my eye). I am still a fan of sweeter cocktails and also enjoyed my friend's MANGO IS THE NEW BLACK (rye whisky and spiced mango nectar made a great combo).   {dessert}  I loved the soft vermicelli noodles and beets swimming in condensed milk in the PAYASAM & RED BEET HALAWA. It was a light dessert and reminded me of sweet dessert soups you find in Chinese restaurants. The RASMALAI was also a light dessert with cheese in a cream sauce flavored with spices and rose water. I preferred the sweeter flavor of the Payasam. Both desserts were quite large and we split them between our party of 8.  Things to note: - You can take the 38 or 38L from Geary/Powell if you're downtown - If you're coming with 2-3 other ppl, I would take Uber or Lyft to save time and avoid the crowded buses - Close proximity to Japantown if you want some daytime activities before/after eating  I would definitely come back again if I'm in the Japantown area!

CvM4fHos5paf_oRxEuTEcQ.review_text: Dosa is undeniably some of the best Indian food I have eaten in San Francisco and I have eaten a LOT of it!  It's also a great date night spot! Came here on Friday night with reservations, of course, after not wanting to take the chance on a long wait. We had the chutney sample, spicy basil dosa, pumpkin masala dosa and fall vegetable curry with coconut rice! YUM! Everything was delicious; the dosas were huge and hardly any room was left for curry, which was also super tasty! Cocktails were on point with an Indian flare.   TIP: The dosas are very filling. A couple will fill 2 people up, no problem!

kmNpgegXzuwfT9u66RUZBA.review_text: Here's a game for you to play if you find yourself eating here. Attempt to have everyone at your table get an empty glass of water for more than 2 minutes. I have never eaten at a place that refilled water with a such a religious fervor. Water was refilled with an urgency that made me suspect my glass would explode if it was left empty for even 5 minutes. Anyway, on to the important things. Dosa is potentially the hippest restaurant I've ever dined at. The dim lighting and the night lounge like decor made me realize that I've been dining like a 40 year old. It's a nice place to bring your 20 or 30 something year old friends, but not such a great place to bring your grandparents unless you're also going to bring a flashlight so they can read the menu.  I made a reservation for Friday night, and when we showed up, our table wasn't ready. I think reservations should be thought of as granting a shorter wait time rather than no wait time here. It wasn't too bad though. We were seated ten minutes later. People without reservations waited about an hour.   We chose items off of the dine about town menu. To start off, we had the chicken chennai and the coconut seafood soup. Both were amazing, but the soup was better. It was full of humongous scallops, prawns, mussels, fish and squid cooked in a delicious coconut milk broth. I'm not normally much of a seafood person, but this was fantastic. The dosas came next. Between the green mango and paneer and the truffle masala, the truffle was better. If I came back though, I'd probably skip on the dosas altogether. They were good, but not worth paying full price for. I'm not sure if it was because the dine about town menu had smaller portions or because this is their normal ratio, but my dosa was about 25% filling, and 75% just empty wrapper. The soup that came with them was too salty and spicy for me to finish. For our last course, we had the hyderabadi lamb and the prawn masala. Both were delicious. This course was a tie. Lamb was tender, prawns tasted fresh. You wouldn't go wrong picking either one.   I did take a peek at the full price menu. Entrees here run between $20-$35. They also do validate parking if you park in the Japantown garage. Validation should give you free parking and not just parking at a reduced rate.

A38s8uE8XR2N0cn1K1Gt0g.review_text: Dosa is the place to go for a spicy tummy before drinks. Great location and chill vibe. If you never had a Dosa, the flat crepe looking thing, TRY IT. Make sure to sit by the window so you can people watch while you wait.   Please don't get over zealous and order many items. You will have leftovers that you probably wont eat in the next day.

TWZqHNynItvvWNvfvLOKMg.review_text: DOSA was a wonderful place! I haven't had Indian in quite some time and it was delicious. The food presentation by each waiter was great, especially with the different sauces and how each will bring out different flavors depending on your taste. We tried the lamb, chicken,  squash dosa, and a delicious salad. Everything paired very well with the wine recommendation. Since it was Halloween it was added fun being dressed up and watching all the trick-or-treaters walk by! I highly recommend this restaurant. Also wonderful location right on Fillmore Street!

kaKEer3UR5utYZsgp2tgPw.review_text: This is one of my top 10 favorites in SF so far. I loved my dinner here. The ambiance is nice, the service was quick and our waitress recommended us really good dishes.   I really liked the biryana chicken and rice, the lamb chops, and one of the appetizers with popped rice (and guac yum!). The paper dosa is on the 7x7 list, and it's humongous, but I wasn't a huge fan of it. It's crispy and thin, and big enough to share one amongst the entire time (we had 4 people), and you basically dip pieces of the dosa into sauces given.   The staff was really nice, and it's a great dinner spot to catch up with friends. I thought the food was quality, and I'd recommend it as one of my favorite go to restaurants in SF. Best of all, the wait isn't horrible because it's pretty big inside!

Rgf9lI8RTU5q8-rc5wwklA.review_text: I've been here a number of times, and I'm going to start by saying - my least favorite thing here is the dosa.  If you want a serious dosa, go to a hole-in-the-wall.   I got the paneer dosa last time I was here, and the peas in the paneer dosa were clearly frozen before serving (and some were still a little cold) yuck - and the dosa just didn't have that fresh, amazing flavor it should. The sambar was mediocre (not much flavor) and the chutney was RIDICULOUSLY spicy. whaat?!  The chicken curry - ok THAT was as good as my dad makes it (and that's saying something). SO SO SO good. perfect amount of spice, they didn't skimp on the chicken and didn't load it down with cream. SUCH good flavor.   The drinks - as usual, SO good. I got the Manhattan and my compadre got a white wine recommended by our waiter. she was happy with her wine and I was THRILLED with my Manhattan (sidenote: they put some vanilla something or other in it so it also SMELLED deliciouuuss).   Also, we had to be in and out in 45 minutes to catch a movie and they were VERY accommodating of that, so that was definitely appreciated. If I hadn't gotten a dosa, this review would probably be 4 stars vs. 3..

4tVHeMKpG_2r0N3bdDpc7Q.review_text: It was Nirvana on a plate!!! Everything was so good that we kept saying "Yuuum" throughout the whole dinner. The ambience was great too. Trendy, ethnic, and in a fun neighborhood. Nice bar area as well!  My menu items:  Drink- The emerald monk: Delish!!! Nice and strong too! This is a must! I was relishing every sip!  Appetizer- Chennai chicken: This was so good! It was like fried chicken tenders with an idian twist!  Main entree- Spicy mung masala: Waitor told me that it was his fav. I'm so glad I took his advice. It was amazing!! Enough spiciness to the chutney and the dosa was to die for! I still keep dreaming about it! (Big sigh)

8TA9k_7AhXaSWg3yc-gmJg.review_text: Really good overall. The ambiance was really nice and was accompanied by great service.  We ordered a Dosa, Scallops and the lamb dish with the coconut rice that was recommended with the lamb. It was delicious.  Also, a really good spot to eat if you are going to catch a movie at Kabuki across the street.

6ltdR-NUebl8jrUz5Xe7VA.review_text: Looks like service here deteriorated ... many servers and wait staff but all disorganized!  :(

iwOyiVjimhErtCnxAD7yHQ.review_text: We had heard all the buzz about this place and grabbed whatever reservation was available (5pm instead of 7:30pm?... yes please!). And we were not one bit disappointed! The food was just amazing! A bit on the fusion side, but so very flavorful. The staff was super friendly and nice and the decor was classy. The coconut custard dessert was amazing... not simply because I like coconut everything. This was just divine!

vc-CUn5f8V8fUKOFanOzwA.review_text: We make it a point to go to Dosa whenever we are in SFO.  Service is great, food is amazing. Just go. Enough said.

xwIeGfv2NAhq9Kofn5qQmg.review_text: Came here for lunch on Friday and it was great. The place was only about 1/3 full so we were seated immediately and and server was attentive to our needs. I ordered the sweet potato dosa and it was delicious. Next time I may not order the same dosa because there are so many variations on their menu that seem appetizing and I'd love to try the other combinations. This was my second time dining here and I will be back =)

6Fo8xB96WFj8Bk0AK7fRpQ.review_text: Mmmmmmm, dosas. Dosas dosas dosas. I went here for a brunch/lunch type deal on a recent Sunday to catch up with a friend, and it did not disappoint. We each started with a mimosa and had a dosa. I can't remember what he had, but I had a pumpkin spice dosa that was out of this world. Seriously, it was oh-so-good. Perfect mix of sweet and savory, with that flaky dough. nomnomnom. Again, I can't remember what my friend had, but he loved it, so I have a feeling I could recommend any dosa on the menu.  Because the only thing we had were dosas, I can't speak to anything else on the menu. But seriously, you come to a restaurant named Dosa on Fillmore and order something BESIDES a dosa? No. Just no. Get a dosa!  I do wish it wasn't quite so expensive, but hey, it's good food and this is SF. It happens.

BOphI5JEzht9JAFpV-_ioA.review_text: This upscale south Indian cuisine. Loved the food here. So yes, it's pricey, but worth the trip. We found service bit slow, however once we got the servers attention, it was all good.

n17dxizQKL2KuLGqWA_bKg.review_text: This place was hyped up to me and while it was good, it was not outstanding. As Yelp would say "it's OK, not A-OK". Let's go through it point by point.  THE ROOM - Beautifully decorated but there are so many tables jammed together, it's extremely loud and there is very little chance for privacy. 3 Stars  THE SERVICE - Nice folks but very haphazard, long stretches of no service, then four different people in under two minutes asking us if we were done and could clear our plates. They also screwed up the bill and double charged us. 2 Stars.  THE DRINKS - All three of the "Spice Route Cocktails" were hits. We tried the King Louie, Wry Rajah and Lucky 7, excellent. They also have solid beer & wine choices! 4 Stars  THE FOOD - A little disappointing, everything was mild (even the "extremely spicy" dishes). We tried, the CHUTNEY SAMPLER (great), DAHI VADA (best dish of the night), CHILE-CILANTRO FISH (disappointingly bland), PRAWN MASALA (great sauce, rubbery prawns), DUCK VINDALOO (the waiter said it was the spiciest dish in the house, it was not, at all), TAMIL LAMB (good but the flavors didn't pop). For dessert we shared the RASMALAI (pretty good). 3 Stars  OVERALL - A low 3 Stars. Great looking room & cocktails. Decent but not amazing Food but inconsistent service. DOSA still seems to be a big favorite in town and I am willing to give it another shot as I still have to try their actual "dosas" and see how they are but it didn't blow me away.

d8tiiDXdc9vAvEVKIus7yg.review_text: Tried, Rava Dosa and it was authentic. Reminded us of India and we licked the last bit of it. Dosa's in Indian restaurants are usually Oily but not here. Ambience was great but was a little crowded. My wife has been craving to go back ever since. Would definitely return to try out their wide selection of dosas.

hiPzZgdP83HtF_aQ9lg9bA.review_text: Amazing food, beautiful décor, and delicious drinks.  I love the unique breads and dosas they offer, plus their curry is spiced to perfection.  I just love this place.  This location is bigger than the one in the Mission, but food is consistent in both.  I cannot wait to go back.  It is a bit pricey, but you get what you pay for.  If you love Indian food like I do, you must go.  Great place to have a birthday dinner and to bring a date.  The one in Fillmore has a really nice bar area to grab a drink and hang out too.  I can't wait to go back!

sJWkHvMEHcyAAwjrl4HCGQ.review_text: I am South Indian.  And this is by-far one of the best South India restaurants I've been to anywhere in the world including London, New York, and South India.  The food is absolutely delicious.  I did the prix fixe.  Except the seafood vada which was so-so, everything was near perfection.  The ambiance is higher end for a typical south Indian place, but some of it still came off a little cheap.    As an aside, I would recommend ordering a lambrusco by the glass (it's offered so rarely in restaurants in the US).

1xZGYbOBkFekd-epFYBqnw.review_text: Food is insanely delicious! Great place to take someone from out of town. Very attentive and over-animated waist-staff. Go and eat!!!

s85ov2JmELYoW2lwwmkVUg.review_text: A somewhat "upscaled-urban" version of their other location in the Mission district, Dosa on Fillmore fuses modern chic décor with ornate Indian influenced pieces. The beautiful dark woods mixed with warm golden hues around the two-story restaurant are absolutely striking.   Once seated and greeted, we were given delicious Papadam (lentil chips), which I happily munched on while my sister ordered for us. For our party of four, we settled on a family style selection of the Channa Bhatura, Spicy Mung Masala Dosa, Chicken & Eggplant 'Baingan Bharta', and the Kerala Fish Moilee.  First, let's talk about how amazingly delicious and fun the Channa Bhatura was. Perfectly seasoned and tender chickpeas that are scooped up with pieces of lightly fried and puffy wheat bread (bhatura). And the most fun thing? The Bhatura comes served like a balloon ready to be punctured and used as a utensil. DEE-LISH and ENTERTAINING? that's a Nguyen-Win Situation to me :)  The Spicy Mung Masala Dosa brought back many memories for me as I constantly ordered Dosas in Chennai. This particular dosa was not only stuffed with mung beans but also with potatoes and cilantro-quite possibly two of my favorite things. All Dosas here are served with three types of "dipping sauces": coconut chutney, tomato chutney and sambar. As a Condiment Monster, this was also a Nguyen-Win Situation for me :)  Our two main entrees were also scrumptious-though I did prefer the aforementioned two items. The Kerala Halibut Moilee was extremely tender, moist and paired so well with the velvety coconut sauce. The Baingan Bharta was indeed succulent and earthy.  And although we were way too stuffed for any dessert (shocking, I know), we did indulge in a few cocktails.  Our dining experience was extremely enjoyable and I would HIGHLY recommend Dosa on Fillmore  to anyone interested in Indian cuisine. True, although many dishes have been slightly modified from their original state to compliment San Francisco, you will be hard pressed to find a spot that serves such high quality, South Indian inspired cuisine.   4.5 Stars

6fFO2RoWeriGi_z3ZGbwlw.review_text: AUTHENTIC AND GOURMET: Sometimes to find authentic cuisine, you have to sacrifice atmosphere and go to hole in the wall. But at Dosa, they manage to serve delicious, authentic South Indian food in a top-rate upscale environment! The food, service, atmosphere, are all excellent. Also, they try to use organic and local ingredients where possible.  INSIDE: I prefer this to the other Dosa location. Located in a smaller space, it's a little more intimate feeling. The tables are spaced close together, but that can be forgiven.  FOOD: Free papadum appetizer - order the chutney sampler to make it more interesting. The masala dosa is a staple and a must try. They have a number of small plates, like "north and south samosas," as well as great entrees like mango prawns. At lunch, try the Thali for a sampling of different items (although some of the offerings are an acquired taste). Check out the drink list for elaborate and pricey cocktails. They now offer interesting egg dishes for brunch. I recommend going family style, and having a feast!

gMvTe2Vm4-l79jH3apmbog.review_text: Came here for lunch and we realized we definitely should have come here for dinner. The interior here is great and the service was excellent, but I thought the lunch menu was lacking compared to what they offer for dinner. I'll definitely come back and update my review once I can sample their dinner menu (especially their lamb dish)

iv2xiHvWSH3mS0Xa9U3blw.review_text: 4.5 STARS!!!   My boyfriend took me to Japantown and I immediately thought that we were going to be eating sushi but instead he took me to Dosa. The restaurant itself is beautiful. I fell in love with all the decorations. Very elegant looking to me.   Our waiter was friendly (can't remember his name) and gave us recommendations since it was our first time there. He was very knowledgable of the menu and was helpful. The waiter gave us this complementary snack before ordering and it was a great way to start the meal. I wish I knew what it was called, but I think it's some type of Indian chip or maybe bread?   I ordered the chicken xacuti and the mango lassi. My boyfriend ordered the lamb dosa. The chicken xacuti is a curry dish and it was DELICIOUS. The sauce was spicy but not too overwhelming. It's served with coconut rice which is a good complement. As for the mango lassi (yogurt based smoothie), I thought it was average. It was not as sweet as the other mango lassi that I've had in the past. The lamb dosa was delicious as well and it wasn't as heavy of a meal compared to the chicken xacuti. The staff are very quick in regards to refilling water glasses or responding to customers' questions/requests.   Reason why this place is 4.5 stars instead of 5: Despite the flavorful amazing food, I thought the pricing could have been maybe 2-3 dollars cheaper (at least during lunch time). Also, I thought $5 for a mango lassi was overpriced. I'm used to paying $3 at other indian restaurants.   Anyway, if you are in the Japantown area and don't have a particular craving for sushi TRY DOSA. The restaurant is gorgeous. The staff are friendly. The food (although overpriced) is flavorful and packed with a lot of spices. Go out and try it!   I will definitely be coming back to DOSA in the future (and bringing friends/family to try it).

_bn12fdkR5k-0YO5cQ3MGw.review_text: On my visit to the bay, my good friend and his lovely girlfriend took me and my lady to this place. Apparently this has been their go-to place for Indian cuisine and it just so happened to be the last day for Dine About Town! Lucky us!  _what I ordered: - Kale Pakora:: I'm not the biggest fan of kale but this salad tasted fresh with subtle flavors. It was light and delicious.  - Lamb 'Keema' Dosa:: I have never had dosa before but I LOVE it! It was served with (3) different condiments varying on the spectrum of spice: coconut chutney, tomato chutney, and sambar. I believe that is the order from mildest to spiciest. If you are sensitive to spiciness, ask for the spiel on each (there is one gentleman that does an exquisite job at explaining it; it's theatrical!). - Chicken Xacuti:: the chicken would literally fall off of the bone. it was perfect.  _atmosphere/service: This is a very elegant, nice sit-down restaurant. The interior was very clean with very high ceilings and large-scale art to add to the ambiance.  _parking: There's a parking structure adjacent to the restaurant. I'm not sure what the rates are because my friend covered it (thanks, Alex!).

N4oewbxa4ud7HTHA1aSbZw.review_text: Beautiful and Delicious.  Good combination, is it not?  Set in soothing amber tone, airy vaulted ceiling, well coordinated arty objects and most importantly, comfortable seats, you can expect fine dining experience, here.  Innovative cocktails with crispy Pappadum smoothly lead you into different sphere of culinary world. Chutney sampler was a good idea to bring variation of taste.  Also, was very tender and flavorful nuggets of Chennai Chicken.  Kerala Fish Moilee, a block of moist white (sorry forgot what kind) fish topped with sweet, spicy, fragrant coriander sauce accompanied by fluffy coconut rice was our favorite.  So was the huge triangle of Dosa Masala, such comfort food.  2 cocktails, 1 beer, 1 wine, 2 appetizers, 1 Dosa, 1 Entree + tax/gratuities = $150  Dosa is one of the establishments which can integrate culinary authenticity and local supplies. I would have liked to see more fish offerings, if anyone is listening.

t-a_3_hfZZQBEvuoiAOh4Q.review_text: Jus had the spritzer and it was very refreshing. The dosa masala with the 2 dips and spicy soup was amazing! ! All the spices and curry flavors were delicious! Not a fan of papadum although I do like the crispy texture! Will be back for cocktails!

CH2K9PMocIMe4gkCAxS9FA.review_text: After getting the Christmas tree and before stopping by the Korean grocery store we decided to grab a quick lunch at Dosa. This was the best decision of the day.   The South Indian caramelized onion  pancakes were top notch. Full of flavor and spice it's South Indian food you won't forget especially for the price.

XF3WTVuveXoE4g9e-9JsIA.review_text: Since one of my friends really wanted to have the chocolate-hazelnut dosa, we made it a point to visit Dosa in San Francisco. But we ended up at the wrong branch since that's available only at Dosa on Valencia.  We'd already had a tough time getting a parking spot on Fillmore so we stayed back to eat at this one instead.   A few of us were apprehensive about eating here considering the Indo-Americanized food and it's steep prices but sat down nevertheless. Ordered vada pav, masala dosa, spicy basil masala dosa, spicy moong dosa and uttappam.   Vada pav was delicious!  Masala dosa was very tasty too. The potato curry and coconut chutney were top notch, whereas the sambar and tomato chutney were not.  Uttappam was served in small portions which looked weird and apparently tasted odd too.  Spicy basil masala dosa was not as spicy.  Moong dosa was okay-ish.   For dessert and later, we had rasmali and masala chai.  The chai was pathetic - nowhere close to Indian chai.  Rasmali was super creamy and delicious.   Definitely worth coming back.

U1fYcbo-hRYKm4gIrVqz2A.review_text: I really love eating the masala dosas and vada pavs here (when they don't skimp on the onions, mmm) but the mixed drinks made by the head bartender are usually toxic.  I've learned the hard way to just not order them, but the other day I guess I forgot that it was a lost cause and just ordered a simple gimlet.  It was truly horrible and it's only like three ingredients.  Personally, I'd recommend staying away from the cocktails here and just getting beer.  Blegh.  Weirdly, the bartenders at the Valencia location are totally awesome.

yW-GBoKnzyduaG86Y1NLzw.review_text: Is not bad, but not sure if I'd return. I came here with a friend to catch up, and didn't realize I was walking into a date spot. It's ok. I have a special friendship. We can deal.  We weren't too hungry, and ordered a Paper Dosa and the Mushroom uttapam (like a savory pancake thing). The staff were really nice about explaining how to eat it, as I have not been to Dosa in years (I'm going to say...like, 6 years now?). Always fun to eat with your hands (mostly) though!  The 2 items were just enough for us. We saw the curries were a bit pricey, and we weren't too hungry so just went with these 2 items. It ended up to be perfect for how hungry we were.   The staff were very friendly, and were attentive without being too overbearing. My water was never more than 1/2 empty, and they were quick about picking up any empty plates. Food was good, and overall a great experience! It IS a little pricey for Indian food, but for the price and the environment, its not a bad deal.

kv9Vg5FbJiFgcNQ_FOJ2Ng.review_text: Late review.  Dined here a year ago with my husband.  Nice ambiance with high ceilings.  They transformed this building to a nice one.  I think it looks better than the one on the mission.  Be careful with their floor, it can get slippery especially with heels on.   We decided to their Menu prixe.  I don't remember what was included but it's a great way to try their dishes.  I like how they use local ingredients.  Definitely worth a try.

wE_BzyibHCASTjEpMVRq-g.review_text: I love dosas, and I love Dosa too!  We went here for lunch, and the place was pretty empty when we arrived.    We had the lamb frankie and the paper masala dosa.  The lamb arrived wrapped and cut in half, perfect for sharing.  That was probably my favorite part of the meal.  When the dosa arrived, we stared at how big it was.  We couldn't fit it on the table for 2 without spilling over to the nearby table.  Good thing no one was sitting next to us.  Food was excellent.  The only thing preventing 5 stars was the price.  Love the high ceilings and ambiance.

9IF2ZMnkrZlvxCHcO0h1EQ.review_text: Finally dined here after hearing good things about it from numerous friends over the years. The happy hour hands down is the way to go. Beer, wine and cocktail specials, plus a handful of appetizers for $6. Happy hour also goes until 7 p.m. which seems later than most.

4k2u2qccl2OJac_EJioF6A.review_text: My boyfriend and I had dinner here over the weekend. Everything was excellent... From the drinks, to our dinner and dessert, and the service!  We will definitely be back!

Sg_BvnTHsbc1AABiJjaiPA.review_text: We were only here for happy hour (before state bird) but I really want to eat here someday! It's like.. I love boyf on any given Sunday, cuddling on the couch or whatever, but wedding boyf in a suit is like whoa. Likewise, I love Indian food, so dressed-up Indian food is gonna blow my mind, right?  Anywayyyy my gf and I both had a margarita and a red off the HH menu each. Bartender said there were 2 shots in each margarita, which would have been nice to know before I ordered my second drink. Needless to say, we were both pretty drunk at dinner. PS the drinks were quite good :) Nice ambiance too, the place was surprisingly uncrowded and we were able to snag the last couple seats at the bar.

IPqDGfh7IBHvQ1YDI2OjsA.review_text: After having a,5:30 reservation and arriving on time at 5:30 the hostess made us wait 10 minutes to seat us.  Mind you the restaurant was empty at 5:30 and she told us to wait while she seated other people. (Perhaps imaginary guests?).  There was one family she seated but why would it take 10 minutes  get us settled at a table when here was no one else in the waiting area?  It started out the evening on a bad note and was so avoidable.  She could have said "welcome to Dosa! I will get you seated in just one moment"  (10 minutes to sit on a bench while she organized menus?! Please!  As for the food, we ordered two purple cauliflower soups that said the ingredients were cauliflower, fennel, shallot, coconut milk and curry leaves.  There were no indication on the menu that it would be spicy.  However, it tasted like hot chili peppers and nothing else.  They didn't mention that there was even chili In the soup.  I send mine back but my husband was hungry and kept eating his but was mad at himself for doing so.    The spicy mung bean salad was good.  It was spicy but we were warned by the pepper next to it on the menu.  We also had a noodle dish that was just too hot.  Thankfully we ordered the big puffy bread which was delicious.   Our waiter was very nice.  I complained to him about the hostess and when the soup arrived and it was too hot he was very nice and did not charge us for my meal.  Of course I felt bad about whining. I would have rather had something delicious to eat so that I did not have to eat a big bag of popcorn at the movie.    The waiter also comped us ice cream for dessert.  It really helped sooth our burning mouths but I had more guilt about complaining.  In any event, after dining at Dosa many times before movies at the Kabuki we will not return.  The last time we dined there we sat at the bar and witnessed a rude bartender who was in a bad mood and was not nice to a couple of the patrons.  The more we reflected on the meal, we came to the conclusion that this restaurant is going down hill.  There are too many new restaurants to try to spend time and money walking away with a bad dining experience.

NdU0YuKeyVs7cmOI5HsIQw.review_text: Two words.. Trendy.  Unauthentic.    Don't expect the DOSA to make an authentic Indian Dosa.   Our two dosas came out half baked and half roasted to the black.  May be that is the trend in this restaurant. 30 min wait time to get your dosa after you ordered it.  Be sure to order appetizer if you are hungry.   Ambience is great.  Concept is great.  The cook needs to put more effort to make the dosa right and not to slap something on a plate and serve.    Our waitress was pleasant and smiling all the time with all the tables full. So, the training that the wait staff got is prefect. Give the same training to the cook who make dosas.

zxSXv_Z7S73A_2T_tyNSbw.review_text: I came here with my mom and some friends when she came to visit the city. I'd never had dosa before so I was a little overwhelmed with what to expect, but it was pretty good. Our server was very nice. Luckily we got a reservation on Opentable so that it wasn't a long wait to get a table. We were seated in a quieter area of the restaurant, which was a relief, since it was so loud and crowded! Only real downside to the service was that because it was so busy, they forgot one of our appetizer orders and by the time they delivered it we were halfway through our dinner and had no room to eat more.  I got the pumpkin dosa which was pretty good. I expected there to be pumpkin inside the dosa, but it was just a separate dip, which was sweet and yummy. Next time I come here I probably wouldn't eat the insides of the dosa--or maybe it was just the pumpkin dosa filling that was boring, just potatoes. My boyfriend got the paneer dosa which came in 3 little wraps instead of the large triangle, and I thought that one tasted really good.  If you can come here DEFINITELY try the peony cocktail! SO GOOD! I had the Mango is the New Black cocktail which was ok but a little watery. My boyfriend had the specialty gin and tonic which he said was also alright, not really like a gin and tonic. But the Peony was sooooooo decadent and delicious and absolutely amazing. Yummmmm please.  Maybe if I came here again we'd just order a couple of dosas to share, instead of everyone ordering a separate dosa.

LZt80LbsfQ9kOz96H7c1bA.review_text: This place is cravable. Delicious Indian food with a great atmosphere.  Duck Vindaloo is DELICIOUS  Dosa was light/crispy with spicy/savory filling - had one with broccoli rabe  Seasonal vegetable curry was also delicious.  Highly recommend the cocktails too! The Peony was the perfect compliment of sweet/spicy to the meal and one of the best cocktails i've ever had. I'll definitely be coming back!

Rh1zLiZJDIw3YL-pnqxhNQ.review_text: I heard Dosa On Filmore is so nice quality of service and also wi-fi facilities. But didn't found any of that. As an Indian restaurant there are too many sub-continental food selections and very yummy. Vegetable pancakes with dripping sauce is very good. Kerala Aviyal and Coconut Rice also seemed very nice but not too good as before.  Service should be better and overall sounds ok.

Sd0aBczS7-I3JQIbfdzfng.review_text: Good sambhar, best vada pav, and everything else yummy! Each item that we ordered was made without shortcuts.   I wish they open in other locations.

khJwHfXWmFjwZpvtLOzXAg.review_text: Ok food and decent service.  They have a few good dishes (e.g., bhel puri, vada pao).  However, their main dishes are just average. Ambience is good and the seating is spacious.  Waiters are courteous.  Overall, a decent experience

c8ps1IgRopfRVdnrHkZ9TQ.review_text: This restaurant is a high-quality establishment offering top-notch indian food in a very unique setting. I love the idea of communal tables in a restaurant. My fiancee and I had the pleasure of being seated at these tables and making a solid connection with a woman on a business trip who lived in the same area back home. We ordered and shared food and life experiences over the course of our stay at Dosa on Fillmore, which was definitely a highlight of our trip.  We enjoyed selections from the drink, appetizer, dinner, and dessert menu, all of which were highly delightful. Sweet potato dosas, kale pekora, coconut custard, oh my. I would return to SF for the sole purpose of eating at this restaurant.

ck4oX0q1oGTj_flOHmA5zQ.review_text: Five starts for food, drinks and service.  Something happened with our online reservation so it never actually went through.  They were able to accommodate us with only a 45 minute wait.  Their bar area with warm ambiance and great cocktails made this wait pass by super quick.  Their gin cury spice cocktail is outstanding!  The same could be said about the food.  We split the lamb entree and the basil dosa, both of which were outstanding.  Also the coconut custard is delicious.  Overall, if you like spicy food, interesting and/or southern Indian food, this is the place to go!  Great experience form beginning to end.  I'm excited to come back.

uo5vCmR3kPahryrE7bbAJg.review_text: What a wonderful experience. There's even a wonderful selection of gluten-free, dairy-free and nut-free options. The food is delicious. The sauces are wonderfully nuanced and the dishes are balanced and inventive. The staff is friendly and service is attentive. A new home away from home!!!

IjEdf04BVXZHJibHU79gnA.review_text: We ordered paper dosa and masala dosa. Loved the food and ambiance.

CgXcPydtPwf_AGGrf8ARRQ.review_text: Food Quality - Excellent. Food Taste - Excellent. Food Originality - Excellent. Customer Service - Average. Price - Good.

kb2hScTLQNS3AwF_y4ZBeQ.review_text: Great food, great ambiance. Had a good time.

Ha03F3fp-8K3b7krbFS2vA.review_text: Going by Yelp's star annotations, we definitely had an "A-OK" experience. My boyfriend and I got the samosas, the paneer and peas dosa and the uttapam sampler. The menu went a little overboard on how sustainable, seasonal or organic something was, and they even sell 'house purified' water for like $5/750mL. I'm sorry, but that's ridiculous.  The samosas were good, one northern and one southern style samosa come per order - but the most interesting part of the dish was the tamarind sauce and chutney.  The dosa had 95% paneer, and a few little fresh peas dotted throughout. The accompanying coconut, tomato and sambar dipping sauces were fine. A little bland upon bland, then you hit the through-the-roof hot sambar, and nothing seemed very balanced.   We asked our waiter (who liked pointing at us with two index fingers kind of like the Fonz) what the different uttapams were in the sampler, because one with onions was actually really delicious, and he was like 'well, I couldn't tell ya'. After a few minutes he was like 'oh, it's probably the green onion one.' Gotcha.  This was our second time here, and that'll probably be it for us. Uddupi palace is way more up our alley - intimate and more sincere, none of the thick pretense floating around Dosa on Fillmore and definitely no Fonz-finger-pointing.

qZwehAvS51R1AQygzR_9IA.review_text: Very classy spot. Think large open inside with large glass windows and black armchairs.  Service was excellent. Our glasses were never more than half-empty and we received very good recommendations on what to order from our waiter.  My friend and I ordered the spicy basil dosa and the paneer "frankie". Both were exceptionally tasty.  Overall, highly recommended.

UySLQuZU6SOuuMO4J74x7w.review_text: Wow i really liked this place. It is expensive though and the potions are small.  However the flavor was faaaantastic!  Ask the waitress/waiter for recommendation for spiciness level, because their dishes can get super hot.  Also get a variety, because everything has its own great taste.  High ceilings and fine dining.

61KaLPuWHwSi6i_eYX4-RQ.review_text: Dosas, where have you been all my life? I don't know how I've made it this far into my love affair with food of all kinds -- including PLENTY o' Indian cuisine -- without knowing that these amazing, giganto, flavor-filled crepes even existed!  The illustrious Tiffany N. took us baby CMs under her wing while in Frisco, and by gum, if this lady doesn't know her stuff. Dosa on Fillmore is a real treasure. Not only is it a beautiful space, especially if you seated up on the balcony portion we did, but everyone from the hostess staff to the busboys were friendly, accommodating, and offered their advice and suggestions without hesitation. Since I don't know of a place in Northern VA that serves dosas (yet! I'm making it my mission to find one!), obviously that was what must-order for me. But before we got to that, as a table we shared some appetizers that are making my mouth water all over again just thinking about them!  The North & South Samosa dish was a fabulous way to highlight the difference between the two types of Indian cuisine. I'm actually not really sure which was which (bad Gretchen...) but one was your traditional potato samosa, and the other was more like a triangular spring roll, flatter and crispier with vegetables inside. Both were equally delicious, especially with my favorite tamarind sauce all up in thurr.  The lamb meatballs and a chicken appetizer dish that I can't remember the name of were also incredibly delicious. The meatballs are pretty spicy, so be forewarned, and the chicken had a good zip to it as well, but came with a yogurt sauce that cooled everything down to  be nice and mellow. Mm-mmm.  Okay, so onto the main event: the dosa! I got the paneer & peas dosa, which actually doesn't come in a single bigger-than-your-head shaped monstrosity but is broken up into three deceptively proportioned looking crepes. I say deceptive, however, because it was still an incredible amount of food! Melty cheese, smashed and  whole peas, all wrapped up in a fluffy crepe... I'm sure it's no stretch for you to imagine exactly how delicious the entire thing was! I appreciated our waitress's tip to dip into all three sauces at once. It was like a flavor 'splosion in my mouth!  I also got a chance to steal from--I mean, share with--my neighbors, so I tried the roasted garlic dosa as well as the crispy paper dosa. Both were, again, delicious, and I really liked the traditional masala potatoes that came inside the paper. I will be going back to Dosa on Fillmore in a heartbeat the next time I fly back to San Francisco, you can bet on that!

upi5o2y96CSGDUy01wfepQ.review_text: A fun and unique twist on traditional south indian cuisine with a variety of tasty dosas. I think the authenticity of the food is probably mediocre at best by indian standards and you're paying more for the ambience because dosas, though tasty, are traditionally served in smaller cafes or street side in India or in indian neighborhoods across the US. However, I'm a sucker for ambience and didn't mind this particularly because its a good excuse to bring others to introduce them to south indian cuisine in a cool atmosphere where you can sample dosas in a variety of american and indian flavors. The paper dosa is tasty, though the size might be a bit surprising if you're unfamiliar with dosas. White truffle masala is also an interesting idea. Overall, a creative and worthwhile eating experience. I wish there were more restaurants doing fusion south indian food.

hOnGyOZ0aOvub06PPGeJXQ.review_text: I don't know what's better - the amazing food or the best drinks. Spicy beverages? Yes, please!  Eating here is always an adventure. 4 stars because the older male bartender is always a grump.

Jiptar-MXhgKnJ5VLetieQ.review_text: The staff at Dosa went above and beyond tonight to ensure I had the perfect meal. This has always been a favorite neighborhood spot; we often bring out-of-town guests here. When we got invited to a birthday dinner tonight, I was concerned because of a recent dietary restriction: no chillies, tomatoes, peppers, potatoes, eggplant. I looked at the menu and saw nothing that I could order. Even my favorite cocktail, the Peony, has a dash of chili.  I called ahead and spoke to Todd (the manager). He agreed it would be tricky - most dishes at Dosa have up to 30 ingredients that are mixed ahead of time. He told me to ask for him when I arrived. So my husband and I got there about 15 minutes early and Todd spoke with the chefs to see what they could make especially for me. By the time the rest of the party arrived, he already had my order set and informed my waiter. They brought me two dishes that weren't on the menu: an appetizer of scallops with tamarind sauce and Uttapam with mushroom and onions. And I got my Peony (sans chili).  No one at my table even noticed that I wasn't eating the other shared dishes. I was so relieved and grateful that the staff took the time and care to meet my specific needs. I noticed how they treated the other guests as well (one friend had a cashew allergy and our waiter carefully checked the dishes for him). All 10 guests at our table were happy with the attentive service and the delicious food.   Bravo, Dosa! You already had 5 stars in my book; I would give you 6 tonight if I could.

ylnEwZk1_a9e7a3mC_OZ4w.review_text: Service was horrendous! We went for lunch on Sunday.  There were 3 of us.  Only 2 of us were served.  We were ignored by the waiter and the hostess and manager were of no help.  We even had trouble getting our check so we could leave.  How hard could it have been to ladle out another bowl of soup????

Iy7gBdaaM291508wqoqzVw.review_text: Dosa on Fillmore (DoF) is a very peculiar Indian restaurant. Our waitress recommended the house special flat bread creations: two dosas and one uttapam. Presentation is gorgeous. Flavors are spicy and potent. The house chips and a pale ale from Paso Robles saved me from overload. I can't handle much in the way of hot hot food, and I slipped in under the danger zone tonight at DoF.  The included soup is too intense, but I managed to consume half of it. The included green chutney is mild and pleasant, but the red sauce isn't.  Decor and furnishings are spectacular. Sit in a corner booth if you can for comfort and people watching.  Take the advice of your server. One dish each is plenty filling, especially when you share. The overall trend is quite spicy, but you will survive with your server's assistance.  I had the huge sweet potato dosa, and it was impressive and flavorful. My wife had the summer uttapam that was attractive and delicious. My favorite was actually our friend's spicy chile dosa that was not too spicy at all, and had excellent flavors and texture.  Salted caramel ice cream was fine for mini-dessert, but the toasted cocoanut sorbet was a total dud: grainy and lacking in cohesiveness.  Not sure if we'll return any time soon, but it was very memorable and high quality.

ImYRAU_19IkuSRqGXZmQVw.review_text: Pros: - delicious dosa and uttapan (with Americanized fillings) - friendly staff and short wait for table  Cons: - a tad pricey for dosa - I don't have much to say (doesn't that in itself say a lot)  Bottom line: I will be back with my dosa-obsessed friend, but if you want more reasonably priced South Indian food, try Vik's in Berkeley

bGPaNsTLxN6n4kbQwCPkew.review_text: I was in SF for an evening and really wanted to go to State Bird Provisions. Silly me, walking in without a reservation and thinking I might be seated. The hostess suggested I try Dosa. I headed down there and found something that was not at all what I expected!  The restaurant itself is really beautiful, with unusual, large-scale proportions.   The service was fantastic. At first, I suspected our server was going to be completely overbearing, but he turned out to be fantastic. We were overwhelmed by the menu (not your traditional Indian restaurant fare, because it's Southern Indian, I guess?), asked him for suggestions, and he walked us through the menu in detail, pointing out his favorites and also the dishes that were popular among guess.  All the food was intensely flavorful, beautiful, had a nice amount of heat without being too spicy (we had a couple of non-spice eaters in our party).  When we sat down, they brought us a bowl of papadam. We were expecting some sort of sauce or something for dipping, but none was brought. So we dug in. It was really flavorful, with whole cumin seeds, and completely addictive.  For four of us, we ordered two small plates and three larger dishes. Shredded Duck: A caramelized onion uttapam with duck vindaloo topped with tiny greens and some shredded watermelon radish. Beware, it's very tiny. However, it is highly delicious. South Indian Bhel Puri: An amazing salad of puffed rice, green mango, beets, potatoes, tomatoes, onion, cilantro. Everything is cut up into tiny pieces and is impossibly light (like, the weight when you spoon it onto your plate is nothing), crisp, and an amazing combination of flavors. Served with two different chutneys; one was green and chimichurri-esque, and the other was tamarind and sweet. White Truffle Masala Dosa: A huge, light dosa, crisp on the edges and softer in the middle, wrapped around mashed potatoes. The whole thing was buttery and redolent of white truffle. Super simple, but so delicious. Winter Uttapam: A thicker version of a dosa, almost like a frittata, with the toppings cooked into it. This one had sunchokes, potatoes, spinach, sundried tomatoes, trumpet mushrooms, and caramelized fennel. It was tasty, but with that line up of toppings, it wasn't as flavorful as I expected. The three sauces it was served with were all delicious: coconut chutney (mild), tomato chutney (a little heat), and sambar, this incredible soup that I ate straight out of the bowl. That may have been poor form, but it was totally worth it.  Kerala Fish Moilee: Sustainably-caught halibut in a pool of a red coconut sauce that was impossibly flavorful, citrusy, and spiced, over coconut rice. There was this amazing salad served with it with Brussels sprouts, butternut squash, and caramelized red onion. The whole plate was just beautiful.   I wasn't planning to drink...didn't even really want to, but I couldn't pass up the opportunity to try one of their cocktails once I saw the list. I would've liked to try six of them, but settled on the Peony (Plymouth gin, hisbiscus masala nectar, coconut milk, lime, bird's eye chile). It was beautiful (a recurring theme at this place), light pink, opaque with coconut milk, and with a swath of lime zest on the top. It was balanced and flavorful, not too sweet, and the coconut milk was a nice counterpoint to the spiciness of the food.   Dosa is totally unlike any other Indian restaurant I've ever been to, and I loved it.

vjwLL41-EOQQkLSonUMdGw.review_text: Finally making it out to Dosa for a Sunday birthday brunch two weeks back, our group of 10 was promptly seated once our reservation time rolled around, with a handful of our party milling around their bar prior to this. After perusing a fairly extensive brunch menu, we ordered the following to share: * Chennai Chicken ($11) - A different take on what I believe is usually a curry-like dish, Dosa prepares their Chennai chicken as strips of lightly-fried white meat, served up with a yogurt dipping sauce. Great, bold, flavor, with a bit of kick to top things off. * Samosas "North & South" ($9) - More or less your standard samosas, the South was filled with caramelized onions and veggies, while the North was simply filled with spiced potatoes. Despite my love of potatoes, I found the South to be much tastier, with greater flavor. However, when had with the sauces, both were quite tasty. While I ordered the following for myself: * Okra Kolambu ($13) [ flic.kr/p/dp67ut ] - While I find the texture of okra to be a bit weird (admit it, okra is a tad slimy), this was actually a very tasty dish, mixing up savory and sweet flavors with a hint of spice. While most will probably find this to be a single serving, I easily had enough leftovers for seconds. * Rum with South Indian Monsoon ($6 + ?) - Normally a virgin drink, the ingredients (citrus, mint, ginger, juice, and soda) screamed out for a splash of rum. Two others in the group agreed, and not one of us was disappointed by the delicious cocktail that arrived moments later. With enjoyable food and great service, Dosa is definitely on my to-revisit list. And while their dinner menu is definitely more in the $$$ tier, their brunch options price out to a more affordable $$. The only thing about the menu that raised an eyebrow was the pricing of items: having appetizers priced the same as entrees seemed rather unusual. ***Accessibility Info*** Venue - A large, spacious, and multi-level restaurant, maneuverability and accessibility should not pose any problems, as long as you remain on the lower level. In fact, I doubt they have any way of getting to the upper level aside from the winding staircase. Bathroom - Large and spacious, just like the venue itself, with all the usual ADA accoutrements.

qcnEuPx5_27dKAZpS0Kttg.review_text: This place is amazing!!! Their version of a margarita is Devine. As well as the chennai chicken.  I could eat two orders of that chicken.  Sat at the bar and Terry was a very informative, brilliant bar tender. Tx for making our meal even better then it tasted.  My boyfriend and I will be returning for sure;)

o1Mvvr9czvCBxFe0XGd30g.review_text: One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco, if you love Indian food you have to try this place. The Dosas and Uttapams are amazing, go with the South Indian Moons uttapams.

up5v9ZVuZhtjWmnDBhKM8Q.review_text: The best Dosa experience ever period. The place is great, has a high-end experience but not very expensive.  My favorites are the paneer-moong-watermelon salad, kale pakoras, all of their dosas.

Ve0LUwcrzxL7w0RYgY4Aaw.review_text: What hasn't been said in the over 1200 reviews already?! I'll do my best to keep this simple and easy.  I came here with a large group of co-workers and Dosa was more than accommodating. Not only did the server introduce herself to the group and offer some fabulous dinner suggestions, she was also quick to offer some great wine pairings. There's nothing better than being waited on by someone who is both friendly and knowledgeable.  A big fan of Indian food I'd somehow never tried dosa before. With the suggestion of the white truffle Dosa I could barely wait to get my dinner! In almost no time at all we were served a number of lovely appetizers. From lamb kebabs to samosas, it was all delicious. Then out came my dosa. WOW! It was massive, it was light and flaky and it was de-double-licious. Just thinking of it right now makes me want to hop on a plane back to the Fillmore and get another plate full. The server had mentioned it was her personal favorite item and boy was that a great anecdote. I can't wait to come back and eat more. The portion was huge and I shared with with friends.... but it was SO GOOD I'll probably come next time and eat it all for myself.

ChoNOyJUpHauiGWxeAfYEg.review_text: What a place this is... great food, excellent service, and worth the wait!  My wife and I went to Dosa in February without a reservation, and were told there's a 45-minute wait. We heard how good this place was though, and decided to wait -- excellent decision. Our server was extremely helpful and recommended a few dishes to us.  We started with a special brussel sprouts dish, which was delicious. I also had an order of pekoras. For the entree, my wife had an uttapam, while I had a dosa. We both loved our dishes so much! So tasty! They have a lot of options for vegetarians and others with dietary restrictions -- my wife and I had no trouble finding something good!  Since it is a little pricey, I'd recommend it for special occassions. I'm totally going back though!

UyhnjAlyMXtbR-qB5kkhlQ.review_text: First of all, stay away if you are on any sort of low carb diet.  My friends and I shared the following:  * Green mango and paneer dosa * White truffle oil dosa * Spicy basil dosa * Uttapam with sunchokes and sweet peppers * Duck vindaloo * Prawn masala  The ratio of 1.5 dishes for each person was a bit aggressive.  The tomato, coconut, and lentil dipping sauces that accompanied the dosa were delicious. The flavors of the various types of dosa were not as distinct as I would have imagined. I think the flavor of the dough and dipping sauces overwhelmed the other ingredients, so the meal started to feel a bit monotonous.  I was stuffed with carbs by the time the entrees were served and could not fully appreciate them. The vindaloo sauce was good over rice though.

XVpq1dc0MGvKJKzmfpb_JQ.review_text: I got the watermelon salad, crispy fish, spicy basil dosa, and the mango shrimp. The salad and spicy basil dosa were amazing. The gimlet drink I got was refreshing and spicy-one of the better drinks I've ever had. I've never had dosa before and the waitress took us through the hold menu the server explained everything on how to eat it and the service overall was wonderful. Very fun experience and ill definitely be back.

wqoXYLWmpkEH0YvTmHBsJQ.review_text: I really like this dosa location. The food is also always delicious. The best dish I've ordered here has got to be the channa bhatura. It comes out as a large puff dough thing. It's definitely not healthy but it's really good. If you haven't tried it you definitely should! They allow you to reserve a table via opentable which I really find handy. As a pac heights resident, this place is on the top of my $$$ list.

ilr5hbxy0-5hLWxQwj0W8w.review_text: Delicious food and drinks . Drinks definitely have a uniqueness . I absolutely loved the decoration and photos placed inside.  classy yet casual.  Besides the fact that two of the dishes we ordered were not available , everything else was great . Customer service ,ambiance ,music was on point !  will definitely visit again .

hM0hJshCQzWh0x8OYuTnjQ.review_text: Great dosas!  My wife and i have sampled dosas all over the Bay Area and the two we had today at Dosa were spot on.  Both dosas were dark brown and crisp.  The fillings (masala and keema) were tasty (especially the keema).  The red and green sauces were delicious.  And even the soup was good.

U2MkCxrJAsibjclc4ZR3Mg.review_text: Great ambience and good food! It's one of the fancier Indian restaurants in San Francisco. There is generally a long wait during busy hours and so it's highly recommended to make a reservation in advance. I liked the vada paav (sliders) and of course dosas.

AHKSSaeYZ8h4nOXm5tyWzg.review_text: After driving all day to the lovely city of San Francisco, we were famished. My hope for trying the up and coming State Bird Provisions was immediately dashed as they were fully booked even on a Tuesday evening. Thankfully our local hosts had good alternatives, and as it was nearby we headed over to Dosa who graciously accommodated us last minute.   Dosa is gorgeous. It's a stunning space, the room is expansive and atmospheric with beautifully rendered art that blends old and new. In effect, it's a representation of the Southern Indian dishes available that are both authentic and modern. The food pleasantly reminded me of Vij's in Vancouver, the best Indian food I've ever had. Anywhere. This isn't quite at that level, and its not as consistent but then what is? For the most part, the food was jaw-droppingly good, though interestingly my least enjoyable dish was the namesake dosa.   Before I forget, the bread is amaaaaazing here. There is no naan (wrong part of the country), but you won't notice. Bhatura is a must order. It's a giant, light fluffy piece of edible pastry heaven. Pretty sure I could live off of it. Papadon was equally good, one of the best I've come across. Light and lovely. Paratha was also quite nice.  Samosas North and South are wonderfully prepared here, perfectly crispy. Bookended with two different but equally divine sauces, especially the sweet one.  Lotus Stem Dayboat Scallops were exquisite. Again balanced by two ridiculously addictive sauces, this was my favorite dish of the evening.  Rasam Fire Broth was interestingly named, because it wasn't particularly fiery but it was extremely tasty. It had a moderate kick, but a very good and interesting flavor.  Roasted Chili and Garlic Dosa was exceedingly hot. Almost unpleasantly so, but keep in mind I like moderately spicy not hair curling hot, so if you like really spicy it might be wonderful.   Mangalorean Prawn Masala was nicely prepared. Great flavor, nice balanced spice. Quite enjoyable.  Duck Vindaloo was very good.   Sun Choke Uttapam wasn't that successful for my palate, possibly it was the version we chose, but I don't think I'd visit that dish again.  Surprisingly we ended with a fantastic dessert.
